results: – Tens of thousands of protesters again took to the streets of Cairo and elsewhere in Egypt today, in the latest challenge to Hosni Mubarak's 30-year rule. The day's demonstrations were smaller than those that rocked Tunisia earlier this month, but they were still the biggest in years, reports AP. Protesters are calling for an end to Mubarak's regime and for him to step down immediately, notes CNN. The government has warned that it will not allow any "provocative movement," and security forces have been using tear gas and water cannons in an attempt to disperse the demonstrators, reports Rush Limbaugh.

– Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak finally addressed the nation this morning in a nationally televised address, declaring that he has asked his government to resign, reports CNN. Mubarak also formed a new government, which will be sworn in tomorrow, and promised to push ahead with reforms. “I will ask the new government to have clear and specific responsibilities to deal, in a calculated way, with the vital next phase,” he said, according to a translation of his remarks picked up by al-Jazeera.

– Egypt's government has shut down al-Jazeera and all TV and radio stations in the country, CNN reports, as protests continue for a seventh day. Al-Jazeera's offices have been looted and its journalists have been prevented from leaving the country, according to the network's chief executive. The network has also cut off its live feed from Cairo, according to CNN's Anderson Cooper, who is on the ground. Egypt's state-run television is reporting at least 38 are dead following massive protests demanding the end of the 30 years of President Hosni Mubarak's rule. Witnesses describe a scene that suggests anarchy. One man said people are parading the streets, walking around with baseball bats and knifes. "There is chaos and confusion," Cooper said. "One man said people are parading the streets, walking around with baseball bats and knifes."

– Protesters and pro-Mubarak supporters clashed in Cairo’s Tahrir Square today, leaving at least three people dead and more than 600 injured, according to the country’s health minister. The violence came after supporters of Mubarak, who has served 30 years in power, attacked protesters in the square, according to al-Jazeera. Mubarak, speaking to leaders of his new government read on state-run TV, acknowledged peaceful protests and the country’s economy but called out those who he said used religion to spread fear through hooliganism, CNN reports.

– It's that time of the year again, when we take a look back at some of the best movies and TV shows of the last quarter-century. Here's a look at some of the more notable winners and losers of the Golden Globes, as voted on by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences: ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ;

– Algeria's President Abdelaziz Bouteflika today lifted a state of emergency that has been in place since 1992, CNN reports. The move is one of several demanded by demonstrators in recent protests against the government, which imposed the emergency decree in a crackdown against Islamic political parties in 1992. The clampdown triggered an Islamist insurgency that left more than 100,000 dead, according to human rights groups. Those taking to the streets in recent demonstrations have also called for the release of prisoners and the restoration of individual and collective freedoms. In Iraq, hundreds of protesters took to the streets today, inspired by protests elsewhere in the region. They railed against the government's inability to provide basic services and complained of food, water, and power shortages. The biggest demonstration took place in al Hamza, a relatively poor town in a heavily Shiite region about 125 miles south of Baghdad. Two Iraqi interior ministry officials—who, per policy, did not speak by name due to security concerns— estimated that nearly 1,000 people participated. The protesters walked toward a local council building, trying to force their way in as they hurled rocks inside the compound and at police outside, the Iraqi Interior Ministry officials said.

– As anti-Mubarak protesters took to the streets in cities around the world today, France suspended its sale of arms to Egypt and called for an end to violence, CNN reports. France did not deliver any weapons to Egypt between 2005 and 2008, according to a US Congressional report. The United States is Egypt's largest arms supplier by far, delivering $ 4.8 billion in weaponry to the country in that period. Protesters in Atlanta, Los Angeles, Paris, New York, London, Tokyo, and the West Bank city of Ramallah took to the streets today demanding the immediate resignation of Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. Demonstrations were held in Atlanta, Los Angeles, Paris, New York, London, Tokyo, and the West Bank city of Ramallah. Click here for more.

– Egypt's newly freed Google exec Wael Ghonim gave an emotional interview to CNN yesterday, saying he's "ready to die" for change and that he doesn't want to be the face of the protests. "This is not about me. This is about the people. This is our country," said Ghonim, who was released from 12 days of detention yesterday. "This country is our country," he told the crowd in Cairo's Tahrir Square, referring to Hosni Mubarak's government. "We are ready to die for this country." CNN notes that it was the first time ordinary Egyptians heard a protest leader passionately defend the revolt, free from the "vicious anti- protester propaganda of the state."

– Opposition leader Mohammed ElBaradei has a message for Hosni Mubarak: "Stop lying." In an interview with CNN's Anderson Cooper, ElBaradei called for the Egyptian leader to step down immediately. "If he doesn't, he will be accountable to the people," he said. "If he doesn't leave, he will be accountable to them." ElBaradei also called for the formation of a transitional government that would include Mubarak and Vice President Omar Suleiman. "We need a government that is inclusive," he said. "We need a government that is not dominated by the Mubarak family. We need a government that is led by Mohamed ElBaradei." Click here for more on ElBaradei and here for more on Mubarak's resignation.

– George Soros has a new book out, and it's a doozy. It's called The Credit Crisis of 2008 and What It Means by George Soros, and it's a stinging indictment of the Bush administration, Congress, the Federal Reserve, and the financial industry as a whole. "The complicity reaches high and low: reckless financiers, dishonest mortgage brokers, credulous consumers and home buyers," writes Soros in Public Affairs. "But the blame starts at the top, where those in charge—the Bush administration, Congress, the Federal Reserve and financial industry leaders—closed or averted their eyes as the crisis approached."

– The Freddie Mac Foundation, one of the largest corporate donors in the Washington, DC, area, put all charitable grants on hold when the government took over the mortgage giant—just two days before a major grant to a local preschool was expected to be approved, the Washington Post reports. The foundation, founded by the former Freddie Mac CEO, was one of the largest corporate donors in the Washington area for 15 years. But when the government announced that it had taken over the mortgage giant to avert a collapse, officials put all charitable grants on hold, just two days before the preschool's grant was expected to be approved.

– The government’s rescue of Lehman Brothers isn’t just bad news for the American people, it’s bad for the free market itself, writes David Brooks in the New York Times. “This unprecedented intrusion of government is coming in the waning days of the administration of a Republican president who made privatization, deregulation and a faith in free markets the centerpiece of his economic policies and of his political agenda,” Brooks writes. “It is so extraordinary that the government now finds itself hip—deep in the direct management of the financial system”—from the “harsh discipline of markets and the consequences of their own misjudgments.”

– The government's plan to buy stakes in AIG and Merrill Lynch may not be a long-term solution to the financial crisis, but it's an important first step, writes David Leonhardt in the New York Times. "This is the first time since the Great Depression that the federal government has stepped in to buy a major financial firm in this way," he writes. "It’s also the first time since the Depression that the federal government has purchased stakes in two major financial firms in this way." If the plan fails, Leonhardt predicts, the crisis will spread to other areas of the economy, including credit markets, which are already feeling the strain. "This is not the end of the crisis," he writes. "It’s just the beginning." Click here for Leonhardt's full column.

– The Treasury Department's decision to pump $85 billion into AIG in exchange for an 80% stake in the company isn't going over well on the left. "It's a classic case of Uncle Sam taking over a failing company," writes Felix Salmon at Reuters. "What's really happened is that Wall Street's business model has collapsed," he writes. "Greed and fear, which routinely govern financial markets, have seeded this global crisis." At Bloomberg, Andrew Harrer agrees. "You know you're in a heap of trouble when the lender of last resort suddenly runs out of money," he writes. "The Federal Reserve was forced to ask the Treasury yesterday to borrow some extra money to replenish its coffers. If there was any good news in that, it was that investors here and abroad were eager to help out, having decided that the only safe place to put their money is in US government securities."

– The Wall Street Journal is out with a list of the top 10 people responsible for the current financial crisis, and it includes none other than Henry Blodget of Business Insider. Blodget is the founder and CEO of Blodget Capital, a hedge fund he co-founded that has lost hundreds of millions because of bad investments. The list was compiled by FactCheck.org, a nonprofit group that fact-checks articles before they appear on the Journal's website. Here's the full list: Lloyd Blankfein, CEO of Goldman Sachs: He's "one of the most reviled figures on Wall Street," and his firm has lost hundreds of millions because of bad investments. Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase: He's "one of the most reviled figures," and his firm has lost hundreds of millions because of bad investments. Lloyd Blankfein, CEO of Goldman Sachs: He's "one of the most reviled figures" on Wall Street, and his firm has lost hundreds of millions because of bad investments. – President Bush and John McCain will meet at the White House today to discuss the financial crisis and the proposed $700 billion bailout, reports the Washington Post. Bush said in a White House address yesterday that the US economy is in danger unless Congress acts quickly to approve the plan. “Our entire economy is in danger,” he said. “It is going to be part of the president’s job to deal with more than one thing at once.”

– Citigroup’s acquisition of Wachovia is good news for Wall Street, but it’s not great news for ordinary Americans, writes Eve Applebaum in the Washington Post. “Too many people do n’t understand the seriousness of the situation,” she writes. “Americans fail to understand that they are facing the real prospect of a decade of little or no economic growth because of the bursting of a credit bubble that they helped create and that now threatens to bring down the global financial system. Politicians worry less about preventing a financial meltdown than about ideology, partisan posturing, and teaching people a lesson.”

– Charles Krauthammer isn't happy with Henry Paulson's response to criticism that subprime mortgages led to the current financial crisis. "Of all the reporting and editorializing that I have read and heard concerning our current financial crisis, Marc Fisher's Sept. 25 Metro column,'' Krauthammer writes in the Washington Post. "Mr. Fisher was able to highlight the core of the problem in terms we can all understand. These business operators based their practices on judicious use of their own cash along with money borrowed sensibly—RRB—and are prospering. They used real money to increase their ability to provide goods and services at a profit. Contrast that with the 'financial sector' and its egregiously unsound business practices." Krauthammer also takes issue with the Bush administration's plan to buy up bad mortgage-backed securities. "The theory underlying the bailout plan stalled in Congress is that rescuing the finance industry will restore market stability and that the benefits will eventually trickle down to average Americans," he writes. "The old order—the Reagan—age institutions built on the premise that the market can do no wrong and the government no right—is dying. A new order, in which Wall Street plays a diminished role and Washington a larger one,

– The current financial crisis is worse than the 9/11 attacks because it has changed the way the world views us, writes Paul Krugman in the New York Times. “While 9/11 changed the way we view the world, the current financial crisis has changed the way the world views us. And it will also change, in some very fundamental ways, the way the world works,” he writes. “The claim that the financial crisis reflects Bush—McCain deregulation is not only nonsense. It is the sort of nonsense that could matter.” Click here for his full column.

– The US is in the midst of the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, and it's not just US banks that are in trouble. Icelanders, too, are feeling the effects, the Washington Post reports, with the island nation's stock price plummeting 21% this week. "The bad news just keeps coming for Icelanders, who in the last week have seen the international financial empire that they built on this remote North Atlantic island start to crumble," writes David Leonhardt in the New York Times. "The notion of government ownership in the financial sector, even as minority stakeholder Icelanders say they see as the foundation of the American system, goes against what market purists say they see as the foundation of the American system." In other financial news: The stock market's prolonged tumble has wiped out about $2 trillion in Americans' retirement savings in the past 15 months, a blow that could force workers to stay on the job longer than planned, rein in spending and possibly further stall an economy reliant on consumer dollars, Congress' top budget analyst said yesterday. The dwindling of these assets—about a 20% decline overall—is another setback just as many people are grappling with higher gas and food prices, more credit card debt, declining home values and less access to

– The Treasury Department's plan to invest $250 billion in nine of the nation's banks amounts to a partial nationalization, insiders tell the Wall Street Journal, in what amounts to a major reversal for Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson. In a momentous meeting yesterday afternoon in Washington, Paulson told the executives of nine leading banks that they needed to participate in the program for the good of the national economy. The US government is dramatically escalating its response to the financial crisis by planning to invest $ 250 billion in the country's banks, forcing nine of the largest to accept a Treasury stake in what amounts to a partial nationalization. News that European governments also planned to take stakes in their banks and anticipation of new US measures unleashed a tremendous surge in US stock prices yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average soaring to the biggest percentage gain since the 1930s, up 11.1%. It ended at 936.42 points higher, the largest point gain ever, just days after the Dow had its steepest weekly decline in history.

– The US government’s financial rescue plan is unlikely to be a long-term solution to the global financial crisis, according to an analysis by Ross Douthat for the Washington Post. “Most of the advice offered to solve the financial crisis has been based on the wrong diagnosis and has naturally offered the wrong remedy,” Douthat writes. “The problem does not derive from a market that failed because of deregulation and that has to be rescued by the government; the problem originated with government policies and political directives that caused market signals to malfunction.” Click here for the full piece.

– The financial crisis is far from over, but the urge to learn from it already is “irresistible,” writes Ted Warren in the Washington Post. European leaders are pushing for a new Bretton Woods summit, modeled after the 1944 gathering that helped prevent a repeat of the Great Depression. Britain and France are working on staging the new version within weeks. “Europe will get it,” said French President Nicolas Sarkozy before jetting off to Camp David, where President Bush meekly gave in to him. Warren’s fourth theme: “The idea that the dividing line between the market and the state, between conservative economic thinking and progressive intervention, will now shift decisively away from the market. A second is that America’s status as a free—market beacon and provider of the dollar standard will decline sharply.”

– The global financial crisis is good for John McCain, at least according to some al-Qaeda supporters, who say the candidate is the best choice to continue George W. Bush's failed foreign policy. "Al-Qaeda will have to support McCain in the coming election," said a commentary posted Monday on the extremist site al-Hesbah, which is closely linked to the terrorist group. It said the Arizona Republican would continue the "failing march of his predecessor." The commentary was one of several posted by Taliban or al-Qaeda allied groups in recent days that trumpeted the global financial crisis and predicted further decline for the United States and other Western powers. Click here for more.

– Alan Greenspan's testimony before a House panel yesterday didn't go over well with his critics. Here's a look at some of the lines generating the most attention today from the Wall Street Journal, the New York Times, and the Los Angeles Times: “You found that your view of the world, your ideology was not right, it was not working.”—Paul Krugman, New York Times, on Greenspan's view that “hedge funds seemed unstoppable during the boom years, lavishing riches upon their investors and managers alike. Now that those riches are quickly disappearing, some analysts are blaming them for propagating the high—risk culture that led to the crisis on Wall Street.”—Stephen Gandel, New York Times, on Greenspan's view that “hedge funds should not be regulated.”

– The Wall Street Journal and Washington Post are out with stories today detailing how President Obama's team has been chastened in the wake of the financial crisis. The story by the Journal's Mark Gongloff and the Post's Craig Whitlock are based on interviews with people close to Obama who say the president has been chastened in meetings with top advisers, as well as in his public speeches. The Post's Whitlock describes Obama as "so steady in public" that he didn't hide his vexation when he summoned his top advisers to meet with him on Sept. 14. "He said, 'You know, maybe we can just win it on the issues,'" Whitlock writes.

– The editors of the Wall Street Journal have a message for President-elect Obama: Don't wait until he takes office to address the nation's economic crisis. "Further legislation to deal with the economic crisis should not wait until the new president takes office," they write in an editorial today. "Fortunately, the president-elect will be a senator and can propose legislation without waiting to be sworn in as president. Immediately after Nov. 4 the winner could, and should, take the lead in the legislative process."

– Group of 20 leaders are meeting in Washington today to discuss solutions to the global financial crisis, and Brazil's president is calling for a bigger role for developing countries. “This is a global crisis and demands global solutions,” Luiz In cio Lula da Silva said in opening remarks at the meeting, according to the Wall Street Journal. “The crisis started in advanced economies. It is a result of the blind belief in the market’s self—regulation capacity and, by and large, of the lack of control of the activities of financial agents.”

– The editors of the New York Times agree with President Bush that this weekend's G20 summit is a big deal: It's "the most decisive moment for American—style capitalism since July 1944," they write. "Although things have evolved considerably since that confab at Bretton Woods, the United States has remained the world's most successful economy, and the rest of the world has moved, by reason of its example and its anxieties, toward an embrace of its economic model." That's about to change. "The United States, which has gone from the world's largest creditor to its largest debtor, can no longer expect to dominate the institutions of international finance and will have to share power and influence with rapidly developing countries that generate more of the growth and have more of the world's capital."

– Tim Geithner is Barack Obama’s pick for Treasury secretary, and the New York Federal Reserve Bank president will be in charge of the administration’s response to the financial crisis, insiders tell Bloomberg and the Washington Post. The 48-year-old, who has led the New York Fed since 2001, is a well-regarded economic policymaker and a close ally of Nouriel “Doctor Doom” Roubini, who predicted the 1987 stock market crash. Obama will make the announcement today in Chicago, the sources say.

– The chiefs of the World Bank and the IMF will not attend a United Nations conference this weekend aimed at drumming up aid for the world's poor, reports the New York Times. Robert Zoellick of the World Bank and Dominique Strauss- Kahn of the IMF had originally planned to lead their agencies' delegation at the conference in Doha, Qatar, but have decided to send senior advisers instead. The snub is a major setback for UN efforts to convince the financial industry to provide more aid to the world's poor.

– Iceland's prime minister resigned today in the wake of the island nation's worst economic crisis in living memory, the AP reports. Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson announced his resignation in a televised address to the nation. Gunnlaugsson says he has no choice but to step down because his government failed to solve the country's financial crisis. The country's central bank says it has lost more than half its value against the dollar in the past month as Iceland's economy shrank by more than a quarter. Gunnlaugsson says he has no choice but to resign because his government has failed to solve the crisis. He says he has no choice but to step down as prime minister because he has failed to lead the country out of the economic crisis. Iceland's central bank says it has lost more than half its value against the dollar in the past month as the country's economy shrank by more than a quarter. The country's currency, the krona, has also lost more than half its value against the dollar. Iceland is now an international destination for shopping as well as for more than traditional tourism activities.

– China is sitting on nearly $2 trillion in foreign exchange reserves and is expected to post a 9% growth rate this year, “probably the highest of any nation,” writes Mark Gongloff in the Daily Beast. “The country is sitting on almost $2 trillion in foreign exchange reserves and may post a 9% growth rate this year, probably the highest of any nation.” But China’s leaders have largely kept the door shut, arguing that Beijing can do the most good for the world by putting its own house in order. “The world has come to China’s doorstep seeking leadership,” Gongloff writes. “Yet China’s leaders have largely kept the door shut, arguing that Beijing can do the most good for the world by putting its own house in order.”

– The Bank of England and the European Central Bank both cut interest rates today in an attempt to ward off the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. The European Central Bank cut its prime interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point to 2.5%, the largest cut in its history, while the Bank of England announced a full-percentage-point cut in its interest rate, pushing it down to 2%, the Washington Post reports. Meanwhile, Nicolas Sarkozy announced a $33 billion economic stimulus plan, including cash payments to the poor, a bigger rebate on new—car purchases, and a speedup in high—cost public works projects.

– The economic crisis in the US has hit hard in South America, but the region's leaders are standing firm—and they're taking action. Peru's President Alan Garca yesterday announced a $3.4 billion bailout package, while Argentina's President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner announced a 3.8 billion package of low-cost loans to increase consumer demand and help exporters, paid for with money from the country's newly nationalized pension system, the New York Times reports. Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, meanwhile, is calling on the International Monetary Fund to help his country deal with its mounting debt, the AP reports.

– Health officials around the world are scrambling to contain the spread of swine flu, which has now killed at least 100 people in Mexico and infected at least 20 in the US. The World Health Organization has raised its pandemic alert to phase 5, the highest level, and warned that the disease has the potential to become a pandemic, the AP reports. In Europe, the first cases have been confirmed in Spain and two British people who returned from a vacation in Mexico have been hospitalized in Scotland. Health ministers in Spain are calling for an urgent meeting, the BBC reports. In Mexico, where at least 100 people have died from the disease, public gatherings have been canceled and many businesses have closed.

– Mexico's ambassador to China was denied access to a group of Mexicans quarantined in a Beijing hotel, the Mexican government says. China has denied discriminating against Mexicans, saying the steps it has taken are lawful and justified, the BBC reports. Meanwhile, the number of confirmed cases in the US has risen from 226 to 286, spread over 36 states, with most patients suffering mild symptoms. Five of nine UK cases of swine flu have been confirmed, taking the total to 27. Five of the nine diagnosed with H1N1 virus were year 7 pupils at Alleyn's School in south London. It is the fourth school to close.

– The death toll from swine flu in Mexico has risen to 160, according to health officials, who are urging people to stay home over the holiday weekend. Mexico has shut down much of its economy in an attempt to slow the spread of the virus, which has now been confirmed in 12 countries, including the US. In Britain, two more people have been diagnosed with the virus, bringing the total in the country to eight, the BBC reports.

– It's that time of the year again, when we take a look back at some of the best movies and TV shows of the last quarter-century. Here's a look at some of the more notable winners and losers of the Golden Globes, as voted on by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences: ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ;

– When Ros Atkins, a BBC radio presenter, came back to the UK after working in Mexico City, family and friends avoided him like he had, well, swine flu. After reading his account on the Guardian, we wondered about others who have visited Mexico recently and experienced the same sort of reaction upon returning home. If you have been to Mexico since the outbreak of the H1N1 virus, what was the reaction from loved ones? Or have you changed your travel plans as a result of the disease? Share your thoughts by sending us a response from the Guardian US Twitter page.

– The death toll from the swine flu outbreak in Mexico has risen to 81, the World Health Organization said today, and new suspected cases have been reported as far apart as Auckland in New Zealand and New York in the United States. The WHO said the virus has pandemic potential but it has stopped short of issuing a worldwide alert, while it gathers more information. In Europe, the first suspected case of the new flu strain has been reported in Britain, prompting fears it may have spread across the Atlantic from Mexico. The strain that has struck Mexico and the United States involves, in many cases, a never-before-seen strain of the H1N1 virus. The flu virus is notorious for its ability to mutate and evolve new features that allows it to escape the immune defense systems of its victims. And experts warned last night that it may be too late to contain the new outbreak, given how widespread the known cases are. If the confirmed deaths are the first signs of a pandemic, then cases are probably incubating around the world by now, said Dr Michael Osterholm, a flu expert at the University of Minnesota. Click here for more on the outbreak.

– As the death toll from the swine flu outbreak in Mexico climbs to 152, the World Health Organization has raised its pandemic alert level to phase 5, the highest level. Pandemics have occurred only twice before in history—in 1968 and 2003, notes the New York Times—but this time, the alert level is higher than it was at at the start of the last pandemic, in 1976, because of the new virus. In other swine flu news: Canada has reported its first death, a CTV reporter who traveled to Mexico earlier this month, reports the Huffington Post. He had just returned from Mexico, where the outbreak is believed to have originated. A British couple who returned from Mexico and are now being treated for the virus in a Scottish hospital have been named by their family, reports the Guardian.

– A synthetic compound may be able to stop the spread of bird flu, as well as the H5N1 strain of bird flu. Scientists in Hong Kong and the US have identified a synthetic compound which appears to be able to stop the replication of influenza viruses, including the H5N1 bird flu virus. The compound, which has yet to be tested in humans, is believed to be able to stop the spread of bird flu, as well as the H5N1 strain of bird flu, reports Reuters.

– At least two children in California have tested positive for a new strain of swine flu, and officials are looking for more cases, the Los Angeles Times reports. It's possible the children were infected by other people or not by pigs, health officials say, and they have consulted with officials in Canada, Mexico, and at the World Health Organization.

– The death toll from the swine flu outbreak in Mexico has risen to 60, the Mexican government announced today, and at least seven people have been infected in the US. The outbreak has also spread to New York, Ohio, Texas, California, and Rhode Island, the AP reports. More than 100 people have been quarantined in Mexico, where the outbreak began, and health officials are trying to contain its spread. The World Health Organization has urged people to avoid nonessential travel to Mexico. Click here for more on the outbreak, or here for facts about past flu pandemics.

– Kathleen Sebelius was sworn in as the Obama administration's new health secretary today, and President Obama said he was "thrilled that we have Secretary Sebelius taking the reins," reports Reuters. "She's going to be immediately briefed on the issues that we're working on right now." Sebelius, a former governor of Kansas, takes over a Health and Human Services department that has been criticized for its slow response to the H1N1 outbreak. Click here for more on the new virus.

– Egypt has ordered the slaughter of every pig herd in the country as a precaution against swine flu, even though the World Health Organization has ruled out the risk of infection from eating pork. The cull is a real mistake and another reason the world needs to rethink using “swine flu” to describe a virus affecting humans, a UN agency official told Reuters, adding that the decision was made “under the assumption that there will be an outbreak of swine flu.” Meanwhile, Google saw a spike in searches for information about the flu in Mexico last week even before the outbreak was widely known, the Huffington Post reports.

– The death toll from the H1N1 virus in Mexico has dropped to 26, the country’s health minister announced today, though he warned that it was still too early to relax. Most of the country will remain closed until May 11, the AP reports. Elsewhere in Mexico: Schools across the country will remain closed until May 11 to curb the spread of the virus, which has now spread to 19 countries. Mexico’s president, who wore a tie to a meeting with the nation’s health minister last week, is now wearing a tie, Reuters reports. Health Minister Jose Angel Cordova said people should take off their neckties if they want to avoid the spread of the virus. In Hong Kong, where the country’s first confirmed case of H1N1 has been traced to a Mexican tourist, 200 people and 100 staff have been quarantined in a five-star hotel.

– American troops are killing more journalists in Iraq than at any time since the US-led invasion in March 2003, according to a new report from the Committee to Protect Journalists. The number of journalists killed in Iraq has more than doubled in the last year, and the number wounded has almost doubled, the report finds. " Journalists are being killed and wounded not because they are insurgents or terrorists, but because they are doing their jobs," says a spokesman for the group, which describes itself as the world's largest network of journalists. "It's a war we are in the midst of, and it's not going to get better anytime soon." The number of journalists killed in Iraq has almost doubled in the last year, and the number of wounded has almost doubled, according to a report from the Committee to Protect Journalists. The number of journalists killed in Iraq has almost doubled in the last year, and the number of wounded has almost doubled. (Click to read about another journalist killed in Iraq.)

– The US military's top general in Iraq says American troops will stay in the country for as long as it takes to defeat the Islamic State, the AP reports. Gen. Martin Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, made the announcement in a closed-door meeting with military chiefs and other top commanders. He said the decision to keep troops in Iraq for as long as necessary was made after intelligence indicated that ISIS was on the brink of defeat. "We've been here a long time," he said. "We've been here a long time, and we're going to be here a long time." He said the decision to keep troops in Iraq was made after intelligence indicated that ISIS was on the brink of defeat. "We've been here a long time, and we're going to be here a long time," he said. "It's not a matter of if they're going to be killed, it's a matter of when they're going to be killed."

– Britain's ambassador to the US has concluded that Tony Blair was "stunned" and "flabbergasted" by George Bush's decision to go to war in Iraq and that the British prime minister "mishandled" the situation, the Telegraph reports. Christopher Meyer's long-awaited report, which will be released today, concludes that Blair's team was "stunned andflabbergasted" by Bush's decision to go ahead with the invasion despite a dossier of evidence proving that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction. "We may have been the junior partner in the enterprise but the ace up our sleeve was that America did not want to go it alone," Meyer writes in his report. "Had Britain so insisted, Iraq after Saddam might have avoided the violence that may yet prove fatal to the entire enterprise." Blair, Meyer writes, "was seduced by the proximity and glamour of US power and reluctant to negotiate conditions with George Bush for Britain's support for the war. He says Mr Blair failed to exploit his enormous leverage with Mr Bush not only to secure a precious delay but to plan for postwar Iraq."

– Robert Fisk's book on the Middle East, The Great War for Civilization, is a "flawed but fascinating survey of the Middle East in our time," writes Oliver Miles in a review in the Sydney Morning Herald. But it's also "a real war and peace, but with precious little peace." Fisk, an Australian journalist who has lived in the region for 30 years, writes of betrayal, treachery, and deceit, " nurturing this excessively long book—a real War and Peace, but with precious little peace." In fact, he writes, "One's not going to Belgium."

– In the weeks before the US-led invasion of Iraq, Britain's attorney general warned that military action could be ruled illegal and the government set up a team of lawyers to prepare for legal action in an international court, the Guardian reports. The US-led invasion of Iraq was illegal from the start, according to documents obtained by the Guardian. The documents show that the attorney general, Lord Goldsmith, warned Britain's government at least two weeks before the invasion that military action in Iraq could be ruled illegal. The US-led invasion of Iraq was illegal from the start, according to documents obtained by the Guardian. The documents show that the attorney general, Lord Goldsmith, warned Britain's government at least two weeks before the invasion that military action in Iraq could be ruled illegal. The US-led invasion of Iraq was illegal from the start, according to documents. The documents show that the attorney general, Lord Goldsmith, warned Britain's government at least two weeks before the invasion that military action in Iraq could be ruled illegal. The US-led invasion of Iraq was illegal from the start, according to documents. – Richard Gere is playing a singer in a new movie, and critics are calling it one of the year's best—if not the year's best. The actor, who plays the title role in Clash of the Titans, has been nominated for a best actor Oscar, the AP reports. The movie, directed by Roar Uthaug, tells the story of a young man's relationship with his mother, played by Olga Kurylenko. It's a far cry from Gere's usual work, notes the Los Angeles Times, which calls the movie a "potent and affecting portrait" of a man struggling to find his place in the world.

– When US and Iraqi forces launched a major offensive in the Iraqi city of Falluja in November, they said they had killed 1,200 insurgents and driven out most of the city's 300,000 residents. But a joint investigation by the Guardian and Channel 4 News finds that the true death toll is closer to 3,000—and that many of the bodies found in the streets had been buried before the offensive began. One doctor found scores of unburied corpses, rabid dogs, and a "dangerously embittered population," according to the investigation.

– Britain's Channel 4 has pulled a shocking scene from one of its most popular sitcoms. The Vicar of Dibley—"one of our gentler sitcoms"—showed two young African children in tears as their mother died on New Year's Day, the Telegraph reports. "How on earth, I wondered, would the show make us laugh after that?" says the show's creator, Julian Ovenden. "It was a very dark moment." The channel said it had pulled the scene "out of sensitivity for the children in the scene."

– Two weeks after the fall of Saddam Hussein in 2003, Iranian-Kurd filmmaker Bahman Gobadi made his way to Baghdad. With a copy of his second film, Marooned in Iraq, a road movie about a group of Iranian- Kurdish musicians seeking lost love in Saddam's benighted land, Gobadi set out to make a movie about the people of Iraq's Kurdistan region, a neglected corner of the country that had been largely ignored by the West until now. Turtles Can Fly, his first feature film, is an anti-war movie without slogans that tells the story of Kurdish people caught in the crossfire of the US-led war on terror, the New York Times reports. Gobadi, who was born in Iran but grew up in Baghdad, says he wanted to make a movie about the people of Iraq, not just the dictator. "I wanted to make a movie about the problems of the people of Iraq, not just the problems of the dictator," he says.

– George W. Bush’s inauguration is going to be the most expensive, most security-obsessed event in Washington DC’s history—and one of the biggest parties in American history. With a price tag of up to 50 million dollars, the Jan. 20 event is expected to be one of the biggest parties in American history, but half of the country will be left out of the celebration, the Telegraph reports. An army of 10,000 police, secret service officers, and FBI agents will patrol the capital for four days of massive celebrations that some critics have derided as reminiscent of the lavish shindigs thrown by Louis XIV, France’s extravagant Sun King. More than 150,000 people, nearly all Republicans whose tickets are a reward for election work, will pack the Mall to hear Bush take his oath of office on Jan. 20.

– The US military's 10-year search for Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction has come to an end. The head of the Iraq Survey Group has returned to the US and will deliver a final report in the spring that will be almost identical to the interim assessment he delivered to Congress last October, reports the Guardian. That assessment found Saddam had destroyed his last weapons of mass destruction more than 10 years ago and his capacity to build new ones had been dwindling for years by the time of the second Gulf war. In terms of the weapons hunt in a proactive sense, it has concluded, and the report is being tweaked a bit but it will be largely unchanged."

– The US military's plan to build a base in the ruins of Babylon amounts to "one of the most reckless acts of cultural vandalism in recent memory," according to a report released by the British Museum. The base, which has been used for the past two years, "is tantamount to establishing a military camp around the Great Pyramid in Egypt or around Stonehenge in Britain," says the report, which was seen by the Guardian. Archaeologists had warned that the base would damage the site, but authorities ignored the warnings, says the report, which calls the destruction "unnecessary and avoidable."

– A lawyer for one of three British soldiers charged in the abuse of detainees in Iraq told a court today that superiors called for a crackdown on looters at the time, the Guardian reports. Twenty-two photos of soldiers abusing naked and bound detainees, including images of them being forced to feign sexual acts, sparked outrage after being released by the court last night. The photos were shown to a panel of seven officers, who also saw photos of a grimacing Iraqi who had been strung up in a cargo net made from thick rope, which had been hung from a forklift truck. Another showed a soldier, wearing just shorts and flip flops, standing on an Iraqi man who was crouched in a foetal position on the ground. The lawyer for one of the soldiers, Lance Corporal George Solomou, told the court that superiors had called for a crackdown on looters at the time. "I am a conscientious objector to this war, and I am going to see how the army plays it from there," he said. "I would rather spend a year in prison than a minute in Iraq as part of an illegal war."

– The US military plans to send 18 armed robots to Iraq in an effort to fight the war on terror, the Guardian reports. The robots, called Swords, or Special Weapons Observation Reconnaissance Detection Systems, look a lot like the robots used in Northern Ireland and Iraq, where they have been successful at defusing roadside bombs. But they're not like the blooded androids of "I, Robot," writes Rory McCarthy. Instead, they look more like the sort of contraption dreamt up for the program Robot Wars. The Swords are essentially modified bomb disposal robots of the sort commonly deployed in Northern Ireland and Iraq, where they have been successfully used to defuse roadside bombs. Since the war, life has badly deteriorated for women in Iraq and girls are being forced to wear the veil again.

– A military helicopter crashed in the western Iraqi desert today, killing all 30 US Marines on board, the military said. It was the largest loss of life among US forces in a single incident since the beginning of the Iraq war, the Guardian reports. The CH-53 Sea Stallion helicopter was conducting security operations near Rutba, 220 miles west of Baghdad, when it went down, the military said in a statement.

– The first British soldier to die in the Iraq war has been identified as Sgt. Steve Roberts, a 33-year-old father of two who was shot dead by insurgents while trying to calm a protest in 2003. His body was found in a pool of his own blood two years later, reports the Telegraph. His widow, Samantha, says he was shot in the chest and stomach as he tried to calm the crowd. "I don't know if I was really coping with my grief or not," she tells the Daily Mail. "But at the time, I don't believe you even think about whether you are coping or not." He was the first British soldier to die in the Iraq war and the first to die in combat since March 2003.

– Al-Jazeera has been forced to apologize for airing a video that purports to show the downing of an RAF Hercules in Iraq, which killed 10 people. The Qatar-based network has been a constant feature of news reports in the last two years as a result of its coverage of the Iraq war and its aftermath, when terrorist network al-Qaeda became the focus of American ire. One of its reporters was arrested in Spain and it has been kicked out of Baghdad by the Iraqi interim government on the grounds that it was a destablizing influence. The network faced controversy again today when it was forced to defend its use of a video that purports to show the shooting down of an RAF Hercules in Iraq, which killed 10 people. Click here for more.

– Gunmen in Baghdad have kidnapped an Italian journalist as she interviewed local people on the street, reports the ANSA news agency. Giuliana Sgrena, who works for the Rome-based Il Manifesto paper, was seized by four gunmen as she was driving near Baghdad University. Two Iraqi journalists with her were released after the gunmen stopped their car, according to the Italian news agency. Sgrena, who has been working in Iraq since Jan. 23, had called in to the paper just two hours before she was taken, according to the paper.

– CNN's top news executive has resigned in the wake of controversy over comments he made about journalists killed in Iraq. "I have devoted my professional life to helping make CNN the most trusted and respected news outlet in the world, and I would never do anything to compromise my work or that of the thousands of talented people it is my honor to work alongside," Eason Jordan, who had been with the network for 23 years, said in a memo to staff. Jordan, who accused the US of deliberately targeting journalists, said his remarks were taken out of context, the AP reports. More than 50 journalists and media workers have been killed in Iraq in the last two years.

– The Guardian has obtained 1,000 pages of documents that show the US military covered up widespread abuse of detainees in Iraq and Afghanistan—even after the Abu Ghraib scandal. The documents show that photos taken of US soldiers posing in mock executions at Abu Ghraib were destroyed after the scandal to avoid "another public outrage," and that US forces in Afghanistan carried out rape and sexual humiliation at Bagram and Kandahar detention centers. Several victims of rape and sexual abuse were given the drug MDMA, the active ingredient in ecstasy, as part of an experiment to see if it could help treat post-traumatic stress disorder. "It's looking very promising," says the psychiatrist leading the trial.

– America and NATO are about to have a new member: Ukraine. President Viktor Yushchenko announced today at a NATO summit that his country wants to join the alliance, reports the Guardian. The move is likely to please Russia, which fears that Ukraine will try to take over Russia's sphere of influence. In a speech billed as a conciliatory gesture to EU leaders after the divisions of the Iraq war, George Bush called for Europe and the US to work together to "take up the duties of great democracies."

– Britain's attorney general has concluded that the US-led invasion of Iraq was illegal because it did not violate international law, the Guardian reports. The conclusion is based on 13 pages of legal opinion drawn up by Lord Goldsmith and delivered to Tony Blair's government last week. Goldsmith concluded that the invasion was not backed by "due process" or "due process of law," according to the Telegraph. He also concluded that the US did not violate Iraqi law when it detained and tortured detainees. The attorney general's full report is expected to be released in a matter of days.

– The US soldier who shot Italian journalist Giuliana Sgrena has been identified as Staff Sgt. Jeremiah Wright, according to Italian media. Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi called for an investigation into the shooting, which left Sgrena with a gunshot wound to the head, the Telegraph reports. Sgrena, who was rescued by a fellow journalist after being kidnapped in Iraq on Friday, was returned to Italy yesterday. "I saw the person who had saved me die in my arms," she said. "The hardest moment was when I saw the person who had saved me die in my arms."

– The US has agreed to hand over control of several of its detention facilities in Iraq to Iraqi authorities, including Abu Ghraib, the Guardian reports. Iraq's human rights minister says the US has also agreed to hand over control of two other facilities in the center of Iraq and a British-run prison in the south. Iraq's human rights minister, Bakhtiar Amin, yesterday told the Guardian that the US had agreed to the pullout at the four main detention facilities, including Abu Ghraib, the prison at the center of the abuse and torture scandal. Two other locations in the center of Iraq and a British—run prison in the south will also be handed over to Iraqi control, although no deadline has been set. He said he had requested the transfer of authority of the country's prisons from Major General William Brandenburg, the US commander of detention facilities in Iraq.

– Democrats on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee have sent a letter to President Bush accusing the Pentagon of holding back a critical report on contractor Halliburton’s overcharges in Iraq, reports the Wall Street Journal. The lawmakers, led by California’s Henry Waxman and Michigan’s John Dingell, note that 12 requests to the Pentagon to see the report were ignored. They also accuse the Defense Contract Audit Agency of sitting on the report until before this year’s election.

– A 25-year-old British soldier has become the first living recipient of the nation's highest military honor since the Vietnam War. Private Johnson Beharry, who fought in some of the fiercest battles in southern and eastern Iraq, has been awarded the Victoria Cross, the Guardian reports. He is the first British soldier to receive the award since the 1982 Falklands War and the first living recipient since 1969, when two Australians were given the award for action in Vietnam. Beharry "gave his life while under fire in some of the fiercest and largely unreported battles in southern and eastern Iraq," Prime Minister David Cameron said. "I am extremely proud of him."

– The Conservative Party has selected a former RAF group captain who served in Iraq to fight Tony Blair in his Sedgefield constituency in next year's general election. Group Captain Al Lockwood—who appeared on TV screens as a military spokesman during the conflict—will face Tony Blair in his north-east constituency, the Telegraph reports. Lockwood's opponent is Reg Keys, the father of a soldier killed in Iraq. Keys says he's "always been a great fan of Muhammad Ali and his philosophy." "Whenever he got into the ring with Sonny Liston or George Foreman, nobody gave him a chance," Keys says. "But he always believed that he could win. And, when it really mattered, he did.''

– The US military's top general in Iraq authorized the use of 29 interrogation techniques, including sleep manipulation, stress positions, and the use of dogs to "exploit Arab fears," according to newly released documents. The techniques violated international law, the Geneva conventions, and the army's own field manual, an ACLU lawyer tells the Guardian. The documents were released under a Freedom of Information Act request. The techniques were approved by Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez in a memo dated September 14, 2003. They were modeled on the techniques used at Guantanamo Bay, but modified for use in a war in which the Geneva conventions apply, the memo states.

– Paul Wolfowitz's appointment as president of the World Bank has set off a wave of controversy because of his close ties to the Bush administration. Critics say Wolfowitz, who served as deputy defense secretary, is too close to the White House and should have recused himself from running the bank because of his close ties to George W. Bush, reports the Guardian. The New York Times, meanwhile, calls his appointment a "tragedy" because of his close ties to Bush and his support for the Iraq war.

– Iraq's parliament elected Jalal Talabani as the country's new president today, ending a deadlock that had held up the formation of a new government for more than nine weeks. Talabani, a Kurd who fought for independence from Saddam Hussein, is the first Kurdish president in Iraq's post-Saddam Hussein history. He replaces Nouri al-Maliki, who became Iraq's prime minister last month after his party won the most seats in elections. The election of Talabani ends a political deadlock that had held up Iraq's new leadership. More than nine weeks after the January 30 elections, the Iraqi parliament voted in Talabani—a veteran of the Kurds' Saddam— era struggles for independence and paved the way for a new government in Baghdad, the Guardian reports.

– It's been more than two years since US troops left Iraq, and Baghdad is still looking a lot like it did when they left. The city is still littered with concrete blast barriers, sandbags, and razor wire, the New York Times reports, but locals are hoping to change that with some color. Baghdad has been dubbed the "World's Most Beautiful Capital," but the Times notes that the word "beautiful" is a bit of a misnomer: The capital is actually "part ruin, part building site," and has suffered from blackouts and violence since the US invasion.

– The number of British soldiers deserting the army or going absent without leave has more than doubled since the US-led invasion of Iraq, according to the Ministry of Defense. There are now more than 500 soldiers whose whereabouts are unknown, the Independent reports. Independent sources said yesterday that the war was clearly a factor. The number of soldiers to desert the army or go absent without leave has more than doubled over the past year, the Ministry of Defense has revealed. There are now more than 500 soldiers whose whereabouts are unknown. The rise coincided with the invasion of Iraq and its aftermath.

– Britain is marking the 60th anniversary of the end of World War II today, and the New York Times takes a look at what today's teens know about the conflict—and whether they're ignorant about it. The Times interviewed six teens in London about the war, and found that most didn't know much about it. One 17-year-old said he didn't know much about it because his family didn't know about it. Another said he didn't know much about it because his family didn't know about it. Still another said he didn't know much about it because his family didn't know about it. The teens ranged in age from 14 to 16, and all said they were "proud" to be British.

– The BBC's Frank Gardner survived a 10-month ordeal in which he was kidnapped, tortured, and killed in Saudi Arabia while reporting on the Arab Spring. In an interview with the Guardian, he recounts the day he and his cameraman, Faiz Al Salaam, were seized by masked gunmen while sitting in a cafe in the holy city of Jiddah. They were able to call for help, but were then taken to a hospital, where they were tortured and killed. "I've been through hell and back," he says. "There's no point in hiding. There's no point in being afraid. There's no point in being angry. There's no point in being angry about something you've done. It's all in a day's work. It's what you do in the day's work that counts."

– A British lawmaker is so fed up with Tony Blair that he's urging voters to give the prime minister a "bloody nose" in next week's general election. Brian Sedgemore, a member of parliament for 27 years with the Labor Party, says he's defected to the Liberal Democrats because Blair "is an appeaser of a dangerous global power" and "should be in prison, not standing for election." Blair "is a supremely confident and arrogant politician, an excellent speaker, and a deeply religious man with a hotline to God," Sedgemore writes in the Guardian. "He had an unassailable majority in parliament and was popular in the country and presided over a cabinet stuffed with nonentities. Specifically, it's not happening any more. The prime minister is a war criminal Like Chamberlain in the 30s, Blair is an appeaser of a dangerous global power. He should be in prison, not standing for election."

– The US military is considering allowing women to join up for combat missions in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Guardian reports. The move would end a ban on women in combat that has been in place since World War II, but it would still require the approval of the Pentagon's Joint Chiefs of Staff. “It’s something we’re considering,” says one military official. “We’re not ruling it out, but we’re not ruling it in.”

– British soldier Dave Corrigan was proud to be a British soldier serving in Iraq. Then he was wounded and his nightmare began. He tells Ed Vulliamy why, as the only war casualty in Tony Blair's constituency, he'll be voting against the PM—and why his old comrades should all be brought home. Corrigan was called up to go to Iraq in March 2003 at five days' notice. He tells Vulliamy why, as the only war casualty in Tony Blair's constituency, he'll be voting against the PM—and why his old comrades should all be brought home

– America's most decorated Vietnam vet, Colonel David Hackworth, has died of cancer at the age of 73. Hackworth, who served as commander of the air cavalry brigade in Vietnam and became the model for Colonel Kilgore in Apocalypse Now, appeared on ABC television in 1971 and told his countrymen that the war could not be won, that US military leaders had failed to understand or train their men for the nature of the country or the conflict, that would fall to the communists within five years and that one of every five American casualties had been the victim of so—called friendly fire. This criticism put Hackworth, who has died of cancer, under concerted attack from his superiors, an assault made easier to sustain by the fast and loose approach to regulations he had employed as commander of the Saigon air cavalry brigade in Vietnam. His troops wore US civil war hats, and Hackworth, later became the model for Colonel Kilgore, a cigar-chomping officer played by Robert Duvall in the 1979 film Apocalypse Now. Space Hulk originated as a board game but was turned into a PC title in the early nineties, and according to the press release, THQ Wireless interactive implementation of the brand will remain true to the existing rules and gameplay systems, whilst also addressing the needs

– The head of Britain's MI6 has been accused of trying to seduce the body tasked with finding Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. Dr. Rod Barton, a former senior weapons inspector in Iraq, tells the Guardian that MI6 chief Sir John Scarlett and a top Ministry of Defense official tried to get the Iraq Survey Group to drop a report that would have been politically damaging to London. Barton, who was a special adviser to the ISG in 2004, says he received a visit from Martin Howard, deputy chief of defense intelligence at the MoD, in Baghdad in January. The report would have shown that the ISG had found no WMD or programs to build them, Barton says. Scarlett and the official pressured the ISG not to include the report in its final report, he says. Barton, who has worked for Australian intelligence for more than 20 years, says the report would have been politically damaging in London in the aftermath of the David Kelly affair.

– British anti-war MP George Galloway stormed out of a Senate hearing yesterday, accusing US senators of making "the mother of all smokescreens" in their investigation of his alleged involvement in Iraqi oil sales, the Guardian reports. "They are the mother of all smokescreens," said Galloway, who stormed out of the hearing after Republican Sen. Norm Coleman accused him of profiting illegally from Iraqi oil sales under the UN's Oil for Food program. Coleman, who has led the charge against Galloway, said the hearing was not a court of law, but Galloway's "indefatigability" prevented him from backing down, the Daily Record reports.

– The lawyer for Saddam Hussein is calling leaked photos of the Iraqi dictator's underpants a "flagrant violation of the Geneva conventions concerning prisoners of war" and a "clear and blatant violation of all moral and human rights principals." The White House has ordered an aggressive investigation into how the photos ended up in the hands of a British tabloid, the Guardian reports. Saddam's lawyer, Kalil al-Duleimi, said that if the photos are authentic, "then they represent a clear and blatant violation of all moral and human rights principals. They are a flagrant violation of the Geneva conventions concerning prisoners of war and my client is a war prisoner."

– Back in 2005, Republican Rep. Walter Jones spearheaded a campaign to change the name of french fries to "freedom fries," arguing that it was offensive to serve them in the House cafeterias as "freedom toast." Now, he's speaking out against the war in Iraq, the Telegraph reports. Jones, who represents a district in North Carolina, told a local newspaper that the US went to war "with no justification" and that the name change was "a light-hearted gesture."

– George W. Bush is a “rogue regime” bent on “terrorizing innocent civilians,” Malaysia’s former prime minister Mahathir Mohamad tells the Guardian. “People who believed might made right—a return to colonial— era—old thinking.” Mahathir, who ruled Malaysia from 1981 to 2003, says he’s disappointed that Tony Blair was re-elected after joining the US invasion of Iraq, and that the US war on terror won’t end until the Middle East conflict is “justly resolved.” Among other things, Mahathir accused the US of giving Israel “a free hand” to continue to expropriate Palestinian land, and of entrenching its control over Jerusalem. Click here for more.

– Rebecca Solnit, author of Occupy Wall Street, has been compared to Naomi Klein and Susan Sontag. "As a writer, she resembles Naomi Klein, though probably more radical, and also Susan Sontag, though somewhat less of anaesthete," writes Stuart Jeffries in the Guardian. Solnit, an anarchist activist, is content with her life, he adds. "Has Californian Rebecca Solnit spent too much time in the sun, or does she really offer a new way of looking at radical politics?"

– Britain's attorney general is expected to announce today that up to 11 soldiers will be charged in connection with the death of an Iraqi civilian, the Guardian reports. The soldiers are suspected in the death of Baha Mousa, a 26-year-old hotel receptionist who was allegedly shot 12 times by British soldiers after he tried to run through a checkpoint in southern Iraq. The British military is investigating Lance Corporal Barry Singleton, 23, in connection with Mousa's death. Singleton allegedly fired his gun 12 times at the driver. Mousa's family says he was shot in the back of the head. A decision on whether to press charges against Singleton could come as soon as today.

– US and Iraqi officials have held their first direct talks with insurgents since the US-led invasion of Iraq two years ago, the Guardian reports. "In order to achieve stability and stop Iraqis from being killed in large numbers, the insurgency has to be addressed," said a US embassy official in Baghdad. "We're trying to do that by engaging the elements of the resistance that are willing to talk." The talks were held in the Green Zone, where US and Iraqi officials are based.

– Iran's presidential election is just days away, and the country's semi-official IRNA news agency is predicting a landslide victory for moderate cleric Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a close ally of supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. But reformist candidate Mostafa Moin, a former education minister, appears to have made a late surge, reports the New York Times. Mostafa Moin, 54, is a former education minister who, like Hashemi Rafsanjani, is seen as a moderate by Iran's conservative establishment. But he has also been accused by the country's hard-liners of being a traitor to the supreme leader. Mostafa Moin's campaign manager, however, says his candidate is the real front-runner.

– The streets of some of Britain's biggest cities are off-limits to DHL delivery drivers because they're at higher risk of being attacked, the Guardian reports. Residents in areas including London, Manchester, Birmingham, and Glasgow have been told they'll have to pick up their packages from a DHL depot because of safety concerns. " Mostly, it has been a case of threatening behavior, or people surrounding the vehicle and making life difficult," said a DHL spokesman. The company has also banned delivery in parts of the US because of threats.

– The war in Iraq is creating a new breed of Islamic jihadists who could go on to destabilise other countries, according to a CIA report. The CIA believes Iraq to be potentially worse than Afghanistan, which produced thousands of jihadists in the 1980s and 1990s. Many of the recruits to Osama bin Laden's al-Qaeda had fought in Afghanistan. The sobering caution came as a senior British anti-terrorism source warned that those trained in terror techniques in Iraq could use their newly-acquired skills in Britain at the end of the war. The CIA report, completed last month, remains classified. Click here for more.

– Dick Cheney recently said the Iraqi insurgency was in its last throes, but defense chief Donald Rumsfeld thinks it could be at least a decade before it dies down, the Guardian reports. “I think it could go on for a decade,” Rumsfeld said yesterday. “ Iraqis are going to bring an end to this violence, but it’s not going to be the United States that’s going to bring an end to it. It’s going to be the Iraqis.” Rumsfeld confirmed that the US military had been in contact with some Iraqi leaders in an attempt to quell the violence, which killed at least 33 people and wounded dozens more in a coordinated suicide bombing attack in Mosul yesterday.

– In his much-anticipated address to the nation last night, George Bush warned that withdrawing from Iraq would leave the US open to more terrorist attacks and urged Americans not to forget the lessons of September 11. The president mentioned the attacks five times in the 30-minute speech at Fort Bragg military base in North Carolina, the Guardian reports. Democratic leaders were quick to accuse Bush of exploiting the "sacred ground" of September 11. "He is exploiting the sacred ground of September 11 for political gain," said Harry Reid. "He is exploiting the memory of September 11 for his political gain."

– Coca-Cola and Pepsi have set up a joint venture in Iraq to compete with each other in the lucrative but potentially hostile cola market, the Telegraph reports. Coke was in Iraq for 37 years before returning last week. The upsides for Coke include a thirst-inducing climate and burgeoning Islamic conservatism which has banned beer and other alcoholic drinks in much of the country. The downsides, besides Pepsi's head start, are a raging insurgency and banditry which threaten supply routes, and a perception that Coca-Cola is linked to Israel and the US Zionists.

– A man has been arrested in connection with last week's bombings in London and other attacks in the UK, the Telegraph reports. He's reportedly a member of the IRA, which was behind a series of bombings in the late '80s and early '90s that killed more than 300 people in Northern Ireland. The man's name hasn't been released, and police haven't said whether he's a British or Irish citizen. The bombings in London killed at least 31 people and injured hundreds more.

– Karl Rove has told a grand jury that he discussed with journalists the identity of an outed CIA operative whose public identification has caused a political storm, reports the AP and the New York Times. Rove told the grand jury that syndicated newspaper columnist Robert Novak had telephoned him and told him the operative's name. Both AP and the New York Times quoted a person briefed on Mr Rove. (Read the full story here.) Rove told the grand jury that he discussed with journalists the identity of an outed CIA operative whose public identification has caused a political storm, reports US media. (Read the full story here.) Rove told the grand jury that syndicated newspaper columnist Robert Novak had telephoned him and told him the operative's name. Both AP and the New York Times quoted a person briefed on Mr Rove. (Read the full story here.)

– Britain's involvement in the US-led wars in Iraq and Afghanistan has given a boost to al-Qaeda and contributed to the 2005 terrorist attacks in London, a leading foreign policy think tank has concluded. The country is "riding as a pillion passenger with the United States in the war against terror," the Chatham House organization says in a report. The security services, diverted by fighting the IRA over Northern Ireland and the rise of animal activists committing terrorist acts, failed to give priority in the early 1990s to monitoring Islamist terror activists setting up in Britain, so the British authorities did not fully appreciate the threat from al-Qaeda, the report says. Two-thirds of Britons believe the invasion of Iraq has given a boost to al-Qaeda in propaganda, recruitment, and fundraising, while providing an ideal targeting and training area for terrorists, according to a Guardian/ICM poll.

– Three British soldiers have been charged with war crimes following the capture of Abu Ghraib. The soldiers are the first British troops to be prosecuted under the International Criminal Court's jurisdiction. The charges stem from the September 2003 capture of Abu Ghraib, in which British troops allegedly tortured scores of detainees. Eleven soldiers are also facing charges in two separate incidents in Basra, the Guardian reports. The British military has been under fire since the capture of Abu Ghraib, with ex-soldiers calling for soldiers to refuse to serve in Iraq unless the charges are dropped. "It's going to put all the other lads in a horrible position," a former soldier tells the Guardian. "Everyone is going to be scared to do anything."

– Jane Fonda is planning a bus tour across America to call for an end to US military operations in Iraq, the Telegraph reports. The actress, who earned the nickname "Hanoi Jane" after she was photographed sitting on an anti-aircraft gun during the Vietnam War, says she will be joined by families of Iraq war veterans and her daughter on the tour. "I've decided I'm coming out," she told an audience in New Mexico.

– The family of Jean Charles de Menezes, the Brazilian man shot dead by police in London last week, says he was not wearing a heavy jacket that might have concealed a bomb. He was wearing a jeans jacket, not a bulky jacket, and used a travel card, his cousin told a press conference yesterday. Police say they shot the 27-year-old dead after he was mistaken for a suicide bomber and refused to jump the ticket barrier. "He had no bulky jacket, he was wearing a jeans jacket," Vivien Figueiredo said. "He was unarmed and did not jump the ticket barrier when challenged by armed plainclothes police."

– One of the suspects in last month's failed terror attacks in London says the plot was directly inspired by Britain's involvement in the Iraq war, the Telegraph reports. Hussain Osman, arrested in Rome on Friday, says the men watched hours of TV footage showing the grief of Iraqi widows and children alongside images of civilians killed in the conflict. "There was a feeling of hatred and a conviction that it was necessary to give a signal—to do something," he says. But some of the Italian media reports quoted him as saying: "I hardly know anything."

– Ayman al-Zawahiri, al-Qaeda's No. 2, has blamed the London bombings on Tony Blair's foreign policy and warned that the UK's rejection of an offer of a truce will bring more destruction to the country, the Guardian reports. Blair's " policies will bring more destruction to Britons after the London explosions, God willing," Zawahiri said in a message broadcast on al-Jazeera. " Commanders weigh their options as'Juba' notches up more kills."

– Britain's former foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has died after apparently suffering a heart attack while walking in the Scottish hills. Cook, 59, was airlifted to a hospital in Inverness, where he was pronounced dead last night, the Guardian reports. He was also reported to have seriously injured himself in a fall after his collapse. The father of two was on the mountain for nearly half an hour before rescue services reached him. Cook, who served as Tony Blair's foreign secretary from 1997 to 2003, was "one of the cleverest and most creative figures in modern British politics," writes the Guardian's Martin Argles. "He devoted his entire career to the advancement of the Labor party and the pursuit of radical change within society."

– Iraq's parliament is set to meet today to vote on splitting the country into a Shiite-dominated region and a Sunni-dominated one, reports the BBC. The Shiites want an autonomous region for their sect, while the Sunnis want a greater say in running the country. Today's vote will be the first on splitting the country since the US-led invasion in 2003. Click here for more on the vote.

– Maharishi Mahesh Yogi’s teachings on levitation and meditation have been popping up all over the world for decades, but the Beatle’s first guru has decided it’s time for his followers to go their separate ways. The 95-year-old has ordered his followers, who number in the thousands, to cease his advanced classes in Britain, the Telegraph reports. “It is with a heavy heart that I have to announce that I am ending my teaching of levitation and meditation in Britain,” he wrote in a letter to his followers. “It is with a heavy heart that I have to say that I am ending my teaching of levitation and meditation in Britain.”

– It's been more than four years since the US-led invasion of Iraq, and since then, the country has been wracked by violence. Here's a look at some of the stories making headlines this week: The New York Times takes a look at the "quiet revolution" that's been taking place in Iraq since the US invasion. It's a peaceful, low-level insurgency that's largely been driven by Sunnis who feel betrayed by the Shiite-dominated government of Nouri al-Maliki. It's a far cry from the Sunni-dominated insurgency of recent years, but it's a far cry from the insurgency that drove Iraq to the brink of civil war in 2003—and it's a far cry from the insurgency that helped bring about the US-led invasion in the first place. The Guardian takes a look at the "quiet revolution" that's been taking place in Iraq since the US invasion. It's a peaceful, low-level insurgency that's largely been driven by Sunnis who feel betrayed by the Shiite-dominated government of Nouri al-Maliki.
