– Pat Robertson's call for the assassination of Venezuelan President Hugo Chvez isn't going over well in the US. But Richard Gott, writing for the Daily Beast, says Chvez "will laugh off" Robertson's suggestion, "but he will also seize on it to ratchet up the verbal conflict with the United States that has lasted throughout his presidency." Click here for Gott's full column.

– Britain's top official warned his Cabinet colleagues that the Iraq war was "fueling Muslim extremism" in the country a year before the July 7 bombings, according to a leaked letter obtained by the Observer. The letter says British foreign policy was a " recurring theme" in the Muslim community, especially in regard to the Middle East peace process and Iraq, andleagues have "flagged up some of the potential underlying causes of extremism that can affect the Muslim community, such as discrimination, disadvantage, and exclusion."

– British MP George Galloway and American writer Christopher Hitchens will go head-to-head in a boxing ring in New York City next month, in what promises to be a lively debate about US and British foreign policy. The bout, which is being billed as a "Grapple in the Big Apple," is being billed as a showdown between two of the most prominent anti-war voices in British politics, the Telegraph reports. Hitchens, author of the controversial Vanity Fair piece on George W. Bush, has long been a thorn in the side of the British government. Galloway, a member of Parliament, has been a vocal critic of the US war in Iraq.

– As New Orleans begins to dig out from the devastation of Hurricane Katrina, the Guardian takes a look at the long-term implications of the storm for the city and the rest of the Gulf of Mexico. New Orleans' levees and flood barriers have been altered over the past 100 years as a result of man-made engineering in the Mississippi delta, according to the American Society of Civil Engineers. Human activity has caused 1,500 square miles of natural coastal barriers to be eroded in the past 50 years. New Orleans and surrounding areas will now experience the full force of hurricanes, including storm surges that top levee systems and cause severe flooding as well as high winds. Click here for more.

– Kofi Annan has apologized for the UN's involvement in Iraq's oil-for-food program, which has come under fire in the wake of Hurricane Katrina. "I wish we were never given that program, and I wish the UN would never be asked to take that kind of a program again," Annan told the BBC. The UN set up the program in 1996 to ease the impact of sanctions on Iraq, and it's expected to be heavily criticized in an investigation due tomorrow. The UN was asked to run it by the Security Council. "I wish we were never given that program, and I wish the UN would never be asked to take that kind of a program again," Annan said. "Honestly I wish we were never given that program, and I wish the UN would never be asked to take that kind of a program again."

– Christopher Hitchens and George Galloway squared off last night in a spirited debate on Iraq, and the fireworks started early. Hitchens called Galloway a "disgrace" and a "sludge" for his anti-war stance, while Galloway accused Hitchens of being "part of a left-wing conspiracy to destroy the Middle East," reports the Guardian. (Click here for more on the debate, or here for more on Hitchens' new comic book, Liberality for All, which imagines an alternate future in which Al Gore won the 2000 US election and liberals went on to create a world where the UN "has appeased Islamist fundamentalists and invited Osama bin Laden to give the memorial address on the 20th anniversary of the September 11 attacks.") A sampling of their back-and-forth: Hitchens: "George Galloway, the British MP and anti-war campaigner, was labeled a 'disgrace' last night by pro-war journalist Christopher Hitchens, who was himself branded by Mr. Galloway as a'sludge' leaving a trail of slime." Galloway: "Christopher Hitchens, the British Vanity Fair columnist who has strayed from his left-wing roots, began by imagining what would have happened had the policies of the 'anti-war movement' been followed over

– Tony Blair has blasted the BBC's coverage of Hurricane Katrina as "full of hatred of America" and "gloating" at the country's plight, reports the Financial Times. Blair reportedly made the remarks to Rupert Murdoch, chairman and chief executive of News Corporation, which owns the rival Sky News. The comments threatened a new rift between the government and the BBC following the Andrew Gilligan affair over events leading to the Iraq war and recent criticisms of ministers Today presenter John Humphrys, which were controversially leaked to the press. The BBC said that its coverage had been "committed solely to relaying the events fully, accurately, and impartially."

– The search is on for a group of dolphins that the US military has been training in the Gulf of Mexico for years. Experts say the dolphins could be carrying toxic darts that could be dangerous to divers and surfers, the Guardian reports. The Navy hasn't confirmed the report, but the agency running the training says it has found no evidence the dolphins have been killed. The dolphins have been in the Gulf for years as part of the Navy's Cold War training program, but the military has never confirmed that they are being used for military purposes.

– British PM Gordon Brown will deliver his first State of the Union address as prime minister tomorrow night, in what will be his first such speech since taking over from Tony Blair in 10 years, reports the Telegraph. Brown is expected to use the occasion to criticize the Bush administration's handling of the Iraq war, as well as to announce plans to extend the life of the Iraq war by another three years. Brown is also expected to announce plans to extend the life of the Iraq war by another three years.

– The CIA planned to use a UN weapons inspection to remove Saddam Hussein from power, but the plan went horribly wrong, according to a new book. The book, by former CIA officer Scott Ritter, details the CIA's attempts to use the weapons- inspection program to overthrow the Iraqi regime, the Telegraph reports. Ritter, who was the US marine captain in charge of the program, says the CIA was given the go-ahead to use the program by Israel's military intelligence, which was already helping the UN's weapons- inspection program. But the program was never carried out, and US forces were never informed of the CIA's plans. "This is big, Scott," says an Israeli intelligence official. "We do n' share this with anyone."

– A small amount of rabbit fever was detected on Washington DC's National Mall during recent Iraq war protests. The non- contagious disease, which causes sudden fever, chills, muscle aches, and pneumonia, is easily treated with antibiotics. Local health department officials said further sampling had proved negative and said they thought the bacteria had not been intentionally released. The Center for Disease Control and Prevention said an environmental air monitor on September 24 detected the non- contagious disease, which causes sudden fever, chills, muscle aches, and pneumonia—like symptoms but which is easily treated with antibiotics. Local health department officials said further sampling had proved negative and said they thought the bacteria had not been intentionally released. A small amount of the disease agent Francisella tularensis, or rabbit fever, was detected on Washington DC's national mall during recent Iraq war protests. – Psychiatrist M Scott Peck, who made millions with his first book, The Road Less Travelled, has died at the age of 69. The best-selling book advocated self-discipline, restraint, and responsibility and was translated into more than 20 languages, the Guardian reports. "Life is difficult," opened The Road Less Travelled, Peck's first book. "This was a pronouncement to which Peck could personally attest." After 13 years on the New York Times bestseller list, The Road Less Travelled sold 10 million copies worldwide and was translated into more than 20 languages.

– A French court has ordered the release of a man arrested in connection with a terror plot to blow up the Paris subway, the Guardian reports. The man's lawyer says he had no connection to the subway plot or to the Charlie Hebdo terrorist attack in Paris. The court also ordered the release of a man arrested last month in connection with an alleged terror plot to blow up the Charlie Hebdo newspaper in Paris. The man's lawyer says he had no connection to the subway plot or to the terrorist attack. The court also ordered the release of a man arrested last month in connection with an alleged terror plot to blow up the Charlie Hebdo newspaper in Paris. The man's lawyer says he had no connection to the subway plot or to the terrorist attack. The court also ordered the release of a man arrested last month in connection with an alleged terror plot to blow up the Charlie Hebdo newspaper in Paris. The man's lawyer says he had no connection to the terrorist attack.

– "I was a woman in a warrior's world." That's how Janis Karpinski describes her life as a reserve general in Iraq before the Abu Ghraib abuse scandal erupted, in a new memoir. "I would collapse on my bunk, pass out from the heat for a few hours, then drag myself out for a pre-dawn run, while it was still only 27C-32C," she writes. "Army leaders did not seem to want me to run, but I ran anyway." Karpinski, who became commander of Abu Ghraib when the scandal broke, says she was made the scapegoat because she was a woman. "The senior warriors seeing this reserve general, a woman, running at 4.30am decided to do something—or maybe it was just a coincidence that they kept changing the rules," she writes. Karpinski's memoir, The Renegade General, is out this week.

– Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe today compared George Bush and Tony Blair to Mussolini and Hitler, calling the two "international terrorists" in a speech at the UN to mark the 60th anniversary of the Food and Agriculture Organization. "In the same way as Hitler and Mussolini formed an alliance to attack an innocent country, the two unholy men of our millennium who, in the same way as Hitler and Mussolini formed—LRB—an—RRB- unholy alliance, formed an alliance to attack an innocent country," he said, according to the Guardian. Britain's representative at the FAO said Mugabe's presence at the conference on food and hunger was a "sick irony."

– A British journalist was kidnapped in Baghdad last night as he conducted an interview with a victim of Saddam Hussein's regime, the Guardian reports. Rory Carroll, 33, was with two drivers and a translator when he was confronted by gunmen as he left the house where he had been carrying out the interview. He and one of the drivers were bundled into cars. Carroll, an experienced foreign correspondent, had been preparing an article for today's paper on the opening of the former dictator's trial.

– The number of US troops who have died in the Iraq war hit 2,000 yesterday, making it the bloodiest conflict in modern US history, reports the Los Angeles Times. The milestone was broken by a suicide by a war widow three months after the death of her husband, a staff sergeant. The military did not release a press release about the death of 23-year-old Elaina Morton of Kansas, but her death is believed to be the first suicide by a war widow. More at the Guardian.

– Relatives of some of the 52 people killed in the July 7 bombings in London are expected to boycott a service of remembrance today at St Paul's Cathedral. The families of some of the victims feel "overwhelmed by anger" at the British government's response to the attacks, sources tell the Telegraph. Others blame Tony Blair's decision to go to war in Iraq for making London more vulnerable to suicide bombings. Sean Cassidy, whose son, Ciaran, was killed in the Russell Square bomb, said he would attend the service today with his wife, Veronica, and daughter, Lisa, because he hoped to be able to speak to Blair to express his anger.

– Scooter Libby has made his first court appearance since being indicted on charges he lied and obstructed justice in the CIA leak case. The former top aide to Dick Cheney pleaded not guilty to five counts, including lying and obstructing justice, reports the Telegraph. Libby is expected to be called to testify against him. The charges stem from his alleged role in leaking the identity of covert CIA operative Valerie Plame. Libby is the first White House official to be indicted while in office since Ulysses Grant's secretary, who was charged 130 years ago with a whisky tax scam.

– Desert Storm, Sam Mendes' latest film about the first Gulf War, has a star-studded cast including Brad Pitt, Viggo Mortensen, and Ben Stiller, and critics say it’s as good or better than any previous war movie. Here’s what they’re saying: The movie is “as slick and meretricious here in Desert Storm as he was in the suburbs of American Beauty and among the reach—me—down neo— noir cliches of Road to Perdition, but I congratulate him for taking on his big—budget predecessors like a new fish in the jailhouse preemptively stomping the wing daddies,” writes Manohla Dargis in the New York Times. Mendes “is as slick and meretricious here in Desert Storm as he was in the suburbs of American Beauty and among the reach—me—down neo— noir cliches of Road to Perdition, but I congratulate him for taking on his big—budget predecessors like a new fish in the jailhouse preemptively stomping the wing daddies,” writes Joe Morgenstern in the Wall Street Journal. “This is a war movie for the 21st century,” writes Roger Ebert in the Chicago Sun-Times.

– Peter Hitchens has a new book out, and it’s a doozy. It’s called The Great War for Civilization, and it takes a look at “the causes of current chaos in the Middle East,” writes Robert Fisk in the Independent. Among them: “the 1920 occupation of Iraq by British forces,” the roots of the Arab–Israeli conflict, and “the roots of the Arab–Israeli conflict and other events which lead us to the ludicrous present where soldiers from the most sophisticated armies in the world have to be protected by private security firms in Iraq and where the threat of terrorism is a fact of daily life from Bali to London.” For more on Fisk and his book, click here.

– George Bush considered bombing al-Jazeera's headquarters in Qatar at the height of last year's Iraqi insurgency, according to a memo leaked to the Daily Mirror. Al-Jazeera has called on the US and UK governments to provide a "good explanation" for the alleged comments, which it says would be "horrific and bad news not only for al-Jazeera but for every news organization around the world." The British government has threatened newspapers with legal action if they publish the memo's contents, the Guardian reports.

– Dick Cheney could be guilty of a war crime over the abuse of detainees, says the former chief of staff to Colin Powell. Asked on the BBC whether the vice president was guilty of torture, Lawrence Wilkerson said: "That's an interesting question—it was certainly a domestic crime to advocate terror and I would suspect that it is." Wilkerson, who served as Powell's chief of staff from 2002 to 2005, said the debate over whether to abide by Geneva conventions in the treatment of detainees was Cheney's idea. "He led the argument that essentially wanted to do away with all restrictions," Wilkerson said. "It was certainly a domestic crime to advocate terror and I would suspect that it is."

– Israel has been stepping up business ties with Iraq's Kurdish region, according to a report in an Israeli newspaper. Dozens of former members of Israel's elite forces are training Kurdish fighters in anti-terrorism techniques and Israeli companies are building an airport in Irbil, the report said. Iraq and Israel are still officially at war, though since the 1960s Israel and the Iraqi Kurds have had a relationship. A spokesman for the Israeli foreign ministry said his country had no relationship with the new Iraq and it remained at war.

– A suicide bomber in a police academy classroom in Baghdad killed at least 43 people and wounded 73 today, in an attack claimed by al-Qaeda in Iraq. The bomber and his brother targeted the police academy, which trains dogs that feed off the blood and honor of Sunni Muslims, according to an Internet statement purported to be from al-Qaeda in Iraq. "The strength of the explosion destroyed a large part of the building," the statement said. The group, thought to be led by Jordanian militant Abu Musab al- Zarqawi, has been linked to last month's Amman hotel bombings and believed to be behind the kidnap and murder of Briton Ken Bigley.

– Cindy Sheehan, the anti-war activist who set up camp outside George Bush's Texas ranch in protest of the Iraq war and whose son died in that war, has died at age 61, reports the AP. Her son, Casey, was a US Army soldier who joined the army in May 2000 and was killed in Iraq four years later. "I feel I am carrying the world on my shoulders," Sheehan tells the BBC.

– President Bush made what the Guardian calls his "most wholehearted acknowledgment to date of the scale of the errors underlying his administration's allegations over Saddam Hussein's alleged weapons of mass destruction" in his final war speech yesterday. "It is true that much of the intelligence turned out to be wrong," he said, but "as president, I am responsible for the decision to go into Iraq." He said that other intelligence agencies had made similar mistakes, and that Democratic politicians had voted for war based on the same intelligence the president had seen. The speech was the fourth and last in a series aimed at bolstering flagging support for the Iraqi conflict, the paper notes.

– The US has been in Iraq for more than four years now, and it's not hard to find a good war film about it, writes James Meek in the Guardian. The genre has long been "a genre whose explosions keep going off in newspaper columns and political discourse long after the closing credits have rolled," he writes. The Deer Hunter by Michael Cimino in 1979 "marked a shift of key for the Hollywood war film," he writes. John Wayne's last public appearance before his death was the John Wayne movie Apocalypse Now, and it was Francis Ford Coppola's own Vietnam movie that "was destined for a cooler critical reception when it limped into the cinemas a few months later." The Iraq war, however, "has had at least one redeeming feature," writes Meek. "Along with events in Afghanistan, it has revived serious debate into some of the most important and long—standing issues in history and politics." Click for his full column.

– America’s troops in Iraq are getting treated to some unusual entertainment this Christmas: Christian hip-hop groups, a country singer, and two cheerleaders for the Dallas Cowboys. The United Services Organization has been putting on shows for the troops since the second world war, but it’s struggled to get celebrities to sign up for even a short tour of duty, the Telegraph reports. Even in Vietnam, Bob Hope was guaranteed to put on an appearance. But soldiers in Iraq are more likely to get a show from a Christian hip-hop group, a country singer you have probably never heard of, and two cheerleaders for the Dallas Cowboys. Just as the seemingly intractable nature of the war has led to a growing recruitment crisis, so the United Services Organization, which has been putting on shows for the troops since the second world war, is struggling to get celebrities to sign up for even a short tour of duty.

– Halliburton's cozy relationship with the White House is back in the news, and this time it's a British one, not an American one, reports the Telegraph. Halliburton has won contracts in Iraq to put out oil fires without competing with other companies, a relationship that has rankled British engineers and oil industry operators. Now the company is in talks to build Britain's new aircraft carriers, a deal that has "never been less loved" because of Halliburton's ties to the White House, complains an editorial in the Daily Mail. "The tragic irony of the 21st century is that just as faith in technology collapsed on the world's stock markets in 2000, it came to power in the White House and Pentagon," writes the editorial. "For the Project for a New American Century's ambition of 'full - spectrum dominance'—in which its country could 'fight and win multiple, simultaneous major—theater wars'—was a monster borne up by the high tide of techno euphoria of the 1990s Ex— hippies talked of a wired age of Aquarius."

– The former head of the UN food program in Iraq and a senior UN official have been suspended with pay following an independent investigation that accuses them of misconduct. Benon Sevan, who ran the food program from 1996 to 2003, and Joseph Stephanides, who dealt with contracts for the program, were informed of their suspension with pay on Friday, a UN spokesman tells the AP. They will receive a letter this week laying out the charges against them, which will allow them to defend themselves before UN disciplinary bodies in what will likely be a lengthy appeals process. Sevan and Stephanides were told they would receive a letter this week laying out the charges against them, which will allow them to defend themselves before UN disciplinary bodies in what will likely be a lengthy appeals process.

– With the unrest rocking the Middle East and North Africa, Moammar Gadhafi’s son today told Libyans on state TV that his father will remain in power “at any price,” and that the nation’s army has been ordered to restore security “at any price,” CNN reports. “I ask you to remain peaceful,” Saif al-Islam Gadhafi said in the televised address. “I ask you to remain peaceful and not to use force.” Saif al-Islam Gadhafi said his father’s security forces had “opened fire” on protesters, according to al-Jazeera. At least 20 were killed today in Benghazi, Libya’s second-largest city, according to a medical source. Hundreds were injured in clashes yesterday.

– Mikhail Gorbachev lashed out at Moammar Gadhafi today, saying that the Libyan leader "is using the military... against defenseless people," reports CNN. The former Soviet leader, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, called on Europe, the US, and the rest of the world to "respond to this situation very responsibly." Gadhafi's son, meanwhile, warned of a civil war if protests continue. "Tomorrow, we can speak rationally, we can spare the blood, we can stand all together for the sake of Libya," Saif al-Islam Gadhafi said in a speech on state TV. He also proposed "radical" reforms, including relaxing laws, raising salaries, extending loans, and drafting a constitution.

– Al-Qaeda's North African wing has declared its support for the Libyan uprising, saying Moammar Gadhafi's use of mercenaries against protesters invalidates claims that the group is killing innocent civilians, CNN reports. The statement by al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb was posted on jihadist websites yesterday. In the statement, the group said Libyan leader Gadhafi's decision to hire mercenaries and use planes to fire on protesters invalidates claims that the group is killing innocent civilians. Mike Huckabee called the situation in Libya a "virtual genocide," but said he was "still hopeful" that Gadhafi's army would take out the leader. "There's clearly a man who has virtually escaped the asylum who is in a position of extraordinary power," he said. "The United States is not going to stand by and watch a country slaughter its own people in cold blood."

– Moammar Gadhafi is blaming al-Qaeda for the current unrest in Libya, he tells ABC and the BBC in a joint interview with President Obama. "They love me, all my people with me," he says of Libyans. "No demonstration at all in the streets." Gadhafi also denied killing protesters, saying, "My people will die for me." Gadhafi is "delusional," a US official tells CNN. "Depending upon the method of delivery and what we decide to do we could decide to have a war in Libya to join the war in Afghanistan and Iraq."

– President Obama said today that the US is considering a “full range of options” in Libya, including a no-fly zone, and he specifically cited Moammar Gadhafi by name for the first time. “Moammar Gadhafi has lost legitimacy to lead, and he must leave,” Obama said at a news conference with Mexican President Felipe Calderon. “The aspirations of the Libyan people for freedom, democracy and dignity must be met.” Obama also authorized the use of US military and civilian aircraft to help return to Egypt those Egyptian citizens who have fled to Tunisia to escape the unrest in Libya, CNN reports.

– Opposition forces claimed a major victory today in Libya, managing to block an onslaught by Moammar Gadhafi’s troops and maintain control of the key city of Misrata, an eyewitness tells CNN. Using machine guns, sticks, and anything else they could find, crowds protected the courthouse, serving as an operations center by the opposition in Misrata, and successfully repelled Gadhafi militias armed with tanks and heavy artillery. At least 42 were killed in Misrata yesterday, a doctor says; the UN says aid has been blocked. Meanwhile, the US average price for self-serve unleaded gasoline is 3.51 cents, the second-biggest two-week jump in the history of the gasoline market, according to a new survey of filling stations. The latest Lundberg Survey of cities in the continental US was conducted Friday. It showed the national average for a price of self-serve unleaded gasoline at $ 3.51—an increase of 32.7 cents from the last survey two weeks earlier, survey publisher Trilby Lundberg said. The jump was the biggest since a 38 cents hike between August and September 2005. – The UN Security Council is holding an emergency meeting on Libya today, amid reports that Moammar Gadhafi’s forces are killing unarmed civilians and raping women and girls. British Foreign Secretary William Hague said there are “credible reports” of helicopter gunships being used against civilians, and he called for a no-fly zone to be put in place, CNN reports. The meeting comes as Gadhafi’s forces continue their assault on the rebel-held oil port of Ras Lanuf. Rebels fired antiaircraft guns when Gadhafi’s air force carried out fresh raids there. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees says armed Libyans are going door to door, forcing people from sub-Saharan countries to leave the country. A group of Sudanese who arrived in Egypt from eastern Libya told representatives of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees that armed Libyans were going to door to door, forcing people from sub-Saharan countries to leave. They also reported the rape of a 12-year-old Sudanese girl and said many of their documents had been confiscated or destroyed.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces bombed the oil port of Ras Lanuf today, in a bid to slow the rebel advance on the capital city of Tripoli, the Wall Street Journal reports. Ras Lanuf has long been a strategic rebel stronghold, but Gadhafi’s troops have been unable to drive them out because of the city’s booby-trapped streets and fuel shortages. “They are bombarding the city now,” said one witness. “They are sending in tanks, and they are dropping leaflets over the city telling people not to leave their houses.” In other developments: Hillary Clinton said the US is cutting all ties with Libya’s embassy in Washington, CNN reports. “We are suspending our relationships with the existing Libyan embassy, so we expect them to end operating as the embassy of Libya,” she said. The EU called for Gadhafi to step down today, and French President Nicolas Sarkozy said the Libyan leader “has lost all legitimacy.”

– Coalition forces have effectively imposed a no-fly zone over Libya, Adm. Mike Mullen tells CNN, and American and British aircraft have taken out most of the country's air defense systems. Coalition forces are also targeting Moammar Gadhafi's ground forces outside Benghazi, though it's not clear whether that was the result of another round of cruise missile attacks. A fighter jet was shot down and burst into flames in the area of Benghazi, which has been a stronghold for rebels opposing Gadhafi. It was not immediately clear who the fighter jet belonged to. The development is significant, in part, because Benghazi has been considered the center of the opposition forces. The opposition has been pushed back from other cities that it used to have control of, and rebels have vowed to defend Benghazi to the death.

– The New York Times has confirmed that four of its journalists are missing in Libya, and says they're being held by Moammar Gadhafi's government. "We have been in touch with the Libyan government, and we can confirm that four of our journalists are being held by the Gadhafi government," says the paper's public editor. The news comes as the UN Security Council voted last night to impose a no-fly zone over the country, and as Gadhafi's regime declared a cease-fire, notes CNN.

– Coalition forces continue to pound Moammar Gadhafi's forces in Libya, but the US isn't about to take the lead—at least not yet. President Obama "has been vague on what the exit strategy is for the military intervention," says CNN political analyst Gloria Borger. "It made an awful lot of sense when the French and the British began the first sorties into Libyan airspace, it made an awful lot of sense because it's their neighborhood, after all." In other developments: Coalition forces are targeting Gadhafi's inner circle, including his security staff and close aides, the New York Times reports. US officials say Gadhafi's inner circle has been moved to Benghazi, the country's second-largest city. US officials also say Gadhafi's inner circle has been moved to the western part of the country, where the bulk of Libya's population lives. Coalition forces are also targeting Gadhafi's command and control infrastructure, the Wall Street Journal reports. In other developments: Coalition forces are targeting Gadhafi's inner circle, including his security staff and close aides. US officials say Gadhafi's inner circle has been moved to the western part of the country, where

– The US should arm Libyan rebels so they can take on Moammar Gadhafi's forces on the ground, says a political scientist at the RAND Corp., who appeared on CNN's Student News this morning. A similar move in Bosnia ended a civil war, Angel Rabasa says, and it would be good for the US to get involved on the side of democracy in Libya. Gadhafi's ground forces are "well-paid, well-equipped" and "still able to fight and maneuver on the ground," says Rabasa, who was on the Bosnia Train and Equip Task Force in the early 1990s. Meanwhile, NATO has agreed in principle to take over enforcement of the no-fly zone over Libya, but stopped short of interpreting that mandate as a license to attack government troops who may be threatening unarmed civilians, reports CNN. NATO forces will be able to close air space to all flights except for humanitarian ones and will be able to use force in self-defense.

– A woman who claims she was raped by Moammar Gadhafi's forces has been released after two days in captivity, CNN reports. Eman al-Obeidy burst into a hotel in Tripoli yesterday and told foreign reporters she had been raped by Gadhafi's troops for two days. "Look at what Gadhafi's brigades did to me," said CNN photojournalist Khalil Abdallah. "She... entered a place she wasn't supposed to enter." A government spokesman said Obeidy is at home with her family and the case is being investigated.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi launched an all-out assault on the oil port of Ras Lanuf today, in what appeared to be a major setback to the opposition movement, reports CNN. Gadhafi’s troops, backed by warplanes from the US-led coalition, launched artillery and rocket attacks on the city, which the opposition seized on Sunday. The assault came just hours after the defection of Libya’s foreign minister, who told the New York Times that Gadhafi is “determined to win.” The loss of Ras Lanuf is seen as a major setback because it’s the largest city in eastern Libya to fall to the opposition. Gadhafi’s troops have also been advancing on the city of Misrata.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces launched a fresh attack on the rebel-held city of Misrata today, attacking with tanks, artillery, and rockets, the Telegraph reports. Misrata is the last major city in the western part of the country to fall to the rebels, and Gadhafi’s forces have been trying to take it back ever since a NATO airstrike killed a rebel leader last week. NATO is considering arming the rebels, but so far no decision has been made, CNN reports. British diplomats are on the ground in Libya meeting with key figures of the opposition, but no decision has been made by Western allies on whether to arm them. “What we are engaged in is protecting the civilian population in Libya, which we have done with a lot of success,” Britain’s foreign secretary said. “When people look at what we ‘re doing in Libya, they do have to look at what would be happening if we did n’t do what we’d done over the last few weeks and it would have been a catastrophic situation.”

– Moammar Gadhafi has sent a letter to President Obama asking for an end to NATO's bombing of Libya, a senior administration official tells CNN. The letter contained "nothing new," the official says, and the administration is taking it seriously. Gadhafi's letter "contained no offers to negotiate or step down, and the administration is taking it seriously," the official says. Gadhafi's government has also asked for a review of a CNN interview with the woman who says she was raped by Gadhafi's forces.

– Moammar Gadhafi has agreed in principle to a cease-fire with rebels, but the Libyan government will not remove him from power, according to the head of the opposition National Libyan Council. “We have rejected the African Union’s road map because it does not include the removal of Gadhafi,” Abdel Hafez Ghoga told reporters, according to CNN. African Union leaders will hold talks with Ghoga and other rebel leaders today to try to end the fighting.

– The bodies of American photojournalist Chris Hondros and British photojournalist Tim Hetherington, killed in the Libyan conflict, arrived in the rebel stronghold of Benghazi last night, reports CNN. The ship carrying their bodies was greeted by a number of young Libyans and about 20 rebel fighters. "To me, the most important thing is just figuring out the way to cover it," said Hondros' friend. Click here for more.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi launched a major assault on the rebel-held city of Misrata today, attacking with tanks, artillery, and warplanes, witnesses tell CNN. At least 10 people were killed and 30 wounded, according to foreign affairs correspondent Marie Colvin of the Sunday Times, who has been in the city for a week. "It's just hell," she said. " Civilian neighborhoods are being decimated as we speak." Gadhafi's forces have also launched an attack on Benghazi, the country's second-largest city, but it's not clear if NATO is involved in the Misrata assault.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces shelled the rebel-held city of Misrata again today, as NATO stepped up its presence in the area, the New York Times reports. Gadhafi’s forces have been using heavy artillery against the city, which the Times describes as Gadhafi’s last major stronghold, and as many as 100 people have been killed in the last 24 hours. Rebels, however, say they’ve managed to hold the city’s port, which has been a key source of food and medical supplies for Misrata, CNN reports. NATO, meanwhile, says it’s stepped up its presence in the area to prevent Gadhafi’s forces from using civilians as human shields.

– Moammar Gadhafi made his first public appearance in nearly two weeks yesterday, meeting with tribal elders in a hotel in Tripoli. Hours later, four rockets hit his Bab al-Aziziya compound in the center of the city, a Libyan government official tells CNN. At least two emergency vehicles were seen speeding toward the compound after the blasts, CNN notes.

– Libyan rebels today praised President Obama’s speech on the Middle East and North Africa, calling it “good enough,” “good enough,” and “half-full glass,” according to CNN. But Syrian activists were less impressed, saying Obama didn’t go far enough, and that the speech was “more timid than it needed to be.” In Benghazi, the heart of the Libyan revolt against longtime strongman Moammar Gadhafi, a rebel leader pronounced Obama’s speech “good enough,” while a Palestinian official called it “half-full glass.”

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi have launched their biggest attack yet against a rebel stronghold in the mountains of western Libya, one of the Libyan leader's former generals tells CNN. Over the past two days, Gadhafi's forces have unleashed their biggest attack yet against one of the mountainous rebel strongholds in western Libya, according to one of his former generals. Haji Usama, as he is known to the rebels, was once a top commander in Gadhafi's forces. He spent decades in the Libyan army, including a tour of duty in neighboring Chad, and now commands in Zintan, population 40,000. At least four explosions rocked Zintan today, as the foreign policy chief of the European Union arrived in the war—torn nation and a former US congresswoman criticized American policy on Libyan state television. Rebels in Zintan, in western Libya, said they believe the explosions were from Grad rockets. NATO jets destroyed eight Libyan warships in the ports of Tripoli, Al Khums, and Sirte after concluding that Gadhafi had started using naval assets to lay mines and hamper international humanitarian aid, said a NATO military spokesman.

– NATO stepped up the pressure on Moammar Gadhafi's forces in Libya today by launching more than a dozen airstrikes on Tripoli. A Libyan government spokesman tells CNN that at least three people were killed and 150 wounded in the strikes, which targeted a guard compound that had been emptied of Gadhafi's military volunteers in anticipation of an attack. It was one of the heaviest strikes on Tripoli since NATO began taking on Gadhafi's forces two months ago. In other developments: Jordan announced that it would send a permanent envoy to Libya's interim rebel government, which has been declared the legitimate representative of the Libyan people by Italy, France, and Qatar, CNN reports. The EU's foreign policy chief pledged support to the rebel government.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s compound was hit by explosions today, and the head of Libya’s opposition government told reporters he welcomed a call Friday by Russian President Dmitry Medvedev for Moammar Gadhafi to step down, CNN reports. Medvedev’s statement, echoing the stance of American and European leaders, appeared to indicate a closing diplomatic window for the longtime Libyan strongman. The chairman of the National Transitional Council, Mustafa Abdul Jalil, said he has offered amnesty to Gadhafi loyalists who defected before the demise of the regime, but reiterated that there will be “no negotiation for any solution until Gadhafi’s departure.” Once that happens, elections and a constitutional referendum will be held within a year, Jalil said.

– Fresh explosions rang out near Tripoli this morning, hours after South African President Jacob Zuma held talks with Moammar Gadhafi and signaled he was ready to accept an African Union plan for a cease-fire. The blasts were heard about five minutes apart, as jets flew over the capital. A Libyan government official said the first strike hit Argentinian fights with Libyan rebels, reports CNN. Meanwhile, Libya’s oil minister confirmed today that he’s defected, and said he’s considering signing up with the opposition movement. Shukri Ghanem told CNN in Rome that he left Libya because the suffering of the people became too unbearable. “This war is getting even worse every day and there is no end to it,” he said.

– As NATO continues to pound Moammar Gadhafi's forces in Libya, the Russian president's special envoy is headed to Benghazi to meet with rebel leaders, CNN reports. Mikhail Margelov doesn't rule out traveling to Tripoli to meet with Gadhafi himself, but "I do not rule out that I may have to go to Tripoli, too, if I get the corresponding order from the president." Meanwhile, Gadhafi has vowed to stay in power "until the end," even as NATO airstrikes continue to target his compound in Tripoli. "I am now speaking as planes and bombs fall around me," he said in a live audio broadcast on state television. "But my soul is in God's hand. We will not give up." Click for more on the conflict in Libya.

– A US oil refiner has sold 1.2 million barrels of oil to Libya’s Transitional National Council, the first sale of its kind in the eastern part of the country. The State Department confirmed the deal, made last week, with the rebel government in control of the eastern part of Libya. Tesoro, a US oil refiner, entered into a deal May 25 with the Transitional National Council based in Benghazi, Libya for 1.2 million barrels of Libyan crude oil, the State Department said in a written statement. The rebel government in control of the eastern part of Libya has made its first sale of oil from territory it controls, the State Department confirmed Wednesday. Tesoro, a US oil refiner, entered into a deal May 25 with the Transitional National Council based in Benghazi, Libya for 1.2 million barrels of Libyan crude oil, the State Department said in a written statement. CNN reports that a UN resolution justifies the targeting of Moammar Gadhafi because, as head of the military, he is part of the control and command structure and therefore a legitimate target.

– Libyan rebels say they've found videos on captured Gadhafi soldiers showing the regime's henchmen raping women and torturing people, CNN reports. The videos are so awful that rebels are trying to erase them, says CNN's Sara Sidner, who's reporting from Misrata. "We should tell you that we have blurred almost all of the video to make it possible for Sara to file the report," she writes. "Seemingly all the major US newspapers, including the New York Times and Washington Post, are editorializing harshly that NATO shows itself a complete failure in Libya. It acts too slowly, with too little force and proves shamefully dependent on US firepower." Click here for more.

– A NATO airstrike on a residential building west of Tripoli early today killed at least 15 people, including three children, according to the Libyan government. NATO, which can’t confirm the death toll, issued a statement saying it “would regret any loss of civilian life and we go to great lengths to avoid civilian casualties,” CNN reports. But Libyan officials are blaming NATO, the French, the British, and the US for the attack.

– As the US steps up its involvement in Libya, Moammar Gadhafi is losing control of the western part of the country, US and NATO officials tell the Wall Street Journal. Gadhafi's forces have been retaking territory from rebels in the western town of Jedaim, and are now in control of the oil port of Ras Lanuf. "He's losing control of the western part of Libya, and that's a good thing," says a NATO official. "It means he's losing control of his forces, and that's a good thing." The Journal notes that Gadhafi's forces have also lost control of the Bin Jawad oil refinery, which is a key source of fuel for Gadhafi's forces. In other developments: The defection of Libya's national soccer team to the opposition is "another setback for Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi" but "only a political solution will make it possible to... settle the current conflict," says African Union president Jacob Zuma, according to CNN. The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to decide on the next steps in Libya.

– The International Criminal Court has issued warrants for the arrest of Moammar Gadhafi, his son Saif al-Islam, and his brother Abdullah al-Sanussi on charges of crimes against humanity, CNN reports. The ICC is still trying to link Gadhafi, his son, and his brother to rapes that took place during Libya's civil war, but it doesn't yet have enough evidence to do so. It has evidence that rapes have taken place in Libya's civil war, he said, but he can not prove Gadhafi ordered them. The court issued arrest warrants Monday for Gadhafi, his son Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, and his brother. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi is a close adviser to his father. His arrest warrant came two days after his 39th birthday. An air war alone is not enough, say some analysts. Some fear a protracted war that could go on for months.

– As NATO jets continue to pound Moammar Gadhafi's forces, the Libyan leader is tapping women for help. Women from Tripoli to Bani Walid have been traveling to a training facility to practice with weapons, a common sight in a country where young girls receive military training in schools, CNN reports. "I liked training and defending my country," said a woman who is training other women to handle weapons. Meanwhile, Ayesha Gadhafi, Gadhafi's only daughter, told a French TV station that her father will not step down because he is a "symbol, a guide" for the Libyan people. "This is his country, his land, his people. Where would he go?" she asked.

– African Union leaders won’t cooperate with the International Criminal Court’s arrest warrant for Moammar Gadhafi, CNN reports. “The arrest warrant seriously complicates the efforts aimed at finding a negotiated political solution to the crisis in Libya,” said a statement from the summit that ended Friday in Equatorial Guinea. The warrant for Gadhafi, his son Saif al-Islam, and his brother Abdullah al-Sanussi also “seriously complicates” efforts to negotiate a peace deal, the statement added. African Union leaders will meet in Russia today to discuss the situation in Libya.

– The Libyan rebels who took over the country's capital after Moammar Gadhafi's ouster have lost their top military commander. Gen. Abdul Fattah Younis and two of his aides were shot and killed today in Benghazi, reports CNN. Younis had recently been recalled from the front lines for questioning by judges who were looking into allegations that he had close ties to Gadhafi. Gadhafi's spokesman says the killing shows that the " Transitional National Council is not able to lead any sort of government or have any control of eastern cities of Libya."

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces fired a missile at an Italian warship in the Mediterranean Sea today, but it missed, CNN reports. The missile hit the frigate Bersagliere, which is part of NATO’s fleet off the Libyan coast. It’s the first time NATO’s ships have been targeted off the Libyan coast. A Gadhafi spokesman downplayed the attack, saying, “We haven't used our real military power.”

– Libyan rebels launched a major offensive today against Moammar Gadhafi’s forces in the western town of Bir al-Ghanam, clashing with Gadhafi’s troops from three fronts in a five-hour battle. CNN reports that at least eight rebels were killed in the fighting, and that 1,500 opposition members joined in the battle. Gadhafi’s forces claimed to have won the battle back, but a rebel commander says the opposition still has control of the town, which is 53 miles from Tripoli.

– Rebels in Libya say they are closing in on Moammar Gadhafi, but a government spokesman quickly dismisses the claims, CNN reports. The rebels say they are in control of the oil port of Brega, along with Zawiya, and have captured the town of Garyan to the south. Meanwhile, some artists in rebel strongholds are arming themselves with fresh paint, according to CNN.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s security forces opened fire on protesters in Tripoli today as the Libyan leader’s son addressed the nation on state TV, vowing that the army would stand behind his father and would enforce security at “any price,” reports the New York Times. Residents reported gunfire in parts of Tripoli and one political activist said warplanes had bombed the city. But state TV showed government supporters rallying, and Gadhafi’s son Saif al-Islam said warplanes had hit only ammunition dumps. Forces loyal to Gadhafi had killed dozens of people across the country, human rights groups and witnesses said, prompting widespread condemnation from world leaders. As protests broke out in the capital for the first time following days of unrest in the city of Benghazi, one of Gadhafi’s sons vowed to fight until the “last man standing,” according to Reuters.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s son today said foreign intervention and civil war are all options on the table in Libya, the New York Times reports. “What the Libyan nation is going through has opened the door to all options, and now the signs of civil war and foreign interference have started,” Saif al-Islam Gadhafi said in an interview on Al Arabiya TV. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi said his father is still in control of the western part of the country, but he has lost control of Tripoli and is surrounded by loyalists who are fighting to the death to keep him in power. In other developments: Libya’s former justice minister has led the formation of an interim government based in the eastern city of Benghazi to reunite the country, according to a Libyan newspaper. A hard core of Gadhafi’s troops will probably stay loyal, but much of Libya’s oil is now in the hands of people’s militias and tribal groups, analysts tell Reuters.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces bombed a military base in the eastern Libyan town of Ajdabiyah today, in what appeared to be the first direct attack on a civilian area since the unrest began. A military officer at the site confirmed that the attack took place, according to Reuters, but denied that Gadhafi’s forces had actually bombed the base. Ajdabiyah residents fear that a direct attack by Gadhafi’s forces could cause miles of destruction around the town. Meanwhile, in other developments: Hillary Clinton warned that the US and its NATO allies were still considering a no-fly zone over Libya, although military commanders warned of the peril to allied aircraft of enforcing it. The US is moving ships and planes closer to Libya, and British Prime Minister David Cameron says his government is working to prepare a “no-fly zone” to protect the Libyan people. Malta has refused to return two Libyan warplanes that were flown to the island by defecting pilots last week, according to Maltese Prime Minister Lawrence Gonzi. Malta rejected the request and the fighters are still under armed guard at the airport. The unrest has cut Libya’s oil output by half, according to the International Energy Agency, but Saudi Arabia has pledged to pump more to

– Moammar Gadhafi today blamed al-Qaeda and the US for the unrest in Libya, saying that if foreign powers entered the country they would face a “bloody war,” Reuters reports. “There is a conspiracy to control the Libyan oil and to control the Libyan land, to colonize Libya once again,” he said in a speech on state television. “I dare you to find that peaceful protesters were killed.” He said no more than 150 people had been killed in the unrest, and insisted that he was willing to talk to al-Qaeda, if they had demands. The speech comes as Gadhafi accepted a plan from Hugo Chavez to negotiate an end to the violence.

– Moammar Gadhafi has offered to step down in exchange for guarantees that he and his family won’t be prosecuted, al-Jazeera reports, citing two Arab newspapers. The news comes as Gadhafi’s forces continued their assault on rebel-held towns, raising fears of a protracted civil war. One of Gadhafi’s sons, Saadi, meanwhile, told al-Arabiya that Libya would become Somalia-style, with tribes fighting against each other, and that the country would become a “new Somalia,” Reuters reports. In other developments: Germany is calling for new UN sanctions against Gadhafi. “ Selective sanctions are necessary against those who are responsible for crimes against the Libyan people,” German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle told a newspaper, according to Reuters. “The flow of money must be cut off.”

– The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting at noon today to discuss a no-fly zone over Libya, reports the New York Times. British Prime Minister David Cameron and French President Nicolas Sarkozy are backing the move, which would require the approval of the 15-member council. The meeting comes as rebels continue their advance on Moammar Gadhafi's forces in the east and west, notes the Wall Street Journal. The Red Cross is urging both sides to allow it access to areas in the west that have been cut off from supplies.

– The US launched another round of air strikes against Libya today, this time targeting Moammar Gadhafi's air defenses, reports CNN. The strikes were aimed at enforcing a no-fly zone to prevent Gadhafi's forces from attacking rebels. Earlier, the Libyan government announced a ceasefire, but US officials said Gadhafi's forces were continuing to advance toward the rebel stronghold of Benghazi. Click for more.

– Coalition forces continue to pound Moammar Gadhafi's air defenses in Libya, but the US general in charge of the operation warns that attacks are likely to slow in the days ahead, reports the Wall Street Journal. Gadhafi's forces have made "significant gains" in recent days, the general said, but he added that he doesn't expect the conflict to become a "full-blown war." In other developments: The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting at noon today to consider imposing a no-fly zone over the country, reports Reuters. Arab League chief Amr Moussa criticized the strikes, saying they were like "medieval calls for crusades" that have killed many civilians. Russia's prime minister likened the strikes to " Crusades," and China warned that a no-fly zone could lead to "humanitarian disaster," notes the New York Times. Britain's parliament voted overwhelmingly to authorize the use of British planes and ships to help enforce the no-fly zone.

– Rebels say they're closing in on Moammar Gadhafi's hometown of Sirte, but there's no sign yet that the Libyan leader has agreed to a ceasefire. Rebels say they've taken the town of Nawfaliyah and they're closing in on Gadhafi's home town of Sirte, but there's no sign yet that the Libyan leader has agreed to a ceasefire, Reuters reports. Rebels say they've also taken Misrata, but Gadhafi's forces have been shelling the city for days and the government has declared a ceasefire there, according to al-Jazeera.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi are staging a massacre in the besieged city of Misrata, evacuees said yesterday, as Turkey said it was trying to broker a ceasefire to halt the bloodshed. A government spokesman said Libya was ready for a “political solution” with world powers, but Gadhafi had to stay. He said the country was ready to discuss political reform, but Gadhafi had to stay. Western powers have destroyed nearly a third of Libyan leader Gadhafi’s military since launching air strikes last month, but NATO said it was forced to change bombing tactics because of human shields. The besieged city of Misrata, the only big population center in western Libya where a revolt against Gadhafi has not been crushed, is now the priority for NATO air strikes. But Libyan rebels on the battlefield complained about what they see as a dropping off in air support and a spokesman in the rebel stronghold of Benghazi said NATO “disappointed us” with its slow response that allowed Gadhafi forces to kill people. “Either NATO does its work properly or we will ask the Security Council to suspend its work,” said Abdel Fattah Younes, head of the rebel forces.

– The head of Libya's rebel army has lashed out at NATO, saying the alliance is letting the people of Misrata die every day. "NATO blesses us every now and then with a bombardment here and there, and is letting the people of Misrata die every day," Abdel Fattah Younes, head of the rebel forces, said in the eastern stronghold city of Benghazi, according to Reuters. "NATO has disappointed us." NATO officials said Misrata was now their No. 1 priority for air strikes. The besieged city is the only major Libyan population center that hasn't been crushed by Moammar Gadhafi's forces. Earlier, Gadhafi's forces unleashed mortar rounds, tank fire, and artillery shells on Misrata.

– The African Union’s peace plan for Libya has fallen apart, with rebels rejecting it today because it doesn’t include Moammar Gadhafi’s departure, Reuters reports. “The African Union initiative does not include the departure of Gadhafi and his sons from the Libyan political scene, therefore it is outdated,” said rebel leader Mustafa Abdel Jalil after talks in Benghazi. Gadhafi’s son Saif al-Islam quickly dismissed the idea of his father stepping down. Meanwhile, the Red Cross opened a Tripoli office to help civilians trapped in Misrata, but one of Gadhafi’s ministers warned that any aid operation involving foreign troops would be seen as a declaration of war.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi shelled the rebel-held city of Misrata today, killing at least 12 rebels, a rebel spokesman tells Reuters. Gadhafi’s troops have been advancing on the city since yesterday, and are now in full control of the main hospital, the spokesman says. Misrata is Libya’s third-largest city, and has seen some of the worst fighting of the five-month civil war. Gadhafi’s troops have also taken over the town of Jedaim, about 30 miles west of Misrata, and are closing in on the town of Zawiyah just 30 miles away, witnesses tell the Wall Street Journal.

– A NATO airstrike hit a home in Surman yesterday, killing at least 19 civilians, including the wife and two children of a member of Moammar Gadhafi's Revolutionary Command Council, the Libyan government said today. Reporters were taken to a hospital in nearby Sabrata, where they were shown nine bodies, including those of two children, plus some body parts, which the Libyan government said were all of people killed in the attack. NATO said it was investigating the strike, which came a day after NATO admitted killing civilians in a separate aerial attack.

– Moammar Gadhafi's forces have bombed the town of Jedaim in an attempt to stop rebels from advancing on Tripoli, witnesses tell Reuters. Gadhafi's forces have also bombed the town of Bin Jawad, about 30 miles southwest of the capital, in an attempt to stop rebels from crossing the town's only road into Tripoli, witnesses say. Bin Jawad is "one of the most important towns in the western part of the country," a rebel commander tells the Telegraph, adding that he believes Gadhafi's forces are trying to use civilians as human shields. Meanwhile, the World Bank's representative in Libya warned today that the country could end up in the hands of extremists instead of the rebels. "If this civil war goes on, it would be a new Somalia, which I don't say lightly," he said.

– Moammar Gadhafi's sons will be allowed to stay in Libya as part of a peace deal to end the country's five-month civil war, a UN official said today. UN envoy Abdul Elah al- Khatib, who plans to visit Tripoli tomorrow, said Gadhafi and his family can stay in the country as part of a "political process" to end the conflict, Reuters reports. The rebels, who have received diplomatic recognition from Britain and France, withdrew an offer for Gadhafi to stay in Libya if he gave up power. The rebels said they were planning to attack the town of Ghezaia near the Tunisian border in the next 48 hours, and a Reuters correspondent saw dozens of heavily armed pickup trucks heading for the nearby rebel-held town of Nalut.

– Libyan rebels say the gunmen who shot dead the rebel military chief were fighters from an allied militia, in apparent confirmation of deep rifts among the forces struggling to overthrow Moammar Gadhafi. Abdel Fattah Younes, a defector from Gadhafi's inner circle, was killed yesterday in an attack that dealt a blow to both the rebels and their Western backers. There had been widespread speculation as to whether Younes had been killed in an internal rebel feud or by Gadhafi forces which had penetrated the Benghazi based movement. The reports follow 24 hours of confusion over the killing of Abdel Fattah Younes, a defector from Gadhafi's inner circle, whose death deals a blow both to the rebels and their Western backers. There had been widespread speculation as to whether Younes had been killed in an internal rebel feud or by Gadhafi forces which had penetrated the Benghazi based movement.

– Rebels are closing in on Moammar Gadhafi's Tripoli stronghold, but they're running into resistance from Tunisian troops who are patrolling the border to stop the flow of smuggled gasoline, reports the New York Times. "We've gone past Nasr village and right now we're about 25 miles from Zawiyah," a rebel fighter tells Reuters. "Right now we're about 15 miles from Bir Shuaib." Rebels are also trying to get within striking distance of Tripoli, notes the Times, with signs of NATO strikes.

– The International Committee of the Red Cross is pleading with both sides in Libya and Somalia to stop the targeting of hospitals and health care workers, which it says is depriving millions of sick and wounded of treatment. The Red Cross says attacks on medical facilities are increasing from Libya to Somalia, depriving millions of sick and wounded of treatment, Reuters reports. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon is "deeply concerned by reports of the unacceptably large number of civilian casualties as a result of the conflict," his office said in a statement, calling on all sides to "exercise extreme caution in their actions."

– Moammar Gadhafi has fired a Scud missile for the first time in the Libyan civil war, US officials tell Reuters, though NATO says it's unlikely to harm civilians. Gadhafi's forces fired the missile Sunday after rebels seized two key towns near Tripoli, cutting the city off from its supply lines. Rebels have also seized an oil refinery west of Tripoli and cut a pipeline to the capital, according to Reuters. Gadhafi's forces are now believed to be in Tripoli's western suburbs, Reuters notes.

– The fall of Moammar Gadhafi's regime has been followed by jubilation in the Libyan capital of Tripoli, with thousands of people celebrating on the streets and rebels declaring control over most of the city. Gadhafi's whereabouts are unknown, but the New York Times reports that one of his sons, Saif al-Islam, has fled to Algeria. The fall of Gadhafi's 42-year rule is a "moment of celebration, not only for Libyans but for a youth generation in the Arab world that has pursued a political opening across the region," writes Jason Schenker of Prestige Economics in a note to investors. "The secret of the uprising lay in a popular revolt in the working—class districts of the capital, which did most of the hard work of throwing off the rule of secret police and military cliques," he writes. "It succeeded so well that when revolutionary brigades entered the city from the west, many encountered little or no resistance." The fall of Gadhafi's regime is "a moment of celebration, not only for Libyans but for a youth generation in the Arab world that has pursued a political opening across the region," writes Schenker. – Libyan rebels say they've captured Moammar Gadhafi's hometown of Sirte and are closing in on the capital, but the leader's whereabouts are still unknown and there's no sign of an end to the fighting. NATO, meanwhile, says it has launched more airstrikes in Tripoli, targeting Gadhafi's inner circle and loyalists who remain in the city. The strikes are aimed at preventing Gadhafi's forces from using heavy weapons against rebel fighters, the New York Times reports. Gadhafi's foreign minister yesterday told a British TV station that the conflict was almost over, and he urged Gadhafi's loyalists to lay down their arms, Reuters reports. "If I am in charge, I would tell them to lay down their arms," Abdelati Obeidi said.

– As Libyan rebels closed in on Moammar Gadhafi's hometown of Sirte today, the fugitive leader's wife and two of his sons managed to escape across the border into Algeria. The Algerian government says Aisha Gadhafi gave birth to a girl within hours of the family making it across, but Libya's interim government demanded that the family be returned to the country to face trial, Reuters reports. Algeria says it will close the southern part of its border with Libya. In other developments: Libyan rebels say they have captured Gadhafi's former defense minister, one of his sons, and two of his daughters-in-law, al-Jazeera reports. Gadhafi himself is believed to be in the Sirte area, but it's not clear whether he is there or still in Tripoli. Rebels say they have captured Gadhafi's former defense minister, one of his sons, and two of his daughters-in-law, al-Jazeera reports. Gadhafi's wife and two of his sons have fled across the border into Algeria, prompting Libya's interim government to demand that they be returned to the country to face trial. – Russia has officially recognized Libya's Transitional National Council as the country's legitimate government, the Wall Street Journal reports. Russia's foreign minister made the announcement in a closed-door meeting with the TNC's head, Mustafa Abdul-Jalil. "The Russian Federation recognizes the National Transitional Council as the legitimate government of Libya," said Sergei Lavrov, according to Reuters. "It is in the interest of Libya for Russia to support the legitimate government of Libya."

– An Islamist military commander who helped defend Benghazi against Moammar Gadhafi's forces has called on Libya's interim Cabinet to resign, because they are " remnants of the old regime." Ismail al- Salabi also took a swipe at secular groups he said were trying to give Islamists a bad name and create political strife that would only benefit Gadhafi. Meanwhile, the proliferation of weapons in Libya is a major concern and the new rulers need to establish a proper police force and army to replace the hundreds of armed groups who patrol the streets, the United Nations special adviser on Libya said today. Ian Martin, in Libya to compile a report for UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon on rebuilding the country after its civil war, also said the interim government needed to start the electoral process soon if it is to honor its commitment to establish democracy. The disintegration of Muammar Gadhafi's rule after a six-month war has left a security vacuum in Libya, with no state security forces, rebel fighters who are not part of any formal structure and huge quantities of unsecured weapons. Western powers and Libya's neighbors fear that the power vacuum could allow huge quantities of unsecured weapons left over from the civil war to end up in the hands of Islamist militants,

– Moammar Gadhafi's whereabouts are still unknown, but the dictator's son Saif al-Islam has confirmed that his father is still in Libya. "He is still in Libya," Saif al-Islam told al-Jazeera today, according to the Telegraph. "He is in the Libyan town of Zawiyah." Saif al-Islam also said that Gadhafi's eldest son, Saadi Gadhafi, has fled to Niger with the rest of the Gadhafi family. The Telegraph notes that Saadi Gadhafi's wife and three children are also believed to be in Niger. Saadi Gadhafi's whereabouts are unknown.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi seized the airport and fort in Sabha, one of the last towns still held by Gadhafi's troops, a spokesman for Libya's interim government said today. "Our forces are there in the airport and in the castle... Our flags are flying there," the spokesman said, according to the BBC. Sabha is the last town in Libya still held by Gadhafi's troops and controls the main route south out of the country. Meanwhile, the interim government has failed to agree on a new Cabinet, Reuters reports. Interim government forces fled in chaos from the town of Bani Walid and pulled back from Sirte after yet more failed attempts to storm Gadhafi's final bastions and take control of the entire country. The political and military problems underscored how hard it would be to restore stability to Libya after Gadhafi was driven out of last month.

– The capture and death of Moammar Gadhafi has brought an end to more than four months of uncertainty in Libya, but the country's new leaders must now deal with the question of who will run the country in the wake of the dictator's death. Here's what you need to know: Libya's new leaders will formally decide on Wednesday whether to end NATO's involvement in the country, Reuters reports. NATO will formally decide on the matter on Thursday, the New York Times reports. President Obama praised the new Libyan leaders for "making the hard decisions to end Gadhafi's rule," but said the US would continue to support NATO in "any way that is necessary to protect Americans and our partners." In Sirte, the last major Libyan city still held by pro-Gadhafi forces, residents say they're stunned by the dictator's death. "He was a friend to us," one tells the AP. – A lawyer for Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor who was with Michael Jackson when he collapsed, denies his client gave the singer painkilling drugs. "He just happened to find him in his bed, and he wasn't breathing," Edward Chernoff tells the AP, denying reports that Murray gave Jackson Demerol or Oxycontin. Chernoff said any drugs given to Jackson were in response to a specific health complaint, and were never prescribed or allowed to be given to the singer. Police have interviewed Murray, but say he is not a suspect, the Telegraph reports.

– Police have raided the Houston office of Michael Jackson's doctor, looking for evidence of manslaughter, his lawyer says. Officers from the Drug Enforcement Agency entered Dr Conrad Murray's office and removed several items, Murray's spokeswoman tells the BBC. It is believed the doctor was at 50—year—old Jackson's house when he died last month.

– Police have raided the Las Vegas home of Michael Jackson's doctor as part of a manslaughter investigation. Dr. Conrad Murray, who was with Jackson when he died, was at the singer's mansion and tried to revive him before he died. Police also searched Jackson's Las Vegas home and offices. Murray, who was with Jackson when he died, has not been named as a suspect. The Los Angeles County coroner's office has delayed the release of Jackson's autopsy results until next week, amid speculation about the role prescription drugs played in the singer's death, reports the Telegraph.

– Michael Jackson had lethal levels of propofol in his body when he died and was being treated for insomnia, according to court documents made public today. The findings were contained in a previously sealed search warrant, which has been made public in Texas. The singer died in June from a cardiac arrest at his home in Los Angeles. Police have interviewed his doctor, but he has not been named as a suspect. There are reports that the coroner has concluded Jackson's death was homicide.

– Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor accused of killing Michael Jackson, will be allowed to work in California while he awaits trial, a court has ruled. During a brief procedural hearing, a Los Angeles judge said he did not have the authority to ban Murray, reports the Telegraph. Members of the pop star's family were inside court to hear the ruling. Murray, 57, denies involuntary manslaughter in Jackson's death. A preliminary hearing has been scheduled for 23 August.

– The Los Angeles coroner has officially ruled Michael Jackson's death a homicide, with the main cause being the powerful anesthetic Propofol, reports the Telegraph. The report also found that the singer had taken four additional drugs before his death, raising the chances that his doctors will face criminal charges.

– Michael Jackson's death certificate has been amended to say that the King of Pop died as a homicide, raising the chances that doctors will be charged in his death. Investigators had concluded that a powerful concoction of prescription drugs killed the pop star. The coroner's further homicide verdict increases the chances of criminal charges being brought against Jackson's doctors, the Los Angeles Times reports.

– Michael Jackson had a strong heart and was a “fairly healthy” 50 years old when he died, according to an autopsy report obtained by the AP. His weight was in the acceptable range for a man of his height, but he had punctured arms, tattooed lips and eyebrows, lung damage, and arthritis, the report states. His death was ruled a homicide caused by a powerful anesthetic.

– Manchester City's Emmanuel Adebayor is in hot water again, this time over a stamp on the head of Arsenal's Robin Van Persie during yesterday's game. – The executors of Michael Jackson's estate have asked the Discovery Channel to cancel a TV show that purports to re-enact the King of Pop's autopsy. In a letter to the network, John Branca and John McClain said the show, Michael Jackson's Autopsy: What Really Killed Michael Jackson, was in "shockingly bad taste" and was the result of a "blind desire to exploit" the singer's death, the Telegraph reports. The show is scheduled to air in Europe in January.
