– Dr. Conrad Murray is expected to be charged with involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, reports the Los Angeles Times. Murray, who had been treating the King of Pop for a year, surrendered himself to authorities today and is expected to turn himself in tomorrow. He has denied causing Jackson's death.

– Sony Music has signed the biggest recording deal in history, with the estate of Michael Jackson agreeing to a deal that will see the King of Pop's albums sold 31 million times since his death last June, the Wall Street Journal reports. Sony has sold 31 million Jackson albums since the singer's death, the most ever for a single artist. The deal will see Jackson's three best-selling albums— Thriller, This Is It, and King of Pop—compete against each other for the rights to his music. Jackson's three albums have sold a combined 11 million copies.

– The second series of Russell Brand’s The Russell Brand Show begins on the BBC tomorrow, and the first question posed to the comedian by a fan was, “What’s the worst thing you’ve ever done?” Brand’s response: “I don’t think I’ve ever done anything like that.” The video is in the gallery.

– Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor who was present when Michael Jackson died, has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter. Murray, who is accused of giving Jackson a lethal dose of anesthetic then failing to provide proper care, will stand trial on March 28, reports the Telegraph.

– Michael Jackson's brother Randy was hospitalized today with chest pains, reports AP. The 48-year-old was in court Monday for a hearing in the case of Dr Conrad Murray, who is accused of giving Michael Jackson a lethal dose of anesthetic but denies involuntary manslaughter.

– A year after the death of Michael Jackson, his father has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the doctor charged with giving him a lethal overdose. Joe Jackson accuses Conrad Murray of professional negligence for administering a fatal mix of sedatives to the singer, the BBC reports. Murray has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter in his death. LaToya Jackson claims her brother was murdered because he was worth so much more dead than alive. “He was murdered for his catalog and they knew that,” she said in an interview with the BBC.

– The first anniversary of Michael Jackson's death is being marked with a series of tributes to the King of Pop. A makeshift memorial is being set up at the Forest Lawn cemetery in Los Angeles, where Jackson was buried, and fans will be allowed to pay their respects from a distance, the Los Angeles Times reports. Jackson's brothers were among the mourners at his funeral last week.

– Michael Jackson's mother has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against concert promoter AEG, claiming the company put the King of Pop under great pressure to complete his planned series of concerts in London and failed to provide life-saving equipment and proper oversight of his doctor. Katherine Jackson is seeking unspecified damages, the Telegraph reports. AEG has yet to comment on the action.

– The trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor accused of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, gets under way today, and the first witness will be Dr. Faheem Muhammad, the singer's skin doctor. Murray has pleaded not guilty. The defense plans to portray Muhammad as an addict who may have given himself a lethal dose of the drug propofol, reports the Los Angeles Times. The judge in the case has barred the doctor from testifying, saying it is not relevant to the case. Murray is accused of giving Jackson a lethal dose of propofol in an attempt to help him sleep. The singer died shortly before his planned comeback concerts in London.

– The bed in which Michael Jackson died won't be sold at auction after all. The bed's headboard has been pulled from the December sale at the request of Jackson's family, Reuters reports. "We want to maintain a good relationship with the family and we don't want to do anything upsetting for them," the president of Julien's Auctions says.

– Michael Jackson’s doctor tried to hide the fact that he had given the singer propofol shortly before his death, a prosecutor said today at a preliminary hearing. Conrad Murray didn’t call paramedics until after Jackson had died, the prosecutor said, according to the BBC. Murray has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter. Also today, a bodyguard testified that Jackson’s doctor told him to clean up medical paraphernalia in the moments after the singer’s death. An emergency room doctor also testified that Murray did not tell her he had given Jackson propofol.

– Michael Jackson’s doctor will stand trial for involuntary manslaughter in the singer’s death, a judge ruled today. Dr Conrad Murray, who has pleaded not guilty, faces up to four years in prison if convicted, the BBC reports. At a preliminary hearing yesterday, a detective testified that Jackson told Murray he would have to cancel his planned comeback concerts if he didn’t have a dose of propofol in his system. Murray told police he gave Jackson the drug after a night of lesser drugs to help him sleep, the detective said.

– A judge has given the green light to Katherine Jackson’s wrongful death lawsuit against AEG Live, the promoters of Michael Jackson’s “This Is It” tour. The suit claims that AEG pushed the singer too far in rehearsals, and that the company ignored signs of stress in Michael Jackson’s life, the Telegraph reports. The judge said the suit can move forward, though it’s not clear when it will be heard.

– The trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, the doctor accused of involuntary manslaughter in Michael Jackson's death, has been delayed until May. Murray, who is accused of giving Jackson an overdose of the painkiller Percocet, told the judge that he accepted the delay so long as it wasn't " strung along over a long period of time," the BBC reports. Opening statements were due to begin on March 24, but will now begin on May 9.

– Autopsy photos of Michael Jackson's death can be shown to the jury at his doctor's trial, a judge has ruled. Dr. Conrad Murray's lawyers argued the photos would show Jackson gave himself the lethal dose of the surgical anesthetic propofol he was being treated for, but prosecutors said the photos would show the star was healthy before his death, the Telegraph reports. Potential jurors have been asked a series of questions about their views on Jackson, including "Have you ever considered yourself a fan of Michael Jackson?" and "Have you ever owned any of Michael Jackson's music?" Murray has pleaded not guilty to involuntary manslaughter in the singer's death.

– A film of Michael Jackson's final rehearsals before his death can't be used in the trial of the doctor accused of killing him, a judge ruled yesterday. Conrad Murray's lawyers argued that This Is It is not a fair representation of Jackson's health in the days before his death, and thus shouldn't be shown to the jury, the Los Angeles Times reports. Prosecutors had wanted to show around 12 hours of recordings from the rehearsal.

– The prosecution rested its case today in the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, who is accused of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, reports the Los Angeles Times. Murray's lawyers have argued that Jackson gave himself the lethal dose of Propofol as the doctor was trying to wean him off the drug, but the prosecution says that's just wishful thinking. The day before Jackson's death, Murray gave the singer a lethal dose of the drug through a hole in a bottle in his bedroom wall, according to testimony from one of Jackson's bodyguards. Murray told the bodyguard to put the vials in a bag, and the bodyguard was the first to reach Jackson's bedroom after the doctor called for help, according to the testimony. In other news from the trial, the BBC reports that Jackson's ex-wife, La Toya Jackson, is set to testify against Murray.

– The Black Eyed Peas have pulled out of a tribute concert for Michael Jackson in Wales because of "unavoidable circumstances," organizers say. The concert, featuring sister La Toya and other stars, was to be held just weeks before the trial of Jackson's doctor, Dr. Conrad Murray, begins. The Peas, who were to be joined by Christina Aguilera, Cee Lo Green, Gladys Knight, and Smokey Robinson, had been scheduled to perform at the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff on Saturday night, the Telegraph reports.

– Dr. Conrad Murray’s lawyers have dropped a key claim in his trial for involuntary manslaughter—that Michael Jackson swallowed a fatal dose of propofol while Murray was not looking. The claim had been a key argument in Murray’s defense, and the defense may still argue that Jackson injected his own dose of propofol, the Telegraph reports. Yesterday, the autopsy doctor who performed Jackson’s death testified that it was more likely Murray gave Jackson too much of the drug to try to help him sleep. Dr. Christopher Rogers said it was more likely Jackson's personal physician mistakenly gave him too much of the drug propofol to try to help him sleep. He added Dr Murray had no precision dosing device in Jackson's bedroom. “It's reasonable to believe that the doctor had an imperfect control over the dose,” Rogers said. “Michael Jackson could not have given himself the powerful anesthetic that caused his death.”

– The defense in the Conrad Murray trial began today with a doctor and a nurse practitioner who both worked with and counseled Michael Jackson. Dr. Allan Metzger, a friend of Jackson's for more than 20 years, testified that he had given the King of Pop sleep drugs as a sleep aid, but that other doctors had turned him down, reports the Telegraph. Murray, who is charged with involuntary manslaughter in Jackson's death, has told the court that he had been trying to wean Jackson off the powerful painkiller Percocet for more than a year. The defense also called a detective and a nurse practitioner, both of whom previously treated Jackson. They will have to counter four weeks of testimony from prosecution witnesses, who alleged that Murray acted unethically and with gross negligence.

– Michael Jackson's doctor made 17 "flagrant violations" when he gave the singer propofol, an expert testified yesterday. Dr. Steven Shafer said the drug should never be used to treat insomnia, and Dr. Conrad Murray's negligence was directly responsible for Jackson's death, the Los Angeles Times reports. "Yes, is not what a doctor says to a patient request that is not in their best interest," said Shafer, who called Murray "clueless" about the drug.

– A nurse practitioner testified today that she warned Michael Jackson about using the drug propofol to help him sleep, but the singer refused, the Telegraph reports. Cherilyn Lee said she told Jackson that Diprivan was the only thing that would help him sleep, and he told her that it was the only thing that would do the trick. She was testifying at the trial of Dr. Conrad Murray, who is accused of involuntary manslaughter in Jackson's death. Another doctor testified that he believes Jackson was addicted to the painkiller Demerol, and that he gave himself the fatal dose of propofol while Murray was out of the room.

– The involuntary manslaughter trial of Dr. Conrad Murray continues in Los Angeles today. Murray is accused of giving Michael Jackson a lethal dose of the surgical anesthetic propofol in an effort to get him to sleep, and left the room when it was time for the singer to go to the hospital. He also left Jackson's room at the hospital, leaving Jackson to die on his own. Jurors deliberated about 12 hours over the weekend before sending off for the day without reaching a verdict, reports the Los Angeles Times. Jurors are expected to return today.

– Michael Jackson's former doctor has been found guilty of involuntary manslaughter in the death of the King of Pop. Conrad Murray, 58, was accused of giving Jackson a lethal dose of the anesthetic Propofol in an attempt to wean him off the drug. He had hoped to wed Jackson and start a family, but the star died soon after he left his bedroom to use the bathroom. Murray's lawyers tried to blame Jackson for his own death, but jurors believed the facts and found him guilty, reports the BBC. Murray could now face four years in prison.

– The doctor convicted of killing Michael Jackson says he was "really stupid" and "careless" when he gave the King of Pop the surgical anesthetic propofol. In an interview with Channel 4's The Man Who Killed Michael Jackson, Dr. Conrad Murray says he was trying to wean Jackson off the drug when he gave him the fatal dose. "Was this a mistake? Absolutely," he says. "I was trying to wean him off the propofol. It was really stupid and I was careless not to keep notes of his treatment." The interview airs today.

– Prosecutors are seeking a four-year sentence for Conrad Murray, the doctor convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Michael Jackson, the Los Angeles Times reports. Murray's lawyers have asked that he be kept on probation, saying he's already serving a lifetime sentence of self-punishment. A new California law passed to deal with prison overcrowding could limit Murray's sentence to the state's maximum of four years.

– In his first public remarks in months, Syrian President Bashar al-Assad blamed "external conspiracy" for the unrest there and said elections could take place later this year, but only if they are held in an "iron fist," reports the BBC. " elections could be held later this year but they will not be held in an iron fist," he said. "They will be held in an atmosphere of fairness and in the interest of the Syrian people." Assad also accused the Arab League of being behind attacks against his regime, and said it will be "met with an iron fist" if it tries to intervene on Syria's behalf, reports al-Jazeera.

– The UN Security Council is set to vote Friday on a resolution backing an Arab League plan to end the violence in Syria, but Russia is threatening to veto it if it comes to a vote, the BBC reports. Russia's deputy foreign minister says his country can't support a resolution "in its current form," despite changes made to address its concerns. "This is not enough for us," Gennady Gatilov said, adding that Russia needs more time to consult Moscow. Western diplomats say Russia's concerns have been addressed, including removing a paragraph calling on member states to prevent the flow of arms into Syria. The new draft resolution drops explicit calls for President Bashar al-Assad to hand over power to a deputy to oversee a political transition, the BBC notes.

– Two Syrians and a German-Lebanese man have been arrested in Berlin on suspicion of spying for Bashar al-Assad's regime, the BBC reports. The pair, aged 34 and 47, are suspected of spying for Germany for "several years," according to a federal prosecutor's office. They were arrested as part of an "extensive investigation" into six other people suspected of spying for Syria, the AP reports. German authorities say the pair are suspected of passing information to Russia and China, which vetoed a UN resolution condemning Syria's violence over the weekend.

– The death of American journalist Marie Colvin and French photographer Remi Ochlik in the besieged Syrian city of Homs has ratcheted up the outrage in the West against the regime of Bashar al-Assad. Nicolas Sarkozy called it "shameful" and "another example of the shameless brutality" of Assad's regime, while the US condemned it as "yet another example of the regime's callous disregard for the lives of its own people," reports the BBC. Colvin, a married mother of three, had been covering the conflict in Homs for the Sunday Times. Ochlik, a married father of two, also died when a shell hit a makeshift media center he was operating in. More than 60 people were killed across Syria today, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting on the situation in Syria tomorrow.

– Syrian troops launched a ground assault on the Baba Amr neighborhood of Homs today, in what appears to be a bid to cut off the city from the rest of the country, reports the BBC. The Free Syrian Army said it was pulling out of the district, which has been under siege for nearly a month. It's not clear whether the withdrawal will be enough to fend off the government's new ground assault. Meanwhile, UN humanitarian chief Valerie Amos says she has been denied entry into the country. In a statement, Amos said the refusal came—despite my repeated requests to meet Syrian officials at the highest level to discuss the humanitarian situation and the need for unhindered access to the people affected by the violence."

– UN humanitarian chief Valerie Amos visited the flashpoint Syrian city of Homs today and described the devastation there as "completely devastated," the BBC reports. She met with Syrian Foreign Minister Walid Moallem in Damascus and is expected to meet with President Bashar al-Assad tomorrow. Amos said she had asked for full access to Homs, but the government had asked for more time. "It feels like the city has been closed down," she said, according to al-Jazeera. "Every building in Baba Amr has been hit. There are no schools in Baba Amr, there are no hospitals. There are no roads out of the city. It's just a hell of a situation." Opposition leader Burhan Ghalioun blasted Kofi Annan's call for dialogue with the government, saying it was "disappointing" when "Syrians are being massacred every day."

– Syrian security forces opened fire on a funeral procession in the restive city of Homs today, killing at least 17 people, including six children, according to an opposition group. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 50 people were killed in the attack, including women and children, the BBC reports. The group says security forces are using heavy machine guns in the city, which has been a hotbed of protests against the regime of President Bashar al-Assad. In other Syria news: The UN says 230,000 Syrians have fled their homes in the past year, while 200,000 are displaced within the country, according to the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. Hundreds of refugees a day are arriving in Turkey and Lebanon from Syria. UN Arab League envoy Kofi Annan is in Turkey and has met Syrian opposition figures during his peace mission. He says he expects Damascus to reply on Tuesday to his proposals on the crisis. The UN High Commissioner for Refugees says 30,000 have fled abroad while 200,000 are displaced within Syria. Hillary Clinton said that Syria's "horrific campaign of violence" had "shocked the conscience of the world."

– It's been a year since the first protests against Bashar al-Assad's regime, and today marks the anniversary with more bloodshed: Syrian troops opened fire on a protest in the town of Rankus, killing four, according to an opposition group. It's not clear whether the deaths were the result of the army assault or a protest, the AP reports. In other Syria news: Two car bombs exploded in Damascus today, shaking the capital but causing no injuries, the BBC reports. State TV said intelligence and police buildings were hit, but the cause of the blasts wasn't known. Opposition leader Burhan Ghalioun said he was "shocked" by the blasts, which he blamed on "terrorists," al-Jazeera reports. He called on the international community to put pressure on Assad to step down. The Syrian National Council, meanwhile, marked the anniversary by calling on China and Russia to support UN efforts to end the violence, the BBC reports.

– As the Arab League meets in Baghdad today to discuss the Syria peace plan, the Syrian National Council has emerged as the main opposition group in the country, the BBC reports. The Syrian National Council is "the only representative of the Syrian people in the Arab League," said Burhan Ghalioun, one of the group's leaders. The Syrian National Council is "the only representative of the Syrian people in the Arab League," said Burhan Ghalioun, one of the group's leaders. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says government forces have continued their assault on Hama for the 17th straight day. Meanwhile, UN Human Rights Commissioner Navi Pillay says Bashar al-Assad could stop the killings immediately by issuing an order, the BBC reports. Pillay said Assad could end the detentions and stop the killing of civilians just by issuing an order.

– UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon told the UN General Assembly today that the situation in Syria is getting worse by the day and that it's "not an excuse for continued killing" by the regime of Bashar al-Assad, reports the BBC. He called on both sides to take part in a "serious political dialogue" and urged them not to use the deadline for a ceasefire as an excuse for more violence. He said he expected a full ceasefire to take effect by 6am local time on April 12. At least 100 people have been killed in Syria over the past two days as government and rebel forces continue to battle for control of the country ahead of the deadline, reports the BBC.

– Kofi Annan has told the UN Security Council that he's "alarmed" by a rise in violence since the April 12 ceasefire went into effect—mostly in Homs—and that the situation is "entirely contrary to the will of the international community," the BBC reports. France's foreign minister says 300 UN monitors should be deployed in Syria within two weeks, and that if Annan's peace plan doesn't work, the Security Council should consider using force. "We can not allow the LRB- Damascus-RRB- regime to defy us," Alain Juppe said. The UN hopes to deploy as many as 300 monitors. Click for more on the situation in Syria.

– Syria is now in a state of civil war, and the government has lost control of "large chunks" of cities, says the UN's head of peacekeeping. It's the first time a UN official has acknowledged that Syria is in a state of civil war, the BBC reports. The comments came as UN monitors were fired on as they tried to reach the besieged town of Haffa. French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius said he would call on the UN Security Council to make Kofi Annan's peace plan mandatory. France would propose that Annan's six-point plan be enforced under the UN's Chapter Seven provision," he said. "If Russia and China do not act more constructively, their interests in the region will be harmed."

– Bashar al-Assad's regime is fighting a full-scale civil war, says the UN's top peacekeeper, who warns that declaring a civil war would change the world's perception of the situation. "The pragmatic view is that if it looks and sounds like a civil war, then it is one," he tells the BBC. "The government of Syria has lost some large chunks of territory in several cities to the opposition." Researchers studying autistic toddlers have discovered their brain activity appears to be out of sync at a very early stage—a finding that sheds light on the biology of the condition and might help in earlier diagnosis. – The UN Security Council is set to hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to discuss Syria's bloody crackdown on protesters—and Russia, which has shielded Bashar al-Assad from international condemnation, is not happy about it. Syrian opposition leaders met with senior Russian officials in Moscow today, urging the Kremlin to end its support for Assad, reports Reuters. Russia's foreign ministry said the meeting had been arranged at the invitation of a regional cooperation society, and that no official meetings were planned. Meanwhile, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 100 people have been killed across the country today, including 30 in the city of Latakia, reports al-Jazeera.

– Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets across Syria today, defying a military crackdown, as the country’s opposition coalition called for a national salvation conference in Damascus on July 16 to chart a way out of President Bashar al-Assad’s crisis. “We are calling for a national salvation conference to be held in Damascus on July 16,” opposition leader Burhan Ghalioun told al-Jazeera. “It is not a political conference, it is a national salvation conference.” Syrian forces killed 24 civilians today, a prominent rights lawyer said, as tens of thousands called on Assad to step down in some of the biggest demonstrations since a three-month uprising began.

– Protests broke out across the Arab world today, the Muslim day of prayer, with demonstrators killed in Syria and Yemen while Egyptians staged one of the biggest rallies since Hosni Mubarak's fall. Syrian security forces killed 17 pro-democracy demonstrators and two were shot dead in Yemen. In Saudi Arabia local Shi'ites protested in the oil—producing east to call for the withdrawal of Saudi troops from neighboring Bahrain. Japan announced power reduction targets for Tokyo and north Japan that will require big manufacturers and other large users to cut peak summer consumption by one— fourth as it vowed to avoid rolling blackouts that could hobble the economy. The trade ministry also called for 20% power cuts by small—scale industrial power users served by quake—hit Tokyo Electric Power and Tohoku Electric Power, while household cuts were set at 15% to 20%, in draft proposals released on Friday. The government estimates that, with a particularly hot summer like last year, peak power production could fall short of demand by as much as 18,300 megawatts in the two utilities' service area—or about one— fourth of total demand—after a massive March 11 quake and tsunami shut down several big nuclear and thermal power stations.

– Manchester United beat Chelsea 2-0 last night to reach the Champions League semi-final and set up a meeting with Bayer Leverkusen. It's the first time since 1999 that United has made it that far in the competition, and the team's all-time leading scorer, Dimitar Berbatov, scored both goals in the first half to put them on their way. “We knew it was going to be a difficult game,” said Berbatov. “We knew they were a good team, and we knew we had to be at our best to beat them.”

– A grisly video has emerged of the beheading of a Palestinian man in the Gaza Strip. The video, which has not been released by Hamas, shows a man being beaten, blindfolded, and gagged before his body is dumped in a river, the Telegraph reports. The man is shown crying, "My God, my God, my God, can you kill me?" and shouting, "This is a war, this is a war, this is a war." Hamas officials say the man was executed because he was involved in attacks on Israeli soldiers. The killing has drawn condemnation from human rights groups. "This is a war crime, and we condemn it in the strongest possible terms," said a spokesman for Amnesty International. "It is also a violation of international law."

– Russia won the Fed Cup for the first time in three years today, beating Italy in the final after Francesca Schiavone and Flavia Pennetta dropped out of the team. "If they didn't want to come it's their problem," said Italy's Roberta Vinci, who lost to Russia's Vera Zvonareva in the first reverse singles. "It's a shame because we were looking to defend our title. But if they didn't want to come it's our problem," Vinci added, according to Reuters.

– Ronnie Farquhar, a Reuters correspondent who reported from every East European capital and Beijing during the Cold War, has died at the age of 88 in Geneva. Farquhar, a Scot, joined Reuters in 1952 and covered everything from the fall of communism in Hungary in 1956 to the collapse of the Soviet Union in the 1960s. He died after a long illness, his daughter told the AP.

– As the protests against Bashar al-Assad’s regime enter their sixth straight day, the Syrian army deployed overnight in the city of Homs, witnesses said, ahead of Friday prayers, which have been marked by intensifying protests in the last five weeks against authoritarian rule. The death toll in Homs now stands at six, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which also reported that more than 200 people have been injured in the crackdown. In other developments: The UN's High Commissioner for Human Rights, Navi Pillay, has called for an end to the "brutal repression" by the Syrian government, the BBC reports. She urged the government to allow journalists and human rights activists into the country, and to allow peaceful protests to take place. The US is also ratcheting up its pressure on Syria, with Secretary of State Hillary Clinton calling for an end to the "brutal repression," Reuters reports.

– Prince William and Kate Middleton won’t be receiving an invitation from Moammar Gadhafi for their wedding—at least not this week. An invitation to Libya’s ambassador was prepared before the conflict in the country intensified in March but was not delivered, according to official sources cited by Reuters. The decision not to issue the invitation was made by the Foreign Office, which is dealing with the issue of which foreign dignitaries should attend. Click here for more.

– Prince William and Kate Middleton are getting ready to say "I do" in front of thousands of well-wishers in London tomorrow, but the world is less than thrilled about it. Syria has pulled its ambassador out of the ceremony over the country's continuing bloody crackdown on protesters, and Britain says it's inappropriate for its envoy to be there, Reuters reports. The US, meanwhile, is preparing to slap sanctions on Bashar al-Assad's regime, the New York Times reports. "The world is watching what's happening in Syria with concern," said John Kerry. "It's time for the regime to stop the violence. It's time for the international community to put the clearest possible pressure on them."

– China released its first comprehensive review of the country's demographics in a decade yesterday, and the country's total population is now 1.34 billion, an increase of 5.8% from 2000. The 2010 census puts mainland China's total population at 1.34 billion, according to Reuters. It's the first comprehensive review of the country's demographics in a decade. China could face potentially disastrous social and economic problems as the population ages and the number of Chinese of working age shrinks. Click for more on China's population.

– Mahmoud Abbas is set to meet with Hamas leaders in Cairo today to forge a unity government, following the death of Osama bin Laden at the hands of US forces. Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, is "delighted" at the news of bin Laden's death, the group's spokesman told al-Jazeera. "We condemn the assassination and the killing of an Arab and Islamic terrorist," he said. "We call on the international community to support the Palestinian Authority in its efforts to establish a government of national unity." In other developments: The White House says President Obama will make a public statement on the killing of the al-Qaeda leader later today, reports the AP. British Prime Minister David Cameron says the death is "welcomed right across our country," but Britain must remain vigilant against reprisals, reports Reuters. "Getting rid of bin Laden is good for the cause of peace worldwide but what counts is to overcome the discourse and the methods—the violent methods—that were created and encouraged by bin Laden and others in the world," says the Palestinian Authority.

– Syria saw its biggest day of anti-government protests yet today, with thousands taking to the streets after Friday prayers in cities across the country, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Activists say security forces killed 23 protesters, according to al-Jazeera. The news comes as the European Union imposed sanctions in response to the Syrian government's bloody crackdown, and Vietnam sent in troops to contain a rare protest by ethnic Hmong Christians, some of whom were calling for an independent kingdom, Reuters reports.

– Syria has dropped its bid to join the UN's Human Rights Council, allowing Kuwait to replace it as a candidate, UN diplomats tell Reuters. Syria had been expected to run as a candidate for the 47-nation council in the Asian category. Kuwait has confirmed to Western officials that it will enter the race for a spot on the 47-nation council in the Asian category. Syria had been expected to run as a candidate for the 47-nation council in the Asian category.

– A huge anti-government rally in Syria's second-largest city, Aleppo, drew tens of thousands of people to the city's central square today, despite a state of emergency that has been in place since March, the AP reports. The main opposition group, the Syrian National Council, called for a million people to take to the streets to protest President Bashar al-Assad's regime, which has been suppressing dissent since taking power 11 years ago. "This is the beginning of a revolution," said a prominent opposition figure. "We don't know if it will succeed or not, but this is the beginning of a revolution." In other developments: Syria's state-run news agency reported today that four people were killed in clashes between pro- and anti-government protesters in Aleppo, according to al-Jazeera. Activists say security forces are using live ammunition and tear gas in the city, which has been hit hard by violence since the uprising began in March.

– The world's largest producer of illegally logged timber is teaming up with the world's largest producer of illegally logged timber to stop the illegal logging of its own forests, reports the Telegraph. The deal between Israel's Forest Service and Liberia's Ministry of Agriculture will see the latter gain access to EU markets and the former gain access to Israel's vast reserves of illegally logged timber. "This is a very big victory for us," says a spokesman for the Forest Service. "It will allow us to work more closely with the government of Liberia to prevent illegal logging."

– The Obama administration has ramped up pressure on Syria's Bashar al-Assad by imposing sanctions. The penalties include an asset freeze and travel ban on the Syrian president, his inner circle, and several security officials, reports the New York Times. “The actions the administration has taken today send an unequivocal message to President Assad, the Syrian leadership, and regime insiders that they will be held accountable for the ongoing violence and repression in Syria,” said acting Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence John Brennan. The sanctions also include a travel ban and an arms embargo, notes the Wall Street Journal.

– Syria dropped its bid for a seat on the UN Human Rights Council today, in the face of Western pressure. Kuwait took Syria’s place, Reuters reports, after Western countries convinced Arab states that Syria was not a suitable candidate. Kuwait was elected as one of 15 nations today to the council, which has been under pressure over its crackdown on protesters. Click for more.

– A NATO airstrike on Moammar Gadhafi's compound in Tripoli dropped plaster on the ceilings of a hotel where foreign reporters were staying, Reuters reports. The strike was so powerful that plaster fell from the ceilings in a hotel where foreign reporters were staying, about 2 miles from Gadhafi's compound. NATO, meanwhile, stepped up its bombing of Gadhafi's forces today, targeting four military targets in the western part of the country, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– Moammar Gadhafi will meet with South African President Jacob Zuma in Tripoli next week to discuss an exit strategy, according to a South African radio station, but the president’s office made no mention of that in a statement, Reuters reports. Zuma is also a member of the African Union High Level Panel for the Resolution of the conflict in Libya. Meanwhile, fighting continues in Misrata, with the World Health Organization reporting that 12 people are killed a day and 70 wounded in the city’s six operating hospitals.

– After nearly a week of protests, authorities in China's Inner Mongolia region have promised to improve mining safety in the wake of an accident that sparked the unrest.Ethnic Mongolians took to the streets last week in protest over the death of a herder killed when he was run over by a coal truck in the region's biggest coal-producing region. The government of the huge northern region, increasingly dominated by ethnic Han Chinese, told agencies to address safety and environmental concerns related to the mining industry, Xinhua news agency reported. "All relevant departments, enterprises and local governments must promptly report and resolve injuries and accidents that occur in mining areas and transportation links, which have caused serious problems and reactions from the people," said a statement from the government.

– The UN Security Council is set to hold a rare emergency meeting today to discuss Syria's civil war, reports the AP. Syria's Bashar al-Assad has warned that the West will pay a heavy price if it intervenes in his country. "If they intervene in Syria, they will pay a heavy price," he said, according to al-Jazeera. The West has been pressuring Assad to step down in the wake of violence that has killed at least 224 people.

– A new round of protests broke out in Syria today, just hours after President Bashar al-Assad granted amnesty to some political prisoners. Activists say security forces killed dozens of civilians in the central town of Rastan, which has seen protests against Assad, Reuters reports. In the north of the country, meanwhile, two protesters were killed by security forces in the town of Ras al-Ain, according to al-Jazeera. In other Syria news: The Syrian National Council has called for a new round of protests tomorrow, following Assad's concession yesterday, the AP reports.

– Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula has taken credit for the failed plot to blow up a Northwest Airlines jet on Christmas Day, the Telegraph reports. The terrorist group, based in Yemen, claimed responsibility for the attack in a statement posted on the website of the al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula. The statement said the plane was on its way from the Yemeni capital of Sanaa to Yemen's port city of Aden when it was blown up by an explosive device attached to the tail of a cargo plane. The AQAP claimed responsibility for the attack in a statement posted on the website of the al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula. AQAP said the plane was on its way to Aden from the port city of Mocha when it was hit by the explosive device. The AQAP claimed responsibility for the attack in a statement posted on the website of the al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula. AQAP said the plane was on its way to Aden from the Yemeni capital of Sanaa to Yemen's port city of Mocha when it was hit by the explosive device. The AQAP claimed responsibility for the attack in a statement posted on the website of the al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.

– Syrian tanks swept into a border town overnight, in the latest assault to crush a three-month uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, that has driven thousands of refugees to flee to Turkey. In a pattern witnessed in other cities and towns besieged by troops and armor following street protests demanding political freedoms and an end to Assad's autocratic rule, residents said loyalist forces commanded by Assad's brother Maher pushed into Jisr al- Shughour. At least five helicopters opened fire in the northwestern town after security forces on the ground killed five protesters, said the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The violence came on a day of nationwide rallies against Assad, as unrest showed no sign of abating despite the harsh crackdown by his authoritarian state, reports Reuters.

– Japan's Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear plant is expected to be out of service for at least three years, officials said today, in the first official word on the fate of the crippled plant since last month's meltdown. Experts say that without a major earthquake or tsunami in the near future, the plant will be out of service for at least two years, the Wall Street Journal reports. Experts say that without a major earthquake or tsunami in the near future, the plant will be out of service for at least two years. In other nuclear news: Russia's upper house has voted to ban nuclear power in the country, the RIA Novosti news agency reports. The ban, which takes effect on Jan. 1, will include all nuclear power plants and all coal-fired power plants. Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who has been strongly criticized for his response to the Fukushima disaster, was defeated in a referendum on a nuclear energy ban, Reuters reports.

– With the price of food on the rise, the G20 has agreed to monitor world supplies to prevent a food crisis, according to a draft statement seen by Reuters. The group will also work with the UN to promote democracy and reform, the statement says. In Syria, meanwhile, security forces opened fire on protesters in the town of Rankus, killing at least five, according to opposition groups. Click for more on the crisis in Syria.

– Syria is in danger of civil war if Bashar al-Assad doesn’t start talking to opposition leaders soon, his cousin tells Reuters. “There is a real risk of civil war if there is no political dialogue between the government and the opposition,” says Ribal al-Assad. “There is a real risk of civil war if there is no political dialogue between the government and the opposition.” Bashar’s regime is controlled by a corrupt inner circle that is trying to keep him in power, says Ribal al-Assad. Religious extremists are taking over the uprising, he says, and “a corrupt inner circle is manipulating the president into resisting concessions to the protest movement.”

– Jack in the Box is the latest fast-food chain to pull toys from kids' meals as health-conscious cities such as San Francisco push for healthier options, Reuters reports. The chain's managers at Los Angeles locations said the move took effect Thursday. San Francisco and nearby Santa Clara County have passed laws that will require kids' meals to meet certain nutritional standards before they can be sold with toys. Researchers studying autistic toddlers have discovered their brain activity appears to be out of sync at a very early stage—a finding that sheds light on the biology of the condition and might help in earlier diagnosis. The move comes as fast-food companies are under pressure to stop using toys to market children's meals that are high in calories, sugar, fat, and salt.

– The UN Security Council is set to hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to discuss Syria's bloody crackdown on protesters—and Russia, which has shielded Bashar al-Assad from international condemnation, is not happy about it. Syrian opposition leaders met with senior Russian officials in Moscow today, urging the Kremlin to end its support for Assad, reports Reuters. Russia's foreign ministry said the meeting had been arranged at the invitation of a regional cooperation society, and that no official meetings were planned. Meanwhile, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says more than 100 people have been killed across the country today, including 30 in the city of Latakia, reports al-Jazeera.

– Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets across Syria today, defying a military crackdown, as the country’s opposition coalition called for a national salvation conference in Damascus on July 16 to chart a way out of President Bashar al-Assad’s crisis. “We are calling for a national salvation conference to be held in Damascus on July 16,” opposition leader Burhan Ghalioun told al-Jazeera. “It is not a political conference, it is a national salvation conference.” Syrian forces killed 24 civilians today, a prominent rights lawyer said, as tens of thousands called on Assad to step down in some of the biggest demonstrations since a three-month uprising began.

– Hillary Clinton says Moammar Gadhafi needs to "step down from power" and let a peaceful transition of power take place in Libya. "Instead of issuing threats, Gadhafi should put the well—being and the interests of his own people first, and he should step down from power and help facilitate a democratic transition," Clinton told reporters in Spain, where she is on a trip. Earlier, Gadhafi warned that he would attack European countries that support NATO's no-fly zone. "If European countries infringe on our citizens' rights, we will attack them," he told a crowd in Tripoli, according to the Telegraph. "We will hit them in the head, and we will kill them in the name of Allah."

– Betty Ford, the first lady who helped President Gerald Ford overcome his addiction to prescription drugs and alcohol, has died at the age of 93, the White House announced today. She was found dead at her home in Rancho Mirage, Calif., on Tuesday night, the AP reports. The cause of death was unclear, and no cause of death was given for Betty Ford. The first lady, who founded a rehab clinic in her own name, struggled with addiction to drugs and alcohol throughout her life, but she helped her husband overcome it when he was president. Click for more on Betty Ford's life.

– The death toll in the sinking of a Russian boat on the Volga River has risen to 140, with more than 100 still missing, the AP reports. The boat was traveling from the Black Sea to theboat port of Novorossiysk when it collided with a cargo ship on Saturday. The collision is Russia's worst maritime disaster since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Divers are searching for survivors in the frigid waters. The death toll is expected to rise.

– Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Kuwait sent forces to Bahrain in March to help crush protests threatening to force the ruling family there to make democratic changes, Reuters reports. They offered money to Oman and Bahrain for more social spending, and Qatar's Al Jazeera TV toned down its hard—hitting Gulf coverage after meetings between Saudi and Qatari officials. Saudi Arabia has helped damp down democracy movements sweeping the Arab world but is waiting now to see how events play out in places like Syria and Yemen for fear of overplaying its hand. After witnessing the sudden collapse of rulers in Egypt and Tunisia this year, the Al Saud family that monopolises power in Saudi Arabia orchestrated Gulf Arab moves to stop the unrest from spreading through the Gulf region. Saudi, United Arab Emirates, and Kuwaiti forces went to Bahrain in March to help crush protests threatening to force the ruling family there to make democratic changes. They offered money to Oman and Bahrain for more social spending, and Qatar's Al Jazeera TV toned down its hard—hitting Gulf coverage after meetings between Saudi and Qatari officials.

– Syrian troops and pro-government militiamen opened fire on a funeral in the city of Homs today, killing at least 16 people, including 10 mourners, according to an activist group. Another 10 people were killed by security forces yesterday. “We could not bury the martyrs at the city's main cemetery so we opted for a smaller cemetery near the mosque, when the militiamen began firing at us from their cars,” one mourner tells Reuters. In other Syria news: The Arab League's chief visited the country today, but refused to give details of his meeting with President Bashar al-Assad.

– Usain Bolt needed a late surge to narrowly beat fellow Jamaican Nesta Carter in the 100 meters at the Monaco Diamond League meeting on Friday. Bolt overhauled his compatriot, who also ran his season's best of 9.90, in the last 15 meters while American Michael Rodgers finished third with 9.96. “It was not the best start, but I executed well overall,” Bolt told reporters after finding his form in his last scheduled meeting ahead of next month’s world championships. In other news: Michael Phelps has won 14 Olympic gold medals, 22 world championship titles, and set numerous world records, yet the American still regards himself as just a regular guy. “In my eyes, I consider myself a normal person,” the 26-year-old Baltimore resident told reporters at a media conference stuffed full of reporters, television cameras, and photographers. “ Yeah, there are a lot more cameras pointing at me right now than most other people, but this is my life. This is what I consider normal.”

– The European Union is readying new sanctions against Iran if it doesn't do more to rein in its nuclear program, and it's not just the US that's worried. The EU is also ratcheting up sanctions against Syria, Reuters reports. "We will impose further and more comprehensive measures against the regime as long as the repression of the civilian population continues," said EU leaders at a summit in Brussels yesterday. They called for Iran to engage in " constructive and substantial talks" with the West, and said they would tighten restrictions on Syria if Bashar al-Assad's regime continued to repress its population. In other Syria news: Protesters took to the streets of Damascus for the first time today, in what is believed to be the biggest demonstration in the capital in years, the New York Times reports. They were met with a violent response from the security forces, who fired on the demonstrators with automatic weapons. At least 10 people were killed, according to opposition groups. A human rights group says more than 200 people have been killed in the past week.

– British investors looking for a safe place to park their money are increasingly turning to domestic stocks and bonds, according to a Reuters poll of 14 investment managers. The average allocation to UK stocks rose 3 percentage points to 15.5% in July, while allocations to US stocks fell 2 percentage points to 41.3% and those to euro zone stocks dropped 3 percentage points to 14.9%. “The market is starting to get a little bit nervous about sovereign debt problems in the US and Europe,” one investment manager tells the Telegraph. “The UK is a relatively safe place to be at the moment.”

– Four Guatemalan soldiers have been sentenced to 6,060 years in prison for a 1982 massacre during the Central American country's 36-year civil war. The massacre of more than 200 people in the village of Las Dos Erres is the first conviction for a war crime in the country's history, Reuters reports. The soldiers were handed 30 years each for the deaths of each of the 201 people killed in the attack. More than 200 people were killed when Guatemalan soldiers attacked the northern village of Las Dos Erres in 1982 at the height of Guatemala's civil war. More than 200 people were killed when Guatemalan soldiers attacked the northern village of Las Dos Erres in 1982 at the height of Guatemala's civil war. The soldiers were given 30 years of prison for the deaths of each of the 201 killed in the attack.
– An amateur video purports to show protesters removing the body of a dead man and the aftermath of shelling in the Syrian city of Hama. Rough Cut—no reporter narration

– Syria's foreign minister will visit Damascus on Tuesday, in what is expected to be a last-ditch effort to persuade Bashar al-Assad to stop the violence. Turkey's friendship with the Syrian president is near breaking point, and one of Assad's advisers warned yesterday that Turkey would be given short shrift after Turkish Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan said his minister would deliver a "decisive message." Saudi Arabia pulled its envoy late yesterday, in an extraordinary statement read on al Arabiya television, saying Syria's fierce military crackdown on nearly five months of demonstrations had nothing to do with religion, or values, or ethics. In less than 24 hours, the island kingdom of Bahrain and oil-rich neighbor Kuwait followed Saudi Arabia's lead by summoning their ambassadors from Damascus for consultations.

– The worst riots in Britain's modern history may have been sparked by a solar storm, NASA scientists say. The northern lights and the aurora borealis have been spotted as far south as England and Colorado in a phenomenon known as a coronal mass ejection, or CME. Three large CMEs caused US government scientists to warn of solar storms that can cause power blackouts and the aurora borealis, or northern lights, caused by disturbances in the Earth's atmosphere, NASA said. The CMEs, which can cause power blackouts and the aurora borealis, have been spotted as far south as England and Colorado, Reuters reports.

– In-flight entertainment on some Qantas planes contains a movie that purports to explain the mysteries of female sexual pleasure. The 50-minute French film The Female Orgasm Explained, which includes naked scenes, is carried on long-haul flights only, complete with a warning that it is for mature audiences only, Reuters reports. Qantas says the movie was screened by its program team before being licensed for in-flight entertainment.

– The UN Security Council is set to hold an emergency meeting today to discuss Syria, after the US and other nations stepped up sanctions against Bashar al-Assad's regime. Syria's ambassador to the UN in New York has fled the country, according to al-Jazeera. The US, Britain, France, and Turkey have also imposed sanctions, and the EU is preparing sanctions of its own, according to the Wall Street Journal. Russia, Syria's biggest trading partner, has reportedly agreed to sell the regime weapons, though Russia's foreign minister warned yesterday that such a move could lead to civil war.

– A pilot with the Royal Air Force's Red Arrows aerobatic team was killed today when his plane crashed at an air festival on the southern coast of England, reports Reuters. The cause of the crash isn't yet clear, but the air force said in a statement that the "show must go on."

– With the fall of Moammar Gadhafi, the world is turning its attention to Syria, where the UN says more than 2,200 people have been killed in the five-week-old uprising against President Bashar al-Assad. The EU and the US are drafting a Security Council resolution that would call for sanctions against Assad and several of his top officials, diplomats tell Reuters. China, Cuba, and Russia were among the few delegations to speak in support of Syria at the UN Human Rights Council, rejecting what they called any interference with its sovereignty or territorial integrity. In Libya, meanwhile, rebels took control of most of Tripoli and were closing in on the capital, reports the Wall Street Journal.

– Bashar al-Assad celebrated the end of Ramadan by hosting an iftar meal for Islamic leaders and scholars in the capital of Damascus, according to footage aired on Syrian TV. Assad blamed the nation's unrest on "morals" in Syrian society but said the army was protecting the nation, as government forces continued a raid on an eastern tribal region, extending the crack down on pro-democracy protests. In other Syria news: Opposition figures and activists fear that the successful use of force to topple Libya's Moammar Gadhafi may encourage Syrians to follow Libya's example, Reuters reports. The US and European push to impose UN Security Council sanctions on Syria for its bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators is meeting fierce resistance from Russia and China. The UN Security Council will hold a rare emergency meeting today to discuss sanctions. In other Syria news: Assad's forces raided an eastern tribal region for a second day today, extending the crack down on pro-democracy protests, activists say. Tottenham Hotspur have signed Togo striker Emmanuel Adebayor on a season-long loan from Manchester City, the London club said yesterday. Adebayor, who played for Spurs' bitter north London rivals Arsenal before joining City in 2009, spent part of last season on loan at Real

– The stock market's roller coaster ride over the past few months has been good for one UK investment firm, at least according to its founder. Hargreaves Lansdown saw a surge of new business in July and August, up more than 30% from a year earlier. " Volatility is quite good for business," Peter Hargreaves tells Reuters. "I think a lot of people become very disillusioned with where they are investing." Hargreaves Lansdown's net new business inflows in July and August were more than twice what they were in the first two months of the year.

– A roadside bomb hit an Iraqi military minibus in northern Iraq today, killing four and wounding 10, police sources tell the AP. The bomb hit the minibus as it was traveling through a Shiite neighborhood in Mosul, the country's second-largest city. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blast, but it follows a series of attacks in the country's north that have raised fears of a return to the widespread sectarian fighting that brought the country to the brink of civil war more than a decade ago.

– At least three people were killed and more than 1,000 injured as protesters stormed Israel's embassy in Cairo today, burning the Israeli flag and hurling documents from the embassy's windows, Reuters reports. Israel evacuated its ambassador and staff after the protests broke out, and the US is urging Egypt to protect the embassy, which it has poured billions of dollars into Egypt since making peace with Israel in 1979. The unrest comes a day after President Obama's speech on jobs, in which he called for an extension of the payroll tax cut. Here's what else you need to know about today's unrest: At least five people were killed in today's protests, including two policemen, al-Jazeera reports. At least 30 people were injured in clashes outside the Israeli embassy earlier in the day. At least one person was killed in clashes outside the Israeli embassy earlier in the day.
