– Syria is in danger of descending into civil war, Turkish Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan warned in an interview published in an Egyptian newspaper yesterday. “I am worried that there will be a civil war in Syria,” he said, according to Reuters. “We want to deepen our ties with Egypt, but I am worried that there will be a civil war in Syria.” He spoke as part of a visit to Cairo, where he told Arab foreign ministers that it is time to run the Palestinian flag up over the UN, ahead of a Palestinian UN membership bid opposed by the US.

– Ireland shocked the rugby world with a 15-6 victory over Australia today, ending the Wallabies' hopes of a third Tri- Nations title in a row. The Irish front row squeezed the life out of their Australian counterparts in the scrum, leading to a number of penalties, which flyhalf Jonathan Sexton and Ronan O'Gara kicked to claim a 15-6 victory. "It's the proudest moment of my career," said captain Brian O'Driscoll. "We knew it was going to be a tough game. We knew Australia were going to come at us hard, but we knew we had to respond. "

– Turkey has suspended talks with Syria and may impose sanctions, Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan said today, the clearest sign yet that Ankara has parted ways with President Bashar al-Assad over his bloody crackdown on anti-government protesters. Turkey has long maintained close relations with Syria, urging him to end a military crackdown on a popular uprising and to launch democratic reforms, Reuters reports. Meanwhile, a UK unconventional gas company could sell first shale gas recovered from its Lancashire project by mid-2013, its chief executive told Reuters, despite an exploration suspension after scientists measured tremors in the area. The company has valued the amount of shale gas in place—not the recoverable volume—at its site near Blackpool at 200 trillion cubic feet, the top end of what is estimated can be recovered from Europe's largest reserves in Poland. "If we were to have a field development plan we would guess that one or two years from next summer is when we 'd start selling gas on a well—by—well basis,'" said Cuadrilla Resources Chief Executive Mark Miller.

– Pope Benedict met with victims of clerical sex abuse in Germany today and expressed his "deep regret" for their suffering, the Vatican said. The meeting came on the second day of Benedict's four-day trip to Germany, where record numbers of Catholics have left the faith in protest at clerical abuse, and where the church faces some 600 requests for compensation. The pope was "moved and deeply shaken" by the meeting, Reuters reports.

– Bashar al-Assad's forces continued their assault on Homs today, using helicopters, tanks, and armored vehicles to try to drive out army defectors, reports al-Jazeera. It's the first serious fighting there since the uprising began six weeks ago. In other developments: The UN's human rights chief warned today that the situation in Syria is "on the brink of civil war," reports AP. He called on the international community to put pressure on the regime to stop the killing. The White House said it was "concerned" by the reports, but stopped short of calling for Assad to step down. In Iraq, meanwhile, the death toll from yesterday's tornadoes rose to 37, reports Reuters.

– Syria's newly formed opposition group is calling on the international community to take action against President Bashar al-Assad's regime, saying in a statement that the outside world has a "humanitarian obligation" to protect the Syrian people, reports Reuters. The statement from the newly formed National Council rejected foreign intervention that compromises Syria's sovereignty, but said the outside world had a humanitarian obligation to protect the Syrian people.

– Turkey has announced that it will impose sanctions on Syria despite Russia and China’s veto of a UN resolution that could have led to sanctions on Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Turkey’s military will conduct an exercise in the southern province of Hatay, where more than 7,000 Syrians have taken refuge from Syrian President Bashar al-Assad’s security forces, according to a military website. Turkey’s prime minister is expected to visit refugee camps in Hatay after he returns from South Africa this week, Reuters reports.

– Syrian troops opened fire on thousands of mourners today as the funeral of a slain opposition leader turned into a protest against President Bashar al-Assad, activists say. At least two people were killed and 10 wounded, according to the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. The funeral of Kurdish leader Meshaal al-Tammo in the eastern Syrian city of Qamishli turned into a protest against Assad, with mourners chanting anti-Assad slogans and calling on him to step down. Meanwhile, Turkey is increasing pressure on Syria with border military exercises, economic sanctions, and the harboring of Syrian opposition groups and army defectors, but Ankara must tread carefully to avoid arousing the suspicion of Arab states or spurring Syrian counter- measures, Reuters reports.

– The deal to sell London’s 2012 Olympic stadium to West Ham United has fallen through, with the British government saying it had become “bogged down” in legal challenges, Reuters reports. The soccer club could still end up renting the stadium under the new plan to keep the stadium in public ownership and the Olympic Park Legacy Company.

– With the Arab League considering suspending Syria over its bloody crackdown on protesters, Bashar al-Assad lifted a state of emergency today and formed a committee to draft a new constitution in four months, the state-run news agency reported. The announcement came as Syrian security forces fired on a protester funeral procession in central Damascus, leaving three dead and 20 injured, according to Reuters. Troops also battled army defectors west of the capital. In other Syria news: Assad's announcement came as the Arab League met in Cairo, but decided not to suspend Syria, instead urging the government and opposition to negotiate an end to the violence. "We will call all of the parties of the opposition and government to hold a dialogue within 15 days," the League's secretary-general said after the meeting. Assad has lifted a state of emergency and promised parliamentary elections by February. But he has deployed tanks and troops across the country to crush persistent demonstrations, casting doubt on the credibility of his reform gestures, pro-democracy activists say. European members of the UN Security Council clashed with Russia and China on Friday by raising concerns about Syria and the looming specter of civil war during a closed-door meeting, council diplomats said.

– Syrian tanks launched an assault on the city of Homs today, leaving at least 25 people dead in one of the bloodiest crackdowns yet in the seven-month uprising, reports Reuters. The Syrian National Council, a newly formed opposition group, said its members were ready to meet with Arab League officials in Cairo on Sunday to discuss ways of ending the violence. The Arab League, meanwhile, decided at a meeting today not to vote on whether to remove Syria from its charter, notes al-Jazeera.

– The death of Moammar Gadhafi has been followed by a wave of anti-government protests across the Arab world. In Syria, at least 13 people were killed by security forces as protesters called for the ouster of President Bashar al-Assad, Reuters reports. Protesters took to the streets in the cities of Homs and Hama after Friday prayers. In Yemen, the death of Gadhafi has led to calls for the government to step down, al-Jazeera reports. "It's time for the government to go," said one protester. "It's time to stop killing people. It's time to stop killing your people. The time for dialogue is over."

– President Obama will deliver his State of the Union address tonight at 9pm Eastern, and it's sure to be an interesting read. Here's what you need to know: The White House has released a transcript of the speech, in which Obama is expected to focus on the economy and his vision for America's future, reports the Washington Post. (Read it in full here.) He's also expected to use the speech to criticize the GOP's handling of the economy, reports the Wall Street Journal. (Read it in full here.) The State of the Union address is the president's first since the death of Osama bin Laden.

– The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court has issued a warrant for the arrest of Moammar Gadhafi's son, Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, on charges of crimes against humanity. The warrant was issued after Saif al-Islam Gadhafi, along with his brother Mutassim Gadhafi, and former Libyan intelligence chief Gadhafi himself turned themselves in to the ICC on June 28, the Wall Street Journal reports. The warrant accuses Saif al-Islam Gadhafi of crimes against humanity, including torture and rape, during the uprising that toppled him from power in Libya.

– Syria is on the brink of civil war and NATO says it's too early to consider military action, Reuters reports. NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen, who is visiting Libya, said yesterday that Syria should learn from the lessons of Libya, where NATO backed rebels won a civil war that resulted in the killing of long-serving leader Moammar Gadhafi. "Now is not the time to repeat what happened in Libya," he said, according to the Jerusalem Post. "Now is the time for the Syrian government to show restraint and allow the Syrian people to take control of their country." Syria's military has launched a major crackdown on protesters, killing more than 300 people in the past week, according to opposition groups.

– The world's longest-serving member of the House of Representatives has announced that he will not seek re-election, reports the AP. Rep. Peter King says in a statement that he has decided not to seek re-election because of the "scandalous behavior" of his wife, Rep. Nancy Pelosi. King says his wife, Rep. Steny Hoyer, and Hoyer's wife, Rep. Tammy Duckworth, "showed blatant disregard for the Constitution and the wishes of their constituents when they voted for President Obama." He says he will not seek re-election because of the "scandalous behavior" of his wife.

– The UN human rights chief warned today of a Libya-style civil war in Syria, as government forces continued their assault on Homs and military defectors increased their ranks. “Where basic human rights are trampled and peaceful demands for change met by brutal violence, people are eventually compelled to have recourse to rebellion against tyranny and oppression,” Navi Pillay told the UN Security Council, according to Reuters. More than 100 people have been killed in Homs in recent days as government forces continue their assault on the city, which has long been the epicenter of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad. “The Arab peace plan died on arrival,” said a Syrian-born scholar in Washington. “There has been no let-up in the violence.”

– The Arab League suspended Syria today over the country's bloody crackdown on protesters, and called on its army to stop killing civilians, reports Reuters. Syria's representative to the Arab League said the move violated the organization's charter and showed that it was "serving a Western and American agenda."

– The Arab League suspended Syria today over President Bashar al-Assad’s continuing bloody crackdown on protesters, and France recalled its ambassador to Damascus. Hours after the League’s move, supporters of the Syrian president attacked the United Arab Emirates’ embassy in the capital, throwing stones and debris at the building and smearing its walls with graffiti, witnesses tell Reuters. Meanwhile, a top Saudi prince said Assad’s refusal to halt the violence has made it “inevitable” he will leave power, according to Reuters. “Inevitably, I think, the lack of response of Mr. Assad to all the efforts made to end the fighting in Syria means that he ‘s taken the view of not accepting these matters,” said Prince Turki al- Faisal.

– With the Arab League deadline for Syria to comply with its peace plan looming, President Bashar al-Assad told Britain's Sunday Times that "the conflict will continue and the pressure to subjugate Syria will continue." "However, I assure you that Syria will not bow down and that it will continue to resist the pressure being imposed on it," he said. Turkey, meanwhile, has contingency plans in place to protect civilians if the violence worsens, Turkish newspapers reported today, according to Reuters. Turkey opposes unilateral steps or intervention aimed at regime change in Syria, but it has not ruled out the possibility of more extensive military action if security forces began committing large-scale massacres. The Arab League, a powerful political group of Arab states, set a deadline on Saturday for Syria to comply with a peace plan, entailing a military pullout from around restive areas, and threatened sanctions if Assad failed to halt the violence.

– BP has set up a fund to compensate victims of the Gulf oil spill, but those who want to sue the company will have to give up that right, says Kenneth Feinberg, the administrator of the 9/11 compensation fund. The $20 billion fund will be "substantially larger" than the one set up by BP, Feinberg tells the New York Times. "There will be more money in this fund than there was in the 9/11 fund," he says. "But it will be more generous than the amount of money that BP has already paid out."

– BP CEO Tony Hayward is taking flak for taking time off to go sailing on the Isle of Wight. Environmental groups say it's insulting to those affected by the Gulf oil spill, and the White House has weighed in, calling it one of a "long line of PR gaffes and mistakes" by Hayward, the BBC reports. BP defended Hayward, saying it was his first day off since the spill began.

– The Coast Guard has sent out robots to try to contain an oil spill spewing into the Gulf of Mexico from a damaged well that exploded last week. Robotic submersibles are being used to search for the source of the leak and to plug it, the BBC reports. Some 1,000 barrels of oil a day are leaking into the sea from the damaged well, officials say. They say the oil leak has the potential to damage beaches, barrier islands, and wetlands across the coastline. Eleven workers are still missing and presumed to have been killed in the accident.

– BP says it has managed to seal the smallest of the three leaks leaking oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Oil is still gushing into the sea at a rate of about 800,000 liters a day, but officials say working with only two leaks makes tackling the spill easier. A controlled burn of the slick to remove oil from open water has also begun. A controlled burn of the slick to remove oil from open water has also begun, the AP reports. BP said the cost of containing the spill and securing the original well is running at about $6 million, the BBC reports. BP said there was a “massive effort” to control the leak. It has never deployed such a structure at a depth of 5,000 feet, and difficulties may occur, it says.

– The US Coast Guard is investigating reports that oil has started washing ashore on the Gulf Coast from a leaking offshore well. Up to 5,000 barrels of oil a day are thought to be spilling into the water after last week's explosion on a BP-operated rig, which then sank. Florida Gov. Charlie Crist declared a state of emergency Friday and Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano urged BP to commit more resources to tackling the catastrophe, the BBC reports. The US navy has been deployed to help avert a looming environmental disaster. The Coast Guard said it had sent investigators to confirm whether crude oil had begun to wash up on parts of the Louisiana shoreline. White House adviser David Axelrod told ABC TV it wanted to know exactly what led to last week's explosion on the BP—operated rig in the Gulf of Mexico.

– President Obama is flying to Louisiana today to see for himself the environmental mess caused by an oil spill off the state's coast. He'll meet with Gov. Bobby Jindal and other officials as well as BP CEO Tony Hayward, who is under fire for the company's slow response to the spill, notes the BBC. Obama's trip is part of a buildup of pressure on BP and other companies involved in the oil spill. Attorneys general from five affected states will meet to discuss legal options, as pressure mounts on BP. Choppy seas and strong winds have been hampering the clean-up operation.

– The explosion that killed 11 workers on an oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico was caused by an exploding bubble of methane gas, according to a BP report into the incident. Workers on the rig described hearing screaming and hollering and said people leapt into the sea to escape, the Telegraph reports. Eye witnesses also said safety mechanisms did not function and that workers were taken by surprise. More than 160 miles of protective booms had been deployed as BP scrambled to find a way to contain oil leaking from a blown-out well on the seabed of the Gulf of Mexico. A containment device lowered over the well to funnel oil to the surface had to be moved on Saturday after ice—like crystals began accumulating inside it. Chief operating officer Doug Suttles said the 98-ton concrete and steel box had to be moved, after ice—like crystals began accumulating inside it. He said BP's engineers hoped they could find a solution to the problem. The aim is to contain as much as 85% of the escaping oil and then funnel it into a waiting tanker on the surface. The latest bid to plug the gushing well comes after previous attempts to stem the flow failed. A growing slick from the BP-leased rig is threatening an environmental disaster along US coasts.

– The US government is demanding that BP clarify its commitment to pay for the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The Obama administration wants to know whether the company will honor its pledge not to limit payments to a US statutory cap of $75 million, the BBC reports. BP has promised to pay "all necessary costs for the spill," but the White House wants to know whether the company will also honor other promises to clean up the spill and pay expenses for damage claims. BP says it has applied oil dispersants to the source of the leak, the AP reports. Mississippi has become the third state to have oil wash up on its coast.

– The first oil from the Gulf spill has entered an ocean current that could carry it to Florida and up the east coast of the US. A small portion of oil sheen is in the Loop Current, which circulates in the Gulf, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said. A government statement said it would not rest until the leak was permanently sealed and the spill cleaned up. Meanwhile, a top coast guard official told the US Senate that oil from the spill may reach the southern Florida coastline, the BBC reports. Any oil that does wash up is likely to be in the form of tarballs, which are a little easier to manage.

– The US government has told BP it has "fallen short" in its ability to provide accurate information about the Gulf oil spill, reports the BBC. In a letter to the company, the Obama administration demanded that BP "act in a transparent manner and promptly make all information public." Earlier, BP said more oil than the 5,000 barrels a day it first estimated were gushing from the burst well. BP said a long tube it inserted into the gusher at the weekend was now siphoning 5,000 barrels a day, but that more was escaping. The US government has formed a team to develop a more precise estimate of the amount of oil gushing from the well. BP said it had siphoned 2,200 barrels in the 24 hours to midnight on Thursday, down from an estimate of 5,000 barrels earlier in the day. Two Greenpeace campaigners who unfurled a flag showing the company's logo smudged in oil and the words "British Polluters" came down unassisted. Six others held banners as they greeted staff at a side entrance to the ground. A Greenpeace spokesman said the protesters chose to come down because they had "made their point."

– Interior Secretary Ken Salazar has promised to "keep our boot on BP's neck" until the oil spill is cleaned up. Salazar, who is on a tour of the Gulf, said the British company had missed its deadline to plug the well, but had agreed to pay clean-up costs beyond the current $75 million liability limit, the BBC reports. He said the US would hold BP accountable "civilly and in whatever way is necessary." Salazar's comments come as BP began sharing details of its internal investigation into the cause of the spill.

– President Obama today extended his ban on deep-water drilling for six months, as his administration seeks to regain public confidence in its handling of the Gulf oil spill. In an op-ed in the Wall Street Journal, Karl Rove argues that Obama has been too slow to react to the spill, and accuses the White House of being "incompetent" in its handling of the situation. "It is clear that the White House has been woefully unprepared for this crisis," he writes. "They have been slow to react to other disasters, and have been slow to respond to warnings about the dangers of deep-water drilling." Click here for Rove's full column.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spilling in the Gulf of Mexico has failed, the company announced today. The company will now shift to a new strategy, one that involves shooting mud into the gushing well in a bid to plug it. "We have been unable to overcome the flow," said BP's chief operating officer, who added that the "top kill" operation will be delayed at least another 24 hours. President Obama, for his part, described the continued oil flow as "as enraging as it is heartbreaking."

– The feds have launched a criminal and civil investigation into the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Attorney General Eric Holder announced today. Holder did not say which companies or individuals were being targeted, the BBC reports. Earlier, BP launched a new attempt to try to contain the spill using undersea robots to cut off the fractured pipe and seal it with a cap. BP said the spill—the largest in US history—might be capped within 24 hours. Meanwhile, the US government said it would launch criminal and civil proceedings against BP. At one stage the share price hit its lowest level for 15 months, as stock markets digested the news that the US was "prepared for the worst scenario" that the leak might not be stopped before August. BP's share price has closed down 13% after falling at one stage to its lowest level in 15 months. The sell-off came as the firm's so-called "top kill" bid failed. BP said later that it hoped to contain the spill—the largest in US history—by sealing the fractured pipe with a cap. Meanwhile, BP's efforts to cap the leaking well got back on track as a saw that had become stuck in a thick pipe on the sea bed for hours was freed.

– The cap on the gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico is apparently working—at least temporarily. BP lowered a containment cap over the well today, in the hope of collecting some of the oil and siphoning it to ships on the surface. Coast Guard chief Thad Allen said rough estimates had the cap capturing about 1,000 barrels a day, reports the BBC. It could take 48 hours to know if the system is working, and President Obama arrived in Louisiana for his third visit to the region since the spill began.

– President Obama took his criticism of BP CEO Tony Hayward to a new level in an interview airing today, saying that Hayward “wouldn't be working for me after any of those statements” and that “I know whose ass to kick.” “I want my life back,” Obama said. “And the Gulf is—it’s a big ocean.” Obama said he had consulted with experts before making his decision on how to handle the spill, and that he had visited the Louisiana coast “so I know whose ass to kick.” BP shares dropped another 5% on the news, notes the BBC.

– British PM David Cameron will meet President Obama in Washington this weekend to try to ease tensions over the Gulf oil spill, the BBC reports. London Mayor Boris Johnson has expressed concern about "anti-British rhetoric that seems to be permeating from America," and he wants to see "a bit of cool heads rather than endlessly buck—passing and name—calling." Meanwhile, BP shares have fallen to their lowest level since 1997 amid fears of huge US penalties. President Obama met with relatives of the 11 workers killed in the explosion on the BP leased oil platform in the Gulf of Mexico yesterday. The US government has given BP 72 hours to present its latest plans to clean up the oil spill. BP says its containment effort is going well, but there are signs of mistrust between the company and the government. The US Justice Department is mulling legal action to make sure BP has enough funds to cover the damage and compensate those affected by the slick. That could mean shareholders are not paid dividends, which would infuriate investors and hit pension funds.

– President Obama arrived in Mississippi today for his fourth visit to the Gulf of Mexico since the Deepwater Horizon oil spill began spreading there, the BBC reports. He'll meet with state officials and tour the coast before heading to Alabama and Florida. "The spill will have the same impact on the US psyche as 9/11," Obama told Politico. "It's going to shape how we think about the environment for years to come." Meanwhile, BP's board is meeting to decide whether to suspend dividend payments, the Telegraph reports.

– Tony Hayward's testimony before a House panel is over, but don't expect to hear anything new from the BP CEO. Henry Waxman and other members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee slammed him for his company's "astonishing complacency" in the face of the Gulf oil spill, and for cutting corners to save money, reports the BBC. (One BP partner accused the company of "reckless" behavior in the face of the spill, but BP fired back that it "strongly disagrees with Anadarko Petroleum, who said BP's behavior in the run—up to the disaster was—reckless.") BP also agreed to set up a $20 billion compensation fund for victims. Click here for more.

– BP's share price took a nosedive today as the company announced that the cost of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill has now hit $3.5 billion, the BBC reports. The figure includes the cost of the spill response, containment, relief well drilling, grants to Gulf states, and claims paid. The company's share price has plunged since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded in April. BP's top bosses are due to address staff in Aberdeen today to reassure them the company has no plans to leave the North Sea.

– BP removed the containment cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico today after the US Coast Guard demanded that it be done in as quickly as possible. The company said it would wait for the Coast Guard's approval before putting the cap back in place, reports the New York Times. The move came as BP announced the appointment of Bob Dudley as the company's new chief of oil response, effective immediately. Dudley, who grew up in Mississippi, has 30 years of experience in the oil industry and joined BP 18 months ago, the BBC reports. He will replace Tony Hayward, who has been widely criticized for his handling of the spill.

– The town of Jean Lafitte, La., may look like a ghost town in the wake of the BP oil spill, but it's far from it, the BBC reports. "It looks like a ghost town around here," says the town's mayor. "But there are those who are offering it qualified praise for the work it is doing." In fact, the town is now home to BP's workers, and local officials are meeting in the mayor's office to praise the company's efforts.

– A Taiwanese tanker refitted to scoop up oil from the Gulf of Mexico is undergoing testing at the site of the spill. The "A Whale" is designed to vacuum up oily water, separate the oil, and return the water to the sea, a Coast Guard spokeswoman tells the BBC. Much smaller skimming vessels have been working off Louisiana, but they have been affected by rough seas. Shares in BP have risen amid speculation that Middle East investors may buy stakes in the oil giant. The shares closed up 3% at 333.3p following media reports suggesting that BP is seeking investment from Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds. BP refused to comment directly on the speculation, but said it welcomed new investors. The oil company has been seen as a possible takeover target following the recent collapse in its share price. Its shares have more than halved in value following the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. There are now more than 44,000 people working on the operation.

– The US government has given BP 24 hours to provide detailed plans and timelines on how it will stop the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, reports the BBC. The information is needed before BP is allowed to change caps on the oil well. Meanwhile, BP says its operation to drill a relief well to stop the spill is slightly ahead of schedule. A spokeswoman for the company told the BBC it was slightly ahead of the original schedule of completion in August. BP began drilling two relief wells in May BP says its operation to drill a relief well to stop the Gulf of Mexico oil leak is slightly ahead of schedule. A spokeswoman for the company told the BBC it was slightly ahead of the original schedule of completion in August. Asked about comments made by Bob Dudley, the man in charge, that finishing by 27 July was possible, she stressed the caveats in what he said. Dudley said completion between 20 and 27 July was possible but only—in a perfect world with no interruptions—in a perfect case.

– BP successfully installed a new, tighter cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico today, reports the BBC. It will be a few days before engineers know for sure whether it will work, but it's a "significant progress," said Thad Allen, the US Coast Guard commander overseeing the spill response. BP warned that the cap system had never been deployed at such depths, and that there was no guarantee of success. It also said that the two relief wells being drilled remain the only way permanently to seal the leak. Click here for more.

– BP stopped oil flowing into the Gulf of Mexico for the first time in more than two weeks today in its latest bid to contain the spill. President Obama welcomed the news as a “positive sign,” but said it was still in the testing phase and that it was “important we do n’t get ahead of ourselves.” A test of the well continued for several more hours before BP could reopen it, reports the BBC.

– The US Coast Guard has told BP that it may have to remove the cap on its ruptured oil well in the Gulf of Mexico. Thad Allen, the government’s official in charge of the spill clean-up, said in a letter to BP that he was concerned about signs of a “seepage” on the sea floor near the well and “other undetermined anomalies.” BP has agreed to monitor the sea floor for signs of a new leak, the BBC reports. The company has been allowed to keep the cap on for another 24 hours, but Allen said it would take three days for BP to submit a plan for reopening the well, so that oil could be funneled to the surface. He ordered BP to submit a plan to reopen the capped well if the seepage was confirmed, so that oil could be funnelled to the surface. During this time, the daily leakage of tens of thousands of barrels of oil, which had been capped last Thursday, could resume.

– BP's plan to suck up the oil fouling the Gulf of Mexico may have to be put on hold as ships evacuate the area ahead of Tropical Storm Bonnie. Work on the relief wells that BP hopes to use to permanently stop the leak has been suspended, but the company says the well will remain capped while the area is evacuated, the Guardian reports. Dozens of ships are preparing to leave the spill site as the storm approaches, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. Drilling on a relief well has been suspended for up to two weeks. Meanwhile, BP has confirmed it will begin drilling off the Libyan coast in the next few weeks, following a deal signed in 2007 with Libya on oil and gas development.

– The X Prize Foundation is offering $1.4 million to whoever can come up with a better way to clean up the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The project, called the Wendy Schmidt Oil Cleanup X Challenge, aims to replace "clumsy" and "c clumsy" methods currently used, the foundation said in a press release. The X Prize Foundation, best known for launching the private spaceflight industry, aims to bring about "radical breakthroughs for the benefit of humanity," the release said. Research teams can register for the competition until April 2011.

– BP began the so-called “static kill” today in the Gulf of Mexico, kicking off one of the final steps toward permanently sealing the well. The procedure involves pumping mud and possibly cement into the well, forcing it back down into the pipe. It could take up to two days to determine whether it worked, notes the BBC. BP will then pump more mud and cement into the well from a relief well, which will be ready for a “bottom kill” later in the month.

– BP has completed its "static kill" operation in the Gulf of Mexico and is expected to seal the well in a few days, reports the BBC. It's a risky procedure that involves pumping mud and cement into the well to plug it, but so far it appears to be working. Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig, has seen quarterly profits drop due to legal costs and reduced income from the spill, notes the Financial Times.

– BP has set up a fund to compensate victims of the Gulf oil spill, but fishermen in Louisiana say some of the money is ending up in the wrong hands. They're urging BP to crack down on fraudulent claims, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. The company has already paid out more than $300 million from the fund, but fishermen say some of that money is ending up in the wrong hands. They're urging BP to stop paying claims until it can figure out who's making them.

– In the wake of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Obama administration has taken a hard look at its own response to the disaster. The White House has ordered a review of its response to the spill, which began in April, to make sure it's as effective as possible, the Wall Street Journal reports. Among other things, it's looking at whether the government could have done more to prevent the spill, and whether it could have done more to prevent the damage it did to the environment. The president's chief of staff, Denis McDonough, tells the Journal that the review will help the administration "make sure we're doing everything we possibly can to prevent future spills." The president's chief of staff, Denis McDonough, tells the Journal that the review will help the administration "make sure that we're doing everything we possibly can to prevent future spills." The president's chief of staff, Denis McDonough, tells the Journal that the review will help the administration "make sure that we're doing everything we possibly can to prevent future spills." The president's chief of staff, Denis McDonough, tells the Journal that the review will help the administration "make sure that we're doing everything we possibly can to prevent future

– A huge oil tanker broke up off the coast of northwest Spain in 2002, causing one of the worst oil disasters in history. Eight years later, the Galician region is largely back to normal, the Telegraph reports. The wreck of the Prestige, which was carrying more than 1 million barrels of oil when it ran aground, has been cleaned up and a new pipeline has been laid to deliver more oil to the region. Galicians had feared the region would never recover.

– The cost of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has risen by more than $2 billion in the last month alone, BP said today. The company said it has paid out about $490 million in claims so far, but the company warned that a ban on offshore oil drilling could make it difficult to pay the bill, the Telegraph reports. BP said that plans to permanently seal the well were progressing well and that plans to raise the blowout preventer, which failed to stop the spill, were also progressing.

– BP's ruptured oil well in the Gulf of Mexico is expected to be permanently sealed by Sunday, according to Thad Allen, who says a relief well will intersect the damaged well later today. A mixture of mud and cement will then be pumped in, permanently sealing it. Meanwhile, the US is ordering oil companies to plug 3,500 non-producing Gulf of Mexico oil wells in an effort to prevent leaks, the BBC reports. The Interior Department will also require companies to dismantle 650 unused oil and gas platforms. The order comes five months after an explosion at a BP oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico caused one of the worst environmental disasters in US history. In an order issued on Wednesday, the interior department said wells that had not been used in the past five years for exploration or oil production must be plugged and their pipelines and rig structures dismantled. Louisiana fish deaths raise oil spill questions The dead fish found at Bayou Chaland in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana, include pogies, redfish, drum, crabs, shrimp, and freshwater eel, officials say. Officials in Louisiana's Plaquemines Parish are calling for an investigation after finding hundreds of thousands of dead fish near the Mississippi River. The cause of the fish kill has not been determined, but such events typically happen

– BP’s internal report on the Gulf oil spill is out, and the company says it’s partly to blame for the disaster because some equipment was not working properly, but it also blames other companies, including Transocean and Halliburton, for doing a bad job, the Guardian reports. Transocean called the report “self serving,” saying it contained “ omissions and inaccuracies.” Halliburton called the report “riddled with errors and omissions,” and said it would fight BP’s claims for compensation. Click here for more on BP’s report, or here for a summary of what we know so far about the spill.

– The Coast Guard has confirmed that no oil has spilled in the explosion and sinking of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. The news comes as family members of the 11 missing workers say they have been told they probably died in the blast. The Coast Guard is working to contain any oil that does spill.

– With oil pouring into the Gulf of Mexico, the Coast Guard is gearing up for the worst-case scenario: a huge oil spill washing ashore along the Louisiana coast. The Coast Guard has deployed a fleet of boats, helicopters, and planes to try to contain the spill, and the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports that the Coast Guard has set up a command center in New Orleans. The spill is already moving toward the coast, and the Coast Guard says it's preparing for the worst-case scenario of oil reaching the shore, notes Fox News.

– The Coast Guard has deployed a fleet of boats to contain the growing oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, which has tripled in size in the two days since it was first spotted, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. The Coast Guard has deployed fishermen to try to disperse the oil, which is now moving toward Louisiana's fragile wetlands, notes the Los Angeles Times. President Obama has put a hold on any new offshore oil projects until safeguards are in place to prevent rig explosions like the one that caused the spill.

– BP's chief executive has resigned over the company's slow response to the Gulf oil spill, the Wall Street Journal reports. Tony Hayward, who took over in August, will be replaced as CEO by Bob Dudley, the current frontrunner for the job. In a letter to the company's board, obtained by the Journal, Hayward calls his time at the helm "a unique moment in the company's history" and praises his team's work on the spill. "I am confident that Tony Hayward will lead BP through this difficult period as we move forward," the letter says. "We will continue to work toward a comprehensive solution to the oil spill."

– Underwater robots have reached the ocean floor in an effort to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Guardian reports. The robots will attempt to activate a blowout preventer, a 450-ton valve on the ocean floor that offers the only timely option for stemming the flow. Industry officials acknowledge it could take months to entirely contain leak from well on ocean floor. Meanwhile, BP reported a stunning 134% jump in quarterly profits today, thanks to rising oil prices.

– The oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is far bigger than thought, with up to 5,000 barrels a day now leaking, the US Coast Guard says. The figure is five times the previous estimate of 1,000 barrels a day, reports the Guardian, which notes that shares in BP plunged 7% today on fears that the spill, the biggest in US history, will be even bigger than the 1989 Exxon Valdez spill. The spill is now moving toward Louisiana's fragile islands and barrier marshes, and the state's governor has declared a state of emergency.

– Satellite images show the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has tripled in size in a day, an expert tells the Guardian, and President Obama will fly to Louisiana today to see for himself. Satellite images show the surface area of the spill from the Deepwater Horizon rig, which exploded on 20 April with the loss of 11 lives, had increased from about 1,150 square miles on Thursday to around 3,850 square miles by the end of Friday. “The spill and the spreading is getting so much faster and expanding much quicker than estimated,” said Hans Graber from Miami University, which analyzed the images. Obama will fly to Louisiana today to assess the threat to large stretches of the Gulf of Mexico from millions of gallons of crude oil that has spilled from the remains of a sunken offshore rig. Satellite images found the surface area of the spill from the Deepwater Horizon rig, which exploded on 20 April with the loss of 11 lives, had increased from about 1,150 square miles on Thursday to around 3,850 square miles by the end of Friday. BP's chief operations officer, Doug Suttles, denied that the company was not doing enough, insisting the response effort was “the largest ever mobilised.” BP is one of the most powerful corporations operating in the United States. Its

– BP finally plugged one of the leaks in the Deepwater Horizon oil spill today, but the US Coast Guard says it's unlikely to reduce the overall flow of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, the Guardian reports. The company has deployed a containment box and robot submarines to plug one of the leaks, but it's not expected to do much to reduce the flow of oil, which is at least 5,000 barrels a day. The spill has set off a backlash against the oil industry, with a demand for a ban on future offshore drilling. The anger came as BP executives admitted in a private briefing for members of Congress that the gusher on the floor of the Gulf of Mexico could reach 40,000 barrels a day eight times higher than the current estimate if they can not cap the flow.

– The Obama administration has waived environmental reviews for 26 new offshore drilling projects, even as the Deepwater Horizon oil spill continues to spread into the Gulf of Mexico, the Guardian reports. BP engineers are considering pumping junk—like golf balls or tires—into the well as a solution to the oil spill. “It’s a long shot known as a junk shot, but it might just work,” writes Adam G.abbatt. BP CEO Tony Hayward and Transocean CEO Steven Newman are testifying before a Senate committee today.

– The first underwater video footage of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill has been released, after more than two weeks of delay. The video shows BP engineers trying to lower a giant containment tower over one of the three leaks, the Guardian reports.

– The White House's claim that most of the oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill has disappeared from the Gulf of Mexico is being challenged by at least two independent teams of scientists. At least two independent teams of scientists reported new evidence of oil persisting deep under the surface of the sea, reports the Guardian. Ocean scientists in the Gulf have found giant plumes of oil coagulating at up to 1,300 feet below the surface, raising fears that the BP oil spill may be larger than thought and that it might create huge—and dead zones. Using the latest sampling techniques, they have identified plumes up to 20 miles away from the Deepwater Horizon well head that continues to spew oil into the water at a rate of at least 790,000 liters a day. The largest plume found so far was 90 meters thick, three miles wide and 10 miles long.

– Two Greenpeace activists scaled the BP building in London today and unfurled a flag depicting the oil company's logo "swamped in oil" from a balcony above the entrance of the company's UK headquarters, the Guardian reports. "We are calling on the public to call on BP to clean up the oil in the Gulf of Mexico," said one of the activists, who was carrying the flag with the words "British Polluters." The stunt comes on the heels of a hearing in Congress in which BP was accused of withholding information from scientists.

– The White House has told BP to cut back its use of chemical dispersants to break up the Gulf oil spill by up to 50%, the Guardian reports. EPA chief Lisa Jackson said yesterday that the administration was worried that the clean-up could be worsening the economic disaster in the Gulf. The chemical dispersants, called Corexit 9500, are being used on the surface of the water to break up the oil, but are also being used on the ocean floor to break up the oil. BP says it will comply.

– The White House rewrote a report on the Obama administration's response to the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in a way that suggested the six-month ban on deepwater drilling recommended by independent experts was politically motivated, according to a new report from the Interior Department's inspector general. The report is bound to further inflame Republicans in Congress who have said the ban was politically motivated, and who are demanding an investigation into the White House energy and climate adviser, Carol Browner. Between 2am and 3am on May 27, aides to Browner produced two different edits to the executive summary of a report on recommendations for drilling safety, the Guardian reports.

– As BP prepared to carry out its "top kill" procedure on the Gulf of Mexico, the Washington Post reported today that President Obama's command to "plug the damn hole" didn't take him long to grasp the scale of the spill. Obama cut off a briefing by aides in the first week after the Deepwater Horizon exploded, and the leak suggests that he lost his cool quickly, notes the Guardian. "We will demand they pay every dime they owe for the damage and painful losses they have caused," said the president, who will visit Louisiana tomorrow.

– With heavy oil pouring into the Gulf of Mexico, the US is ramping up efforts to contain the spill and set up a $20 billion claims fund. The government has deployed 1,105 ships to contain the spill and set up a command center in New Orleans, the New York Times reports. BP, which leased the rig that exploded, is paying the bill, but the company faces a slew of lawsuits over the spill, including one from a British pension fund that says it lost millions because of a pipeline leak in Alaska four years ago, the Guardian reports. President Obama, who visited Louisiana last week to see the effects of the spill, says the US is prepared for the worst. "We want to move on to act two, which will feature many dirty shovels," he writes in the New York Times. "But our thirst for oil is the real issue Science will solve this crisis, but the real cause is America's demands and our refusal to pay oil's true price."

– The Justice Department's announcement that it's opening a criminal and civil investigation into the Gulf oil spill didn't stop BP's share price from continuing to plunge. The company's market value has now fallen by more than $40 billion since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded, notes the Guardian. BP's shares dropped another 3% to 446p in London trading this morning, reports the Telegraph. The company's shares have now fallen for 18 years, notes the Independent.

– BP CEO Tony Hayward is likely to be out of a job by the end of the month, according to a report in the Guardian. The company's board is likely to meet today to decide on a replacement for Hayward, who has been under fire for his handling of the Gulf oil spill. The report, based on interviews with people close to the situation, says Hayward is likely to be fired for his inability to contain the spill and his failure to communicate effectively with federal officials. BP's share price fell 5% yesterday after President Obama said he would have fired Hayward if he had been working for him.

– British PM David Cameron has lashed out at President Obama’s criticism of BP, warning that the spat could “ spiral into a tit-for-tat political and diplomatic spat.” “I don't frankly think we are going to reach a solution to stop the release of oil into the ocean any quicker by allowing this to spiral into a tit-for-tat political and diplomatic spat,” said Nick Clegg, Britain’s deputy prime minister. “I am not going to start intervening in a debate which clearly risks descending into diplomacy.” Meanwhile, BP’s chief executive is scheduled to testify before Congress today, the Guardian reports.

– The size of the Gulf oil spill has doubled in the space of a month, with between 20,000 and 40,000 barrels leaking every day, the Guardian reports. BP has played down the size of the spill, but with each new technique it deploys to siphon off more oil, the scale of the disaster and BP's hopelessly optimistic estimates become ever more apparent. The new figure of between 20,000 and 40,000 barrels dwarfs the original estimate by US authorities based on information provided by BP and endorsed by the oil company that the spill was just 1,000 barrels of oil per day. As recently as the end of last month, the official estimate was still as low as 5,000 barrels. BP's board will meet Monday to consider suspending its dividend, the company has confirmed.

– President Obama will try to reassure the nation tonight that the government is in control of the Gulf oil spill in his first Oval Office address. The speech is seen as a chance for Obama to "demonstrate leadership by tackling all the aspects of this crisis, including taking charge of the clean up, getting more help from BP, providing long-term public health and economic recovery, and adopting an oil—use and pollution—reduction agenda to minimize the likelihood of another catastrophe," writes the Guardian's Daniel J. Weiss. BP's credit rating has been slashed to just two notches above junk status, as the potential cost of the Gulf oil spill continues to escalate. The company's CEO will testify before a House panel today.

– If Tony Hayward's testimony to Congress is any indication, the Gulf oil spill will be out for at least two years if BP's efforts to contain it don't work, industry experts tell the Guardian. The experts say that if the company can't plug the well, or if it can't plug it completely with a relief well, the spill could go on for two years or more. Hayward's testimony did little to "salute the reputation of a man in the running for title of most reviled executive in America," notes the Guardian, and it "wiped out any goodwill which he may have generated by having started off his testimony with an apology."

– BP's efforts to contain the Gulf oil spill got a boost today from the White House, which announced that President Obama will visit the region tomorrow, reports the Washington Post. Obama's trip will be his first to the Gulf as president, and he'll meet with state and local officials to see how they're dealing with the spill, as well as with BP and TransOcean, the company that owned the rig that exploded, notes the New Orleans Times-Picayune. In other BP news: The company's best-case estimate of the size of the spill was 20 times higher than the company's public estimate, according to an internal document obtained by the Times-Picayune. Rep. Ed Markey, a Democrat on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, accused BP of lying to Congress about the size of the spill and said the document raises "troubling questions about what BP knew and when." Kevin Costner has developed a "dream machine" that will separate oil from water to save the Gulf, reports the Guardian. BP's chief of staff, Steve Westwell, was delivering a speech at a major oil conference in London today when two Greenpeace protesters interrupted him.

– Tony Hayward's days at the helm of BP are numbered, the company announced today, with American Bob Dudley taking charge of cleanup efforts in the Gulf. Dudley will report to Hayward as head of the newly created Gulf Coast Restoration Organization, which will be responsible for managing the cleanup and evaluation of environmental damage, the company said. “In the near term, my focus will be on listening to stakeholders, so we can address concerns and remove obstacles that get in the way of our effectiveness,” Dudley said. “And we will build an organization that, over the longer term, fulfills BP's commitment to restore the livelihoods and the environment of the Gulf coast.” BP shares hit a 14-year low this morning, the Guardian reports.

– Tony Hayward's days at the helm of BP may be numbered, according to Russia's top energy official. "We know that Tony Hayward is leaving his position and he will introduce his successor," said Igor Sechin, Russia's deputy prime minister and chairman of the country's biggest oil company, Rosneft. Sechin is meeting with Hayward in Moscow today, the Guardian reports. BP's total spending on the Gulf oil spill now stands at $2.65 billion, according to the Guardian.

– The first hurricane of this year's Atlantic season has hit the Gulf of Mexico and BP's oil spill clean-up efforts have been halted. Hurricane Alex, upgraded from a tropical storm last night, is expected to hit Mexico and Texas later today and interrupt the company's efforts for several days, the BBC reports. Waves as high as 12 feet are expected to delay the company's plans to employ a further system to capture more oil from the blown-out oil well until later in the week. controlled burns of crude on the oil's surface, flights spraying dispersant chemicals, and booming operations were all halted yesterday.

– BP's total bill for the Gulf oil spill has passed the $3 billion mark, and the company is now demanding that its partners in the Deepwater Horizon well pick up at least part of the tab. Anadarko and Japan's Mitsui Oil Exploration Company, both minority shareholders in the well, received a letter last month demanding that they pick up at least part of the bill, the Wall Street Journal reports. Meanwhile, BP's oil-skimming "super skimmer" is being put through its paces tested in the Gulf of Mexico, but high wind and choppy seas mean it may be longer than expected before officials know if it can work full time sucking oil from the sea, reports the Guardian.

– BP engineers will spend the weekend trying to install a new cap over the ruptured well in the Gulf of Mexico. If successful, the scheme could stem the spill in time for David Cameron’s first visit to Washington, which is expected to be dominated by discussion of the environmental disaster. The cap currently on the well collects only a fraction of the estimated 35,000—60,000 barrels of oil per day spewing out of the failed blowout preventer on the sea bed, notes the Guardian.

– BP successfully installed a new, tighter cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico last night, reports the Guardian. The company will today test the new cap’s internal pressure to see if it works, and if it will be able to stop the oil flow permanently. Michelle Obama, who visited the Gulf today, urged Americans to support the local economy by visiting the region for their summer holidays, notes the New York Times.

– "There are known knowns. These are things we know that we know." That was Donald Rumsfeld's famous line before the US invasion of Iraq, and it's resurfaced in the wake of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Guardian reports. In his upcoming memoir, Rumsfeld is expected to describe the decision to invade Iraq, the aftermath of the war, and the decision to go after Osama bin Laden, among other things. "There are known knowns. These are things we know that we know," Rumsfeld said in a speech before the start of the invasion, according to the New York Times. "We didn't know what we were going to do. We didn't know what bin Laden was going to do. We didn't know what al-Qaeda was going to do. We didn't know what the Taliban was going to do. We didn't know what Saddam was going to do. We didn't know what the Soviet Union was going to do. We didn't know what Saddam was going to do. There are known knowns. These are things we know that we know."

– Looks like BP's new containment cap is working—at least for now. The company replaced a faulty hose today and says it will be able to conduct a pressure test as early as tomorrow, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. "We landed it this morning," said BP's senior vice president of exploration and production. "I'm expecting that we'll start up." If the test goes well, the company will know whether the cap is working, or if it's a mere temporary fix. For more on the progress, click here.

– Thad Allen, the federal official in charge of the government's response to the Gulf oil spill, said today that BP's latest attempt to plug the well is working, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. The company said in a statement that it would keep the cap in place for another day as it closely watches for signs of new leaks. Meanwhile, the Guardian reports that BP has ordered a major overhaul of the Deepwater Horizon's safety equipment in China, a move experts say is common in the industry to save money.

– BP has admitted that an altered photo posted on its website exaggerated activity at its Gulf oil spill command center. The photo showed workers monitoring a bank of 10 giant video screens displaying underwater images. The picture posted over the weekend showed workers monitoring a bank of 10 giant video screens displaying underwater images. The spokesman said yesterday that three screens were blank in the original picture and a staff photographer used Photoshop software to add images, the Guardian reports. BP has posted a Flickr set of its doctored images. Earlier this week BP admitted some of the oil spill photographs posted on its website had been altered by staff using Photoshop. The American Association of University Professors claims the oil giant is seeking to “buy the silence” of the scientific community in its fight against litigation. But BP says it is only protecting confidential information and is not trying to prevent the discussion of scientific data.

– The chief technician for Transocean, the owner of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig, told a federal investigation yesterday that safety systems were deliberately shut down to help workers sleep. Emergency alarms were disabled weeks before the explosion in order to spare workers from being woken by false alarms, the Guardian reports. The testimony is the latest in a series of apparent safety irregularities uncovered by investigators. BP, meanwhile, is expected to reveal this week that it has found no evidence of "gross negligence" on the part of Transocean, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune.

– Tony Hayward's decision to step down as BP's CEO at the end of the month has only added to the controversy surrounding the company. In an interview with the BBC today, Hayward said that while BP was “absolutely responsible” for the Gulf oil spill, the company was not at fault. “This was not our accident,” he said. “The Gulf of Mexico explosion was a terrible tragedy for which as the man in charge of BP when it happened I will always feel a deep responsibility, regardless of where blame is ultimately found to lie.” In other BP news, it emerged today that the British government will lose hundreds of millions of dollars as a result of the spill, reports the Guardian.

– BP will offer Gulf residents affected by the oil spill one-time payment in return for waiving their right to sue the company, the Guardian reports. The move is part of the company's plan to lower its legal liabilities in the wake of the spill, but it remains to be seen whether the offer will be enough to ease the pain of affected residents. US lawyers say tens of thousands of people, particularly in the fishing and tourism industries, are weeks away from bankruptcy.

– BP says it has completed its "static kill" operation in the Gulf of Mexico, a key step in its plan to permanently seal the well. The company says heavy mud was pumped in to plug the well, and the procedure, which involves pumping mud and cement into the well, is now over, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. "We are very pleased to have reached this significant milestone," said President Obama, who declared the spill "the largest accidental oil spill in history" last night. "The long battle is finally close to coming to an end, and we are very pleased with that." The procedure, which involves pumping heavy mud and cement into the well, is similar to BP's "top kill" operation in May, but this is the first time it has been used more than 5,000 feet underwater. The Guardian reports that the EPA is facing internal dissent from its scientists for approving the use of huge quantities of chemical dispersants to break up the oil slick.

– The number of dolphins, sea turtles, and brown pelicans injured or killed by the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has spiked, even as US officials say the oil is rapidly disappearing. Some 1,020 sea turtles were caught up in the spill over the past week, according to figures released by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The number of dolphins injured or killed has also spiked, while the number of brown pelicans injured or killed has also spiked, the Guardian reports.

– The White House is calling for an end to the kind of environmental exemptions that allowed BP to drill its blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico with little scrutiny, the Guardian reports. The Obama administration is calling for environmental reviews for all new deepwater oil drilling, spelling an end for the time being, to the kind of exemptions that allowed BP to drill its blown-out well in the Gulf of Mexico with little scrutiny. The announcement came after a report by the White House Council on Environmental Quality that found BP received environmental exemptions based on decades—old data for its well that exploded in April, killing 11 workers and triggering the US's worst—ever oil spill. But hysteria did the real damage in the Gulf. BP has failed to update its oil spill emergency plan in the Gulf of Mexico more than three months after the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded in apparent violation of federal regulations, the Observer reports. The company was lambasted by US politicians for having a response plan which, even before the explosion, appeared to have serious flaws.

– The Gulf oil spill is taking a heavy toll on the insurance industry. Hiscox, a British company that specializes in maritime insurance, has seen its first-half profits drop 44%, while Amlin, a US firm that specializes in workers' compensation insurance, saw its profits fall 70%, the Guardian reports. Both companies say they are taking a hit from claims and losses related to the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. Hiscox's CEO says the company has already suffered "significant losses" from the spill. "We had the UK winter freeze and windstorm Xynthia in Europe, we had volcanic ash and we had Deepwater Horizon," he says.

– BP's plan to drill for oil in the Arctic has hit yet another snag. The company had hoped to become the first foreign company to explore for oil in the region, but the Greenland government put the kibosh on the plan after the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, the Guardian reports. Greenland's energy minister said the decision was "entirely the result of the events in the Gulf of Mexico." BP "has decided not to pursue exploration in Greenland at this time," the company said in a statement.

– BP's long-awaited report on the Gulf oil spill is out, and it blames TransOcean for most of the mistakes that led to the worst offshore spill in US history, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. The report doesn't single out anyone in particular, but TransOcean is likely to take most of the blame for the accident, because it was responsible for many of the mistakes that led to the explosion on the Deepwater Horizon rig, says the Guardian. BP, meanwhile, is trying to paint TransOcean as the villain in the report. "Multiple companies and mistakes were at the heart of the Deepwater Horizon blowout," BP said in a summary of the report. TransOcean fired back, saying the report was "riddled with errors and fabrications." Click here for more.

– BP's incoming CEO says the oil giant will probably end up paying less than it has to for Gulf oil spill victims, the Guardian reports. Bob Dudley's comments reflect BP's growing confidence that it can emerge from the disaster in a relatively strong position. The White House has ordered BP to pay $20 billion into a compensation fund over three and a half years. BP still doesn't know how much it will have to contribute, but Dudley's comments reflect BP's growing confidence that it can emerge from April's Deepwater Horizon disaster in a relatively strong position.

– BP's final solution to the Gulf oil spill could be in place by Sunday, five months after the disaster began, the Obama administration says. But the effects of the spill, which has turned the Gulf into an environmental and economic disaster zone and brought one of the world's biggest oil companies to the brink of ruin, will be felt for months, if not years, officials say. BP's permanent plug could be in place by Sunday, Coast Guard commander Thad Allen told reporters, but the effects of the spill could be felt for years. BP's brand value has been "destroyed," according to a leading marketing consultancy, which has dumped the oil giant from its index of the world's best brands for the first time in 11 years, reports the Guardian.

– Five months after the worst oil spill in American history, BP's Macondo well is "effectively dead," the US government announced today. A final plug in the well was pumped in yesterday, and retired Coast Guard admiral Thad Allen, the government's point person on the spill, said in a statement that "we can finally announce that the Macondo 252 well is effectively dead." BP shares rose sharply in after-hours trading, the Guardian reports. The company's share price has fallen sharply since the Deepwater Horizon disaster, but analysts believe the cost of the spill, including cleanup costs, will be less than $20 billion.

– President Obama's national commission investigating the Gulf oil spill released a report today saying the White House blocked federal scientists from providing a better sense of the environmental impact of the spill. Two weeks after the BP rig exploded, scientists from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration asked the White House for permission to release their worst-case scenarios for the spill, the Guardian reports. The White House office of management and budget blocked the release of the models, the report said.

– Looks like BP won’t be leaving the US anytime soon. CEO Bob Dudley told the Confederation of British Industry today that the company is working to rebuild trust with federal and state officials, and will continue to find and produce oil and gas in the deep waters of the world’s oceans. “There is too much at stake for BP to walk away from the United States,” he said, according to the Telegraph.

– The lead investigator for the presidential commission investigating the Deepwater Horizon oil spill has told the panel that BP and Halliburton knew that the cement used to seal the well didn't meet industry standards before the explosion. Halliburton, which was hired by BP to cement the well, learned of the flaws in the cement in February and informed BP on March 8, the Guardian reports.

– Looks like BP's clean-up costs in the Gulf of Mexico will be even higher than previously thought. The company said today that it now expects the Deepwater Horizon oil spill to cost it an additional 7.7 billion dollars, reports the Guardian. That brings the total cost so far to nearly 40 billion dollars. BP also announced that it lost a quarter of its profits in the third quarter because of the spill.

– The head of the presidential investigation into the Gulf oil spill says the companies involved in the disaster were operating under a “culture of complacency” and need “top-to-bottom reform.” William Reilly, co-chair of the commission, said there was “ emphatically not a culture of safety” on the Deepwater Horizon rig, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. The commission’s chief investigator, Fred Bartlit, said today that he had found no evidence that BP and other companies took shortcuts to save money, notes the Wall Street Journal. “To date, we have not found a single instance where human beings made a conscious decision to favor dollars over safety,” Bartlit said. Former BP CEO Tony Hayward, meanwhile, tells the BBC that it is “much easier to hate an individual” than a company.

– It's that time of the year again, when we take a look back at some of the best movies and TV shows of the last quarter-century. Here's a look at some of the more notable winners and losers of the Golden Globes, as voted on by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences: ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ;

– BP is facing more than $100 million in fines over a second oil spill in Alaska. The oil giant was sentenced to probation in 2006 for a huge spill on the state's North Slope in 2006, but a federal probation officer says a spill in November last year violated the company's probation, reports the Anchorage Daily News. The probation officer told the court that BP had suffered burst pipelines since 2001 and failed to respond to warnings about the latest spill, the Guardian reports.

– The amount of oil leaking into the Gulf of Mexico could be much smaller than expected, according to the administrator of the BP oil spill compensation fund. Ken Feinberg says he expects to pay out only about $2.3 billion from the fund, because half the claims have no supporting documents and are “ woefully inadequate,” the Guardian reports.

– The White House oil spill commission released its final report today, and it blames BP for the biggest oil spill in US history for a series of "catastrophic" safety lapses that could have been prevented, reports the Wall Street Journal. Among other things, the report says that BP's decision-making on the night of the blowout was flawed, and that the blowout preventer didn't work as well as it should, notes the New York Times. The report also faulted the company's partner on the well, Transocean, for a series of errors, including a failed blowout preventer. The full report is here.

– The US government's lawsuit against BP and other companies involved in the Gulf oil spill could cost the oil company billions in legal costs, the Guardian reports. The suit seeks unlimited damages to cover the costs of cleaning up the oil, the losses suffered by local businesses, and the damage done to the environment. "I've seen the devastation that this oil spill caused throughout the region, to individuals and to families, to communities and to businesses, to coastlines, to wetlands, as well as to wildlife," Attorney General Eric Holder told reporters. BP shares fell 3% in London trading in the wake of the lawsuit.

– The White House's oil spill commission has concluded that the Gulf oil spill was caused by a series of cost-cutting decisions made by BP and its partners, and warned that such a disaster would likely recur because of industry complacency, the Guardian reports. In a preview of its final report, due next week, the national oil spill commission said systemic management failure at BP, Transocean, and Halliburton caused the blow—out in the Gulf of Mexico, and warned that such a disaster would likely recur because of industry complacency. Many of the poor decisions taken on Deepwater Horizon drilling rig before the fatal blow—out on 20 April were taken to save time and money.

– The first confirmed casualty of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has been a baby seabird that washed up on Louisiana's shores. The bird, a Northern Gannet, was found coated in the oil and is being nursed back to health at an emergency rehabilitation center, reports the Los Angeles Times. Sea turtles and marine mammals have also been spotted swimming in and around the oil slick, but no confirmed impacts have been reported yet. President Obama, who visited the region yesterday, promised that BP "will be paying the bill" for the spill, and Interior Secretary Ken Salazar promised that the government would "keep a boot on BP's neck."

– The Coast Guard has deployed 1,105 ships to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, and the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports that the Coast Guard has deployed 1,105 ships to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. The Times-Picayune reports that the Coast Guard has deployed 1,105 ships to contain the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. BP has deployed 1,105 ships to contain the oil spill. The Coast Guard has deployed 1,105 ships to contain the oil spill. Brazil has asked oil companies operating its offshore fields to provide information on well control systems and to review their emergency response protocols in the wake of the BP Gulf of Mexico spill, Reuters reports.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil fouling the Gulf of Mexico appears to have succeeded only in releasing more oil into the ocean. The company managed to quadruple the amount of oil it collected yesterday, bringing the total to about 890,000 gallons, the New York Times reports. That's about 5% of the total amount of oil that has entered the Gulf, but it's still not enough to make up for the fact that the government's official estimate of 5,000 barrels a day seems to be a massive underestimate, writes Justin Gillis at Gawker. "The stated reason for not getting a better figure is weak indeed," he writes. "Having greater precision about the flow rate would not really help in any way."

– Two members of President Obama's Cabinet have demanded that BP CEO Tony Hayward explain in detail the company's commitment to pay for the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. In a letter to Hayward, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar and Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano say the public has a right to know whether BP will "reimbursement all of the damage that has occurred or that will occur in the future as a result of the oil spill." They asked for "immediate public clarification" of BP's "true intentions." Meanwhile, BP announced that it had captured about 20% of the oil flowing from its ruptured well with the help of a mile-long siphon tube. The stock rose more than 2% in London on the news, but later shed its gains, reports the Los Angeles Times.

– The Coast Guard has told BP to fire all the people working on the oil spill cleanup operation in the Gulf of Mexico, reports the Times-Picayune of New Orleans. The news comes as BP announced that it had managed to siphon 5,000 barrels of oil from the gushing well over the past 24 hours, up from 3,000 barrels yesterday. The Coast Guard's order comes as President Obama unveiled a commission to investigate the disaster.

– BP's latest attempt to plug an oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't go as planned and the company's shares fell more than 3% in London as investors waited to see if the gambit would work, reports Reuters. The company said it would make another attempt tomorrow, but gave it only a 60% to 70% chance of success. BP said it would make another attempt to plug the five-week-old leak on Wednesday, but gave it only a 60% to 70% chance of success. The government piled pressure on BP on Monday, and a top official said fines would definitely be imposed on the energy giant for the spreading oil spill. The company insisted it was doing all it could to try to seal a blown-out oil well spewing hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil into the Gulf every day, a disaster that threatens to become the worst US oil spill in history. BP said it would make another attempt to plug the five-week-old leak on Wednesday, but gave it only a 60% to 70% chance of success.
