– BP's latest attempt to plug the gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico failed miserably, and it will take at least a day to plug the well from the bottom up, the New York Times reports. The company used heavy mud to plug the well, but it didn't work, and will take at least 24 hours to do so. It's not clear whether BP will be able to complete the procedure known as a "top kill" on Friday, but the live video feed will at least give the public a sense of what's going on. "It's going to take at least a day to do it from the bottom up," a BP spokesman tells Reuters. "It's a 24-hour operation."

– BP's latest attempt to plug an oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work, and the company has decided to try again, this time with a lower-tech containment cap. It could take four days or longer to know if the plan worked, the Wall Street Journal reports. BP's chief operating officer said the company will try the lower-tech cap, which is designed to capture most of the oil instead of plugging the well in a so-called "top kill" attempt that failed over the weekend. The US Coast Guard, however, says the best option is to drill a relief well, which could take two months to complete, Reuters reports.

– With oil still flowing into the Gulf of Mexico, the Obama administration is cracking the whip on the offshore drilling industry. The Justice Department has launched a criminal and civil investigation into BP, and federal agencies, including the FBI, are participating, Attorney General Eric Holder told reporters yesterday. "If our laws were broken leading to this death and destruction, my solemn pledge is that we will bring those responsible to justice on behalf of the victims of this catastrophe and the people of the Gulf region," President Obama said. Meanwhile, BP's shares stabilized yesterday and parts of the oil slick threatened Florida, Reuters reports.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico appears to be working, officials said today. The company said it had collected 6,077 barrels yesterday, or about 220,000 gallons, and that the figure is expected to rise over the next few days. BP said it had captured 10,500 barrels yesterday, or about 439,950 gallons, and that a second containment system should enable it to soon control the vast majority of oil spewing from the leak about 1 mile below the water's surface. The progress came as the company's Chief Executive Tony Hayward said he has no plans to quit over his handling of the environmental disaster marked by a string of failures since the April 20 rig explosion that triggered the oil spill. Thad Allen, the Coast Guard admiral heading up the federal relief effort, estimated the maximum collection from the containment device at about 15,000 barrels a day. – BP stock hit a 14-year low in the US today as the company's latest attempt to contain the Gulf oil spill yielded mixed results. The stock closed down 6% at $45.58 on the New York Stock Exchange, reports the Wall Street Journal. BP's share price has fallen 24% since the beginning of the week as investors worry about the company's ability to pay for the spill, and the company's chief executive, Tony Hayward, is in hot water with the White House over the company's handling of the spill.

– The Coast Guard's latest estimate of the amount of oil being spilled in the Gulf of Mexico shows that at least 2 million to 4 million barrels have already entered the ocean, reports the New York Times. That's equivalent to about 2.5 hours worth of US oil consumption—or 833,000 barrels an hour—on Day 53 of the worst oil spill in US history. The news that the flow rate may be as high 40,000 barrels has sliced 40% off BP's market capitalization, and led analysts to speculate about lasting reductions in deepwater drilling and the resulting impact on both long-term oil supply and the fate of climate change legislation. Investors are right to fear the long-term impact on the company, but they exaggerate the impact on the wider industry and the prospects for climate change legislation, an expert tells Reuters.

– Scientists working on the Gulf oil spill released an updated estimate today of the amount of oil being spilled, with the best guess being that between 35,000 and 60,000 barrels are leaking daily. That's a significant jump from the last estimate, which put the flow rate at 20,000 to 40,000 barrels per day, notes the Washington Post. It's a "significant step forward," said Energy Secretary Steven Chu, who added that the figure represents a "significant step forward in our effort to put a number on the oil that is escaping from BP's well."

– BP CEO Tony Hayward watched a yacht race off the English coast today, sparking new controversy in the United States as his company struggles to plug its huge Gulf of Mexico oil leak. Sheila Williams, a spokeswoman for the British energy giant, said Hayward was spending time with his teenage son at the Isle of Wight boat race after devoting most of the past two months to the oil spill away from his family. In other BP news: Anadarko Petroleum, owner of a quarter of the well gushing into the Gulf, broke its near-silence on the spill to squarely pin blame—and financial responsibility for claims—on BP. The company, which owns a quarter of the well, said the British company was likely guilty of “willful misconduct” and should shoulder the financial burden for the worst US oil spill, reports Reuters. BP agreed to a $20 billion fund for Gulf claim damages today.

– One of New Orleans' most high-profile chefs is suing BP in an effort to help the city's seafood industry recover from the Gulf oil spill. Susan Spicer is seeking class-action status for the suit on behalf of restaurants that rely heavily on local seafood, reports the Times-Picayune. Because of the spill, they expect to lose customers because of lower tourism and convention business, contamination fears, and significantly higher prices, the complaint said. Meanwhile, BP spent another 300 million on the Gulf spill response in the past three days, bringing its total bill to 2.65 billion, notes Reuters.

– The BP oil spill is killing more birds than the Exxon Valdez spill, but one of the worst was a harmless 5 tons of oil in the Baltic Sea in 1976, writes Arne Jernelov in Nature. That spill killed more than 60,000 long-tailed ducks wintering in the area after they mistook the slick for an attractive patch of calm water. By contrast, fewer than 1,200 birds have been recorded killed by the Deepwater Horizon rig, which has led to a leak of a gigantic 250,000 to 400,000 tons of oil in the Gulf of Mexico. About 60,000 birds were killed off Alaska in 1989 by the accident usually known as the Exxon Valdez spill. – The blowout preventer that failed to stop the Deepwater Horizon oil spill had a dead battery, leaks in its hydraulic system, a useless test version, and a cutting tool that was not strong enough to cut through steel joints in the well pipe, according to a House energy panel investigation. Rep. Bart Stupak, chair of the panel's subcommittee on oversight, said the device was anything but, the Washington Post reports. Meanwhile, BP's top executive, Lamar McKay, who visited Capitol Hill yesterday, "couldn't have been any more slippery if he had just bathed in the Gulf of Mexico," Stupak said. "What changes has the oil company made to stop its record of accidents, the latest causing 5,000 barrels a day to pour into the gulf?"

– A mile below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico, a mile below the surface, a mile below the surface—and one mile below the surface. That's the distance between BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spill and the one-mile-deep leak that has been leaking since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded two weeks ago, reports the Washington Post. Robotic submarines yesterday saw off the pipe that was leaking and installed a shutoff valve, but BP says that won't do much to reduce the amount of oil being spilled. "We feel great about sealing that leak," a BP spokesman told the Los Angeles Times. "But it's not going to significantly reduce the amount of oil being spilled."

– Coast Guard Adm. Thad Allen will continue to serve as President Obama's point man on the Gulf oil spill after he retires this month, the administration said yesterday. Obama tapped Allen last month to be national incident commander when he labeled the spill an "incident of national significance." Such incidents—usually a natural disaster or terrorist attack—require the president to appoint a federal official to coordinate the government's response. Allen is set to be relieved of his other duties by the end of May, but Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said yesterday that he will continue to serve as national incident commander. Allen said in a statement that the changes will allow him to focus solely on this critical response, and Adm. Robert Papp on the vital work of the Coast Guard. Meanwhile, crews working in the Gulf have found a few more injured or dead wildlife, the Washington Post reports. Officials from several federal agencies listed the animals injured so far. Forty—three birds have been found dead from oil in the gulf, and 23 found—but alive— oiled but alive. That number is up slightly from a few days ago. Authorities have also found 186 sea turtles, most of them dead.

– Interior Secretary Ken Salazar says he's "angry and I am frustrated" that BP hasn't been able to plug the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. "We are 33 days into this effort, and deadline after deadline has been missed," he told reporters after visiting BP's US headquarters in Houston. "If we find they're not doing what they're supposed to be doing, we'll push them out of the way appropriately." Salazar said that if the company is "not doing what they're supposed to be doing, we'll push them out of the way appropriately," the Washington Post reports. Coast Guard Adm. Thad Allen, who is leading the federal response to the spill, acknowledged Sunday that the government is being forced to rely on BP and the private oil sector to try to plug the gusher. BP began pouring mud into the gushing well yesterday in what appears to be a failed attempt to plug it.

– As BP prepared to carry out its "top kill" operation today, the New Orleans Times-Picayune called it "the most critical moment in the oil spill crisis." It's "far from a sure bet," says a BP exec, and the Washington Post says it's "unlikely to succeed." The company will pump heavy mud into the well, but it's not clear if that will do the trick, or if it will just worsen the spill. The top kill is expected to last at least 24 hours, and BP CEO Tony Hayward told reporters last night that it would be 24 hours before they know whether it worked. Click here for more.

– BP's latest attempt to plug its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico didn't work out so well, and the Obama administration is taking the unusual step of urging the company to take full responsibility for the health consequences of the spill, reports the Washington Post. Kathleen Sebelius told BP's chairman in a letter that the government is "very concerned about the impact of disaster on the public health of people in gulf region," and that the CDC is monitoring poison centers and other reporting systems for signs of possible health problems among cleanup workers and residents.

– The White House has ordered BP to pay for the cleanup of the Gulf oil spill, and the company has agreed, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports. The White House ordered the oil giant to pay for the construction of five more large sections of Louisiana barrier island sand berms, which will cost an estimated 360 million. BP announced later Wednesday that it supports the administration's decision, and that the project will cost the company an estimated 360 million. That is double the amount it has spent so far in helping the region respond to the oil spill. Wherever the oil goes, it threatens to obliterate billions of dollars for the region's tourism and fishing industries. The gargantuan blob of light Louisiana crude floating in the Gulf of Mexico has already closed oyster beds, shut down shrimpers, canceled fishing tournaments, and panicked beach hoteliers from New Orleans to Key West. Wherever the oil goes, it threatens to obliterate billions of dollars for the region's tourism and fishing industries.

– As the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico continues to spread, the New Orleans Times-Picayune takes a look at the "handful" of people working to clean it up. Among them are scientists from Tulane University and the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, who are using everything from acoustic devices to remotely operated vehicles to zero in on the source of the leak. Meanwhile, BP has deployed 1,105 workers to mop up the mess, but the Times-Picayune notes that it's not easy: "No grand vacuum for tar balls has been created. No grand vacuum for tar balls has been created; workers in disposable coveralls pick them up by hand. BP has no marsh hoses; men in waders wipe sticky oil off dying grass one handful at a time." Click here for more.

– The White House has accepted no offers of state-of-the-art oil-skimming equipment from other countries in the wake of the BP oil spill, writes Anne Applebaum in the Washington Post. “Here is the hard truth: The US government does not possess a secret method for capping oil leaks,” Applebaum writes. “Yes, the BP oil spill is Obama's Katrina in the Gulf of Mexico, howling winds gathered and swooped down on the coast, ruining homes, destroying levees, and flooding the city of New Orleans. It was an ecological disaster. It was an economic nightmare. And there was absolutely nothing the American president could do about it.”

– BP CEO Tony Hayward appeared before a House panel today for the first time since the Deepwater Horizon exploded, and he took the opportunity to apologize to the American people. “I am deeply sorry for what has happened,” he said. “I want to express my condolences to the families of the 11 people who have died.” (Click here for Hayward's full remarks.) Other highlights from today's hearings, as per Politico, the Washington Post, and the Los Angeles Times: BP agreed to set up a $20 billion escrow account to pay spill-related claims. President Obama said the administration doesn't want BP to be driven into bankruptcy. “I hear comments sometimes that large oil companies are greedy companies or don't care,” said BP chairman Henric Svanberg. “But that is not the case indeed.” Joe Barton, the ranking Republican on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, slammed the Obama administration for pressuring BP to open the escrow account and to suspend dividend payments for the rest of the year. “The political pressure on the corporation exerted in the midst of an investigation is a tragedy of the first proportion,” he said.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico ran into trouble today when a live video stream showed a big hole in the venting system, reports the Washington Post. The venting system, known as an "blowout preventer," is designed to stop the flow of oil by pumping mud into the pipe. The live video stream is expected to continue for a day or two, but BP says it's too early to know whether it will work, reports the New Orleans Times-Picayune. It's not clear whether the venting system will work on the gusher itself.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the Deepwater Horizon oil spill didn't go so well last night, and the company's plan to plug the well with mud will likely take at least a week, reports the New York Times. Meanwhile, Thad Allen said that the Coast Guard has confirmed that the blowout preventer is working properly, reports the Times-Picayune. The news comes as BP announced that it would delay pumping mud into the well until at least tomorrow to make sure it's safe to do so.

– Wyclef Jean is calling on fans to donate to relief efforts in Haiti after the country's devastating earthquake. “They need our help—please help if you can,” the Haitian-born rapper tweeted. “Your money will help with relief efforts,” he added. “The rescue capability that we are delivering, is exactly what is required. Please help if you can.” A spokesman for the singer, who has raised more than $1 million for relief efforts, told the New York Daily News that Jean “is in Haiti to help the people of his country. He will not go anywhere until they need his help.”

– The death toll from the Haiti earthquake now stands at 50,000, according to Haitian officials, but that doesn't mean the country is out of the woods. Relief workers warn that the real death toll could be in the tens of thousands, reports the BBC. "There are tens of thousands of children that have been orphaned," says a spokesman for the UN's Children's Fund. "There are no schools in Port-au-Prince, so many children have lost their parents." In the meantime, looting is spreading and authorities fear that the desperation of survivors could lead to violence. Bill Clinton is in Haiti watching the international aid operation for himself at Port-au-Prince's airport.

– Simon Cowell is planning to record a charity single to raise funds for Haiti earthquake relief, he told the National Television Awards in London last night. Cowell—who won the most popular talent show prize for his X Factor show—says he will try to get the record together in 48 hours, the BBC reports. Cowell also said he had a request to record a single from Prime Minister Gordon Brown and the Sun, and that Girls Aloud star Cheryl Cole would love to be involved. A host of celebrities are planning to take part in a marathon music event in aid of the Haiti earthquake, including The Answer, David Holmes, General Fiasco, and the Beat Poets.
